\titlepage[Imperial College London]% [0]
{A dissertation submitted to Imperial College London\\ [7]
  for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy} [14]
[14]
%% Abstract [14]
\begin{abstract}%[\smaller \thetitle\\ \vspace*{1cm} \smaller {\theauthor}] [15]
  %\thispagestyle{empty} [15]
The discovery of the Standard Model (SM) Higgs boson is one of the primary physics objectives of the Large Hadron Collider at CERN. [38]
This thesis describes a search carried out for the SM Higgs boson on data collected during the 2011 and 2012 proton-proton (pp) collision [61]
runs with the CMS detector corresponding to integrated luminosities of $5.1 fb^{-1}$ and $5.3 fb^{-1}$ respectively. [75]
A detailed description of the search for the SM Higgs boson decaying to two photons [90]
from the full dataset collected at CMS during the 2011 pp collision run is provided. [105]
In particular, the development of signal and background modelling techniques used for statistical interpretations of the data are highlighted. [124]
Results of the search using these techniques from the 2011 dataset are presented. [137]
In addition, an update to the analysis including data taken during 2012 is described and the [153]
results from the combined 2011 and 2012 analyses given. [162]
Results from the combination of several Higgs decay channels at CMS are reported, including those presented in [179]
the International Conference on High Energy Physics in July 2012 at which the announcement of discovery was made. [197]
Ongoing studies to ascertain the properties of the new particle are discussed and some preliminary results from the combined [216]
7 and 8 TeV datasets (corresponding to $5.1fb^{-1}$ and $12.2fb^{-1}$ respectively) are presented. [229]
\end{abstract} [229]
[229]
[229]

File: ./introduction.tex

\chapter{Introduction} [1]
\label{chap:introduction} [1]
[1]
The discovery of a new particle was announced by the ATLAS and CMS [14]
Collaborations on the 4th of July 2012. The long-awaited discovery [24]
followed decades of experimental endeavours in the search for the [34]
Higgs boson, the missing piece of the Standard Model (SM) of particle physics. [47]
If further measurements of the properties of the new particle fit the SM predictions, [61]
the discovery will serve as compelling evidence for the mechanism by which [73]
spontaneous symmetry breaking in the SM occurs, giving rise [82]
to the masses of the fundamental fermions and bosons. [91]
[91]
In Chapter~\ref{chap:theory}, an introduction to the fundamental constituents of [100]
matter and the interactions between them is given. The mechanism by which [112]
the fundamental fermions and bosons acquire mass in the SM, spontaneous symmetry breaking, [125]
is outlined, serving as a motivation for the search for the SM Higgs boson. [139]
Previous searches and indirect constraints are discussed with the chapter concluding in [151]
the search strategies employed at the LHC. [158]
[158]
Chapter~\ref{chap:detector} describes the experimental apparatus required to undertake [166]
such a search, in particular the CMS detector which was used to collect the data upon which [183]
the majority of the author's research was conducted. This chapter includes a section describing [197]
a set of jet energy calibrations derived by the author which were subsequently used  [211]
in the Level-1 trigger system at CMS. [218]
[218]
The main analysis conducted by the author is detailed in Chapter~\ref{chap:hgg}. This chapter [231]
contains a description of the search for the Standard Model Higgs boson in the two [246]
photon decay channel carried out on proton-proton collision data collected at CMS during 2011. [260]
The focus of the chapter is on the background modelling technique developed by the author [275]
used for statistical interpretations of the data. This method was one of two developed at CMS, [291]
which served as a cross-check of the background model used for the published result. [305]
The template signal modelling technique developed for this analysis is also used regularly by the $\Hgg$ [321]
working group at CMS for fast production of results and analysis development in a common analysis framework. [338]
The chapter concludes with the updates for the 2012 analysis including data [350]
collected at a centre of mass 8 TeV. [358]
[358]
Finally, in Chapter~\ref{chap:combinations}, the statistical tools employed and developed [367]
at CMS for the purposes of combined Higgs boson searches are detailed. The chapter includes [382]
the results presented at the July 2012 International Conference of High Energy Physics during which [397]
the announcement of the discovery of the new particle was made by the ATLAS and CMS Collaborations. [414]
The section concludes with a discussion of the ongoing research at CMS intended to ascertain the properties of [432]
the newly discovered particle and includes results produced by the author for the Hadron Collider Physics (HCP) [449]
symposium in November 2012.  [453]
[453]
In addition to the work contained in this thesis, the author contributed towards early studies [468]
in electroweak physics at CMS. The studies undertaken involved the development of a [481]
robust signal extraction technique used to measure the production cross-section of $W$ bosons, [494]
via their decay to electrons, in proton-proton collisions at 7 TeV. [505]
The technique utilised control samples in data to subtract backgrounds from QCD, exploiting the kinematic [520]
signature of the decay $W\rightarrow e\nu$. [525]
Re-establishing well measured Standard Model processes, such as $pp\rightarrow W\rightarrow e\nu$, [534]
was one of the first major goals of CMS, ensuring a high level of understanding of the detector components [553]
and their calibration. The analysis was performed on the first 36$fb^{-1}$ of [566]
data collected at CMS during 2010 and contributed towards the publication containing the $W$ cross-section [581]
measurement from that dataset~\citep{EWK-11-001,AN-11-009}.  [585]
[585]
[585]

\chapter{Theory and Motivations} [3]
\label{chap:theory} [3]
[3]
The goal of particle physics is to identify [11]
the most elemental constituents of matter and understand the nature of [22]
the fundamental forces acting between them. In this chapter, a brief summary of [35]
the components of the Standard Model  will be given along with the motivation for [49]
the search for the Standard Model Higgs boson. [57]
Section~\ref{sec:sm} introduces the mechanism by which mass is generated in the [68]
Standard Model and its relation to the SM Higgs boson is highlighted. [80]
In Section~\ref{sec:smhiggs}, [82]
searches for, and indirect constraints on, the SM Higgs boson before the start up of [97]
the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) are discussed. The section concludes with [108]
how the Higgs boson can be produced and observed in proton-proton collisions at the LHC. [123]
[123]
\section{The Standard Model of Particle Physics} [6]
\label{sec:sm} [6]
[6]
The Standard Model (SM) is  [11]
a well tested, precision model of particle physics. [19]
Within the confines of quantum field theory (QFT),  [27]
the SM provides a description of the electromagnetic, weak-nuclear [36]
and strong-nuclear interactions, incorporating [40]
both relativistic and quantum mechanical effects. [46]
[46]
\subsection{Fundamental Matter Particles} [3]
All of the known fundamental constituents of matter [11]
are spin-$\frac{1}{2}$ fermions. [15]
The equation of motion for a spin-$\frac{1}{2}$ particle with mass $m$, [27]
given in Equation~\ref{eqn:Dirac}, was provided by Dirac~\citep{wu}. [34]
\begin{equation} [34]
(i\gamma^{\mu}\partial_{\mu} - m)\psi = 0 [35]
\label{eqn:Dirac} [35]
\end{equation} [35]
The matrices $\gamma^{\mu}$, $\mu\in{0,1,2,3}$,  are [40]
defined by the anti commutator relation [46]
$\gamma^{\mu}\gamma^{\nu}+\gamma^{\mu}\gamma^{\nu} = 2\eta_{\mu\nu}I_{4}$ where [48]
$\eta_{\mu\nu}$ is the flat space-time metric $(+,-,-,-)$ and $I_{4}$ is the $4\times4$ [60]
identity matrix. [62]
The solutions, $\psi$, to Equation~\ref{eqn:Dirac} yield the particle and anti-particle [72]
states which satisfy the relativistic expression, [78]
$E^{2} = \mathbf{p}\cdot\mathbf{p} + m^{2}$, for a [81]
massive particle with momentum $\mathbf{p}$ and energy $E$. [89]
[89]
The fundamental fermions are separated into those which [97]
do (quarks) and do not (leptons) interact with the strong-nuclear force. [108]
Quarks and leptons are grouped into three generations which share the same properties [121]
but increase in mass. Unlike the leptons, quarks are not seen as free particles in nature, [137]
but rather are confined to exist within baryons composed of three quarks [149]
and quark-anti-quark pairs known as mesons. [155]
A summary of the known fundamental fermions in their three generations is given [168]
in Table~\ref{tab:fermions}. [170]
\begin{table}[htbp!] [170]
\begin{tabular}{|l|l c|l c|l c| c|} [170]
\hline [170]
& \textbf{\Rmnum{1} } & & \textbf{\Rmnum{2}} & & \textbf{\Rmnum{3}} & & \textbf{Charge} \\ [170]
\hline [170]
Leptons & electron & $e$ & muon & $\mu$ & tau  & $\tau$  & -1 \\ [170]
& electron neutrino & $\nu_{e}$ & muon neutrino & $\nu_{\mu}$ & tau neutrino & $\nu_{\tau}$  & 0 \\ [170]
\hline [170]
Quarks  & up  & $u$ & charm  & $c$ & top  &$t$  & $+\frac{2}{3}$  \\ [170]
& down  & $d$ & strange & $s$ & bottom  &$b$  & $-\frac{1}{3}$ \\ [170]
\hline [170]
\end{tabular} [170]
\caption{Fundamental fermions in the Standard Model. All of the fundamental [180]
fermions are spin-$\frac{1}{2}$ particles. The anti-fermion counterparts are not listed [191]
here.} [192]
\label{tab:fermions} [192]
\end{table} [192]
[192]
\subsection{Fundamental Forces} [2]
[2]
The fundamental forces of nature are mediated by the exchange of gauge bosons. [15]
They are all spin-1 particles which arise from [23]
consideration of the symmetries which the relevant theory possesses [32]
(See Section~\ref{sec:ewksymmetry}). [34]
The quantum field theories of electromagnetism, Quantum Electro-dynamics (QED), [43]
and the strong-nuclear force, Quantum Chromo-dynamics (QCD), [50]
yield massless mediator bosons, the photon [56]
and the gluons which are a direct consequence of the gauge invariance of those [70]
theories. Despite this, the typical ranges over which the two interactions occur [82]
are dramatically different; strong interaction effects are only apparent [91]
on a scale of around $10^{-15}$m whereas the range of electromagnetic interactions are effectively infinite. [107]
[107]
The mediators of the weak-nuclear and electromagnetic forces arise through [117]
the unification of the theories of weak and electromagnetic interactions and the mixing [130]
of the associated gauge fields. [135]
The weak gauge bosons, $W^{\pm}$ and $Z$, unlike the photon and gluons [147]
have a finite mass which has been measured experimentally~\citep{combinedWmass,pdg}. [156]
A summary of the fundamental gauge bosons of the Standard Model is given in [170]
Table~\ref{tab:bosons}. A quantum description of gravity is not included in the Standard Model. [183]
This is a reasonable approximation as the strength of this interaction [194]
is much smaller than the other three, thereby having no impact on the predictive power of the model. [212]
\begin{table}[htbp!] [212]
\begin{tabular}{|l|l c|c|c|} [212]
\hline [212]
& \textbf{Mediator Particle} & & \textbf{Charge} & \textbf{Mass (GeV)} \\ [212]
\hline [212]
Electromagnetism & photon & $\gamma$    & 0 & 0  \\ [212]
\hline [212]
Strong Nuclear  & gluon  & $g_{j},$ $j\in\left\{1,\cdots8\right\}$  & 0 & 0  \\ [212]
\hline [212]
Weak Nuclear  &  &  $W^{+}$ & +1 & 80.39 \\ [212]
&  &  $W^{-}$ & -1 & 80.39 \\ [212]
&  &  $Z$    & 0  & 91.19 \\ [212]
\hline [212]
\end{tabular} [212]
\caption{Fundamental gauge bosons in the Standard Model. [219]
All of the gauge-bosons are spin-1 particles. [226]
The masses of the $W^{\pm}$ and $Z$ bosons are taken from [237]
References~\citep{combinedWmass} and~\citep{pdg} respectively.} [240]
\label{tab:bosons} [240]
\end{table} [240]
[240]
\subsection{Electroweak Gauge Symmetry} [3]
\label{sec:ewksymmetry} [3]
[3]
Symmetries in nature are often found to relate to some underlying physical principle [16]
or fundamental law. It was first shown by Emmy Noether [26]
that for any physical system which can be described in the Lagrangian formalism, [39]
any symmetry of the Lagrangian has an associated conserved quantity~\cite{noether}. [49]
In the context of dynamical quantum theories, the particular characteristics of [60]
particle interactions can be used to construct the appropriate Lagrangian [70]
by means of identifying a particular group of transformations under which [81]
the Lagrangian should be symmetric (invariant). [87]
[87]
One of the major achievements of the twentieth century in [97]
the development of the Standard Model was the unification of the electromagnetic [109]
and weak interactions~\citep{glashow,weinberg,salam}. [112]
The original proposal, by Glashow in 1961, was [120]
to construct a theory which incorporates the characteristics of [129]
the weak and electromagnetic interactions by associating them [137]
with a particular symmetry group~\citep{glashow}. [142]
The physical nature of electroweak interactions is encoded into a Lagrangian which [154]
is invariant under transformations of the group $\sutwol\times\uone$. [162]
This group has three generators for $\sutwol$, $T_{i} = \frac{1}{2}\tau_{i}$ [170]
where $\tau_{i},~i\in \{1,2,3 \}$ are the $2\times2$ Pauli-spin matrices, and one [179]
additional generator for $\uone$, $Y$. [184]
The quantum numbers associated with the $\sutwol$ group, weak isospin $t_{1,2,3}$, and [196]
$\uone$ group, hypercharge $y$, are related to the electric charge $Q$ as, [208]
\begin{equation} [208]
Q = t_{3}+\frac{y}{2}, [209]
\end{equation} [209]
where the factor of $\frac{\displaystyle 1}{\displaystyle 2}$ is chosen by convention. [218]
The associated gauge fields are [223]
$\hat{\mathbf{W}}_{\mu} = \left(\hat{W}_{\mu}^{1},\hat{W}_{\mu}^{2},\hat{W}_{\mu}^{3}\right)$ [224]
and $\hat{B}_{\mu}$. [226]
An example Lagrangian for interactions within the first leptonic generation of fermions, $\lagr_{G}$, is [240]
given in Equation~\ref{eqn:ewklagrangianeg}. [243]
\begin{eqnarray} [243]
\lagr_{G} & =& \bar{\chi}_{L}\gamma^{\mu}\left[i\partial_{\mu} [244]
    - g\frac{1}{2}\boldsymbol{\tau}\cdot\hat{\mathbf{W}_{\mu}} [244]
    - g^{\prime}\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right)\hat{B}_{\mu}\right] \chi_{L} [244]
\nonumber \\ [244]
& &    + \bar{e}_{R}\gamma^{\mu}\left[i\partial_{\mu} [244]
    - g^{\prime}(-1)\hat{B}_{\mu}\right]{e}_{R} [244]
      -\frac{1}{4} [244]
      \hat{\mathbf{W}}_{\mu\nu}\cdot\hat{\mathbf{W}}^{\mu\nu} [244]
      -\frac{1}{4} [244]
      \hat{B}_{\mu\nu}\hat{B}^{\mu\nu} [244]
\label{eqn:ewklagrangianeg} [244]
\end{eqnarray} [244]
where the bar notation denotes the adjoint of the field, $\bar{\psi}=\psi^{\dagger}\gamma^{0}$. [255]
The field tensors, $\hat{\mathbf{W}}_{\mu\nu}$ and $\hat{B}_{\mu\nu}$ given in [263]
Equations~\ref{eqn:wmunu} and~\ref{eqn:bmunu}, [265]
describe the kinematics of the gauge fields. [272]
\begin{equation} [272]
\hat{\mathbf{W}}_{\mu\nu} = \partial_{\mu}\hat{\mathbf{W}}_{\nu} - \partial_{\nu}\hat{\mathbf{W}}_{\mu} - g \hat{\mathbf{W}}_{\mu}\wedge\hat{\mathbf{W}}_{\nu} [273]
\label{eqn:wmunu} [273]
\end{equation} [273]
\begin{equation} [273]
\hat{B}_{\mu\nu} = \partial_{\mu}\hat{B}_{\nu} - \partial_{\nu}\hat{B}_{\mu}. [274]
\label{eqn:bmunu} [274]
\end{equation} [274]
[274]
Experimentally, it has been verified that the weak nuclear force explicitly violates [286]
parity, that is transformations under spatial inversions $x\rightarrow -x$~\citep{wu}. [294]
A fermionic field, $\psi$, can be projected into its left and right handed components, [308]
$\psi_{L}$ and $\psi_{R}$, using the operators $\frac{1}{2}(1\mp\gamma^{5})$ respectively [316]
where $\gamma^{5} = \gamma^{0}\gamma^{1}\gamma^{2}\gamma^{3}$. [318]
As the weak nuclear force only interacts with left-handed fermions, [328]
right-handed components of the fermion fields remain invariant under $\sutwol$ transformations. [339]
The right-handed component of the neutrino field therefore does not appear [350]
in the Lagrangian, $\lagr_{G}$, since it interacts with neither the electromagnetic nor the weak interactions. [365]
Under the $\sutwol\times\uone$ group, [369]
the left handed components of the leptonic fermion fields, [378]
$\chi_{L}$ of Equation~\ref{eqn:ewklagrangianeg}, transform as a doublet [385]
\begin{equation} [385]
\chi_{L}  =  [386]
\everymath{\displaystyle} \begin{pmatrix} [386]
\nu_{e} \\ [386]
e [386]
\end{pmatrix}_{L} [386]
\longrightarrow [386]
\exp(-i\boldsymbol\alpha\cdot\frac{\boldsymbol\tau}{2} - i\alpha) [386]
\begin{pmatrix} [386]
\nu_{e} \\ [386]
e [386]
\end{pmatrix}_{L} [386]
\end{equation} [386]
\label{eqn:doublettrans} [386]
whereas the right-handed component of the electron field transforms as a singlet.  [398]
\begin{equation} [398]
e_{R} [399]
\longrightarrow [399]
\exp(-2i{\alpha}) [399]
e_{R}. [399]
\end{equation} [399]
The transformations are ``local'' in the sense that the coefficients  [409]
$\boldsymbol{\alpha}$ and $\alpha$ are functions of space-time. [416]
To maintain the symmetry under local transformations of this type, the gauge fields [429]
transform as follows, [432]
\begin{eqnarray} [432]
\hat{\mathbf{W}}_{\mu} & [433]
\longrightarrow & [433]
\hat{\mathbf{W}}_{\mu} - \frac{1}{g}\partial_{\mu}\boldsymbol{\alpha} [433]
- \boldsymbol{\alpha}\wedge\hat{\mathbf{W}}_{\mu} \\ [433]
\hat{{B}}_{\mu} & [433]
\longrightarrow & [433]
\hat{{B}}_{\mu} - \frac{1}{g^{\prime}}\partial_{\mu}{\alpha} [433]
\end{eqnarray} [433]
[433]
The Lagrangian of Equation~\ref{eqn:ewklagrangianeg} contains no explicit terms which [442]
relate to the mass of the electron ($m_{e}$). Including the electron's mass directly would [456]
require the addition of the term, [462]
\begin{eqnarray} [462]
-m_{e}\bar{e}e  &=& -m_{e}\bar{e}\left[\frac{1}{2}\left(1-\gamma^{5}\right) [463]
      + \frac{1}{2}\left(1+\gamma^{5}\right)\right]e \nonumber \\ [463]
  &=& -m_{e}\left(\bar{e}_{R}e_{L} + \bar{e}_{L}e_{R}\right). [463]
\end{eqnarray} [463]
As $e_{L}$ transforms as a member of a doublet and $e_{R}$ as a singlet, [477]
the addition of this term to Equation~\ref{eqn:ewklagrangianeg} [484]
would break the symmetry of the Lagrangian which motivated its construction, [495]
namely transformations under the $\sutwol$ group~\citep{aitchison}. [501]
[501]
The physical electroweak boson fields, $\hat{W}_{\mu}^{\pm}$, $\hat{Z}_{\mu}$ and photon field, [511]
$\hat{A}_{\mu}$, are obtained through a mixture of the electroweak gauge fields as, [523]
\begin{eqnarray} [523]
\hat{W}_{\mu}^{\pm} & = &  \sqrt{\frac{1}{2}} \left( \hat{W}_{\mu}^{1} \mp i \hat{W}_{\mu}^{2} \right) \nonumber \\ [524]
\hat{Z}_{\mu} &  = & \cos\theta_{w} \hat{W}_{\mu}^{3} - \sin\theta_{w} \hat{B}_{\mu} \nonumber \\ [524]
\hat{A}_{\mu} &  = & \sin\theta_{w} \hat{W}_{\mu}^{3} + \cos\theta_{w} \hat{B}_{\mu}, [524]
\label{eqn:ewkbosons} [524]
\end{eqnarray} [524]
where the mixing angle, $\theta_{w} = \tan^{-1}{\frac{g^{\prime}}{g}}$, relates [530]
the couplings of the weak neutral and electromagnetic interactions. [539]
As expected, there is no term which corresponds to the mass of the photon, however, [554]
the same is true for the $W$ and $Z$ bosons. The masses of the $W$ and $Z$ bosons, [572]
given in Table~\ref{tab:bosons}, have been measured experimentally and found to be [583]
non-zero. The inclusion of mass terms for these bosons in Equation~\ref{eqn:ewklagrangianeg} [594]
would also break the symmetry of the Lagrangian. Furthermore, it has been shown that the inclusion [610]
of these mass terms results in a loss of re-normalizability of the theory, making it  [625]
less effective at predicting observables such as cross-sections and decay rates~\citep{halzen}. [636]
Instead, these masses can be generated via a spontaneous, rather than explicit, [648]
breaking of the symmetry. [652]
[652]
\subsection{Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking: The Higgs Mechanism} [6]
[6]
In quantum field theory, a symmetry is ``spontaneously'' broken when the Lagrangian [18]
itself remains invariant while the vacuum state, for which the Hamiltonian of the theory [32]
attains its minimum, does not~\cite{aitchison}. In the context of the electroweak theory, [44]
spontaneous symmetry breaking is [48]
achieved through the introduction of a complex scalar field which attains a non-zero [61]
vacuum expectation value (VEV)~\citep{Higgs:1964ia,PhysRev.155.1554,Higgs:1964pj,Guralnik:1964eu,PhysRev.145.1156}. [65]
This field is an $SU(2)$ doublet, [71]
\begin{equation} [71]
\phi = [72]
\everymath{\displaystyle} \begin{pmatrix} [72]
\phi^{+} \\ [72]
\phi^{0} [72]
\end{pmatrix}. [72]
\end{equation} [72]
The Lagrangian, $\lagr_{G}$, of Equation~\ref{eqn:ewklagrangianeg} is modified to include [81]
an additional term which is $\sutwol\times\uone$ invariant, $\lagr_{\phi}$ [89]
given by, [91]
\begin{equation} [91]
\lagr_{\phi}=(\hat{D}_{\mu}\phi)^{\dagger}(\hat{D}^{\mu}\phi)  [92]
    +\mu^{2} \phi^{\dagger}\phi - \frac{\lambda}{4}(\phi^{\dagger}\phi)^{2}, [92]
\label{eqn:higgslagr} [92]
\end{equation} [92]
where the covariant derivative $\hat{D}^{\mu}$ which acts on $\phi$ is given by, [104]
\begin{equation} [104]
\hat{D}^{\mu} = \partial^{\mu} + ig\frac{1}{2}\boldsymbol{\tau}\cdot\hat{\mathbf{W}}^{\mu} [105]
  + ig^{\prime}\frac{1}{2} \hat{B}^{\mu}. [105]
\end{equation} [105]
The second two terms in Equation~\ref{eqn:higgslagr} correspond to the Higgs potential. [116]
In order to generate masses for the gauge bosons, the parameters, $\mu$ and $\lambda$, [130]
must satisfy $\mu^{2}<0$ and $\lambda>0$. The choice of non-zero [139]
VEV must then be made so that only the $W$ and $Z$ bosons acquire mass, while the [156]
symmetry associated with electromagnetism remains unbroken, leaving the photon massless. [166]
The choice suggested by Weinberg in 1967~\citep{weinberg} was, [174]
\begin{equation} [174]
\mathrm{VEV} = \langle0|\phi|0\rangle = [175]
\everymath{\displaystyle} \begin{pmatrix} [175]
0 \\ [175]
\frac{v}{\sqrt{2}} [175]
\end{pmatrix}, [175]
\end{equation} [175]
where $v= \frac{\displaystyle 2\mu}{\displaystyle \sqrt{\lambda}}$. In order to [180]
obtain the physical particle spectrum, perturbations around the vacuum state [190]
are considered. If $\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}$ and $\hat{H}$ represent small variations in [200]
the four degrees of freedom of the field $\phi$ then, [210]
\begin{equation} [210]
\phi = \exp(-i\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}\cdot\frac{1}{2v}\boldsymbol{\tau}) [211]
\everymath{\displaystyle} \begin{pmatrix} [211]
0 \\ [211]
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(v+\hat{H}) [211]
\end{pmatrix}. [211]
\end{equation} [211]
This can be simplified by choosing the phase fields $\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}$ [221]
to be zero. The Lagrangian obtained by inserting $\phi$ with this form [233]
into Equation~\ref{eqn:higgslagr} and adding it to the Lagrangian of [242]
Equation~\ref{eqn:ewklagrangianeg} is, [244]
[244]
\begin{eqnarray} [244]
\lagr_{\phi}+\lagr_{G} [245]
      & = &  \frac{1}{2} \partial_{\mu} \hat{H} \partial^{\mu} \hat{H} [245]
      - \mu^{2} \hat{H}^{2} [245]
      + \frac{1}{8} g^{2}v^{2}\hat{W}_{1\mu}\hat{W}_{1}^{\mu} [245]
      + \frac{1}{8} g^{2}v^{2}\hat{W}_{2\mu}\hat{W}_{2}^{\mu} [245]
\nonumber \\ [245]
    & & - \frac{v^{2}}{8} \left(g^{2}+{g^{\prime}}^{2}\right)\hat{Z}_{\mu}\hat{Z}^{\mu} [245]
      + KB , [245]
\label{eqn:lagrssb} [245]
\end{eqnarray} [245]
where only terms which are at most second order in the fields are kept, illustrating the physical [262]
particle spectrum, and the [266]
fermion fields are dropped altogether. [271]
The relation between the $\hat{W}^{\mu}_{3}$ [276]
and $\hat{B}^{\mu}$ fields from Equation~\ref{eqn:ewkbosons} has been used to obtain [286]
the physical photon, $\hat{A}^{\mu}$, and $\hat{Z}^{\mu}$ [292]
fields. [293]
From this form of the Lagrangian, it is clear that the $\hat{W}_{1}^{\mu}$,  [305]
$\hat{W}^{\mu}_{2}$ and $\hat{Z}$ fields acquire mass. As the $\hat{W}_{1}^{\mu}$ and [315]
$\hat{W}^{\mu}_{2}$ fields mix to form the physical $\hat{W}^{\pm}$ fields, [324]
the $W^{\pm}$ bosons acquire a mass of $m_{W} = \frac{\displaystyle gv}{\displaystyle 2}$. [332]
The mass of the $Z$ boson is given by [341]
$m_{Z}=\frac{\displaystyle 1}{\displaystyle 2}\sqrt{g^{2}+{g^{\prime}}^{2}}$, [342]
while there is no term associated with the mass of the photon. [354]
An additional scalar field, $\hat{H}$ (the Higgs boson), [362]
remains in the Lagrangian with mass $\sqrt{2}\mu$. [369]
The term $KB$ in Equation~\ref{eqn:lagrssb} denotes additional kinetic terms for the $\hat{W}^{\mu}_{1}$, [381]
$\hat{W}^{\mu}_{2}$, $\hat{Z}^{\mu}$ and $\hat{A^{\mu}}$ fields. [386]
The masses of the fermions are generated by adding Yukawa coupling [397]
terms, [398]
\begin{equation} [398]
-\lambda_{f} \bar{\chi}_{L} \phi \psi_{R} + \lambda_{f^{\prime}}\bar{\psi}_{R}(-i\tau_{2}\phi^{*})\chi_{L}, [399]
\end{equation} [399]
to $\lagr_{\phi}$. [401]
The couplings $\lambda_{f}$, $f=u,d,e,\mu\cdots$,  are directly related [408]
to the mass of the fermions, specifically [415]
$\lambda_{f}\propto m_{f}$ such that the heavier fermions have stronger [423]
coupling to the Higgs boson. Although the SM does not predict the values of these [438]
couplings, the masses of the fermions are experimentally measurable allowing [448]
access to, and providing constraints on, the properties of the Higgs boson. [460]
[460]

\section{The SM Higgs Boson} [4]
\label{sec:smhiggs} [4]
[4]
The introduction of a complex scalar field into the Standard Model [15]
to generate masses for the SM particles results in the prediction [26]
of a new massive scalar boson, [32]
the Higgs boson~\citep{Higgs:1964ia,PhysRev.155.1554,Higgs:1964pj,Guralnik:1964eu,PhysRev.145.1156}. [35]
The discovery of such a particle would give strong evidence as to the [48]
nature of electroweak symmetry breaking and hence many searches for it have been [61]
launched since its existence was first proposed. [68]
[68]
The mass of the SM Higgs boson, $\mh$, is not a predicted quantity in the SM [84]
but is rather a function of the self-coupling parameter, $\lambda$, and [95]
$v$. The latter is determined experimentally to be $v=246$ GeV by precisely [107]
measuring the rate of muon decay~\citep{muondecay}. [113]
However, since $\lambda$ is unconstrained, a large range in $\mh$ remains [124]
theoretically acceptable for the Higgs boson mass. [131]
[131]
\subsection{Constraints and Previous Searches} [4]
[4]
Several theoretical considerations constrain the mass of the SM Higgs [14]
boson~\citep{ellisHiggsReview}. [15]
The desire to avoid the need for non-pertubative calculations for electroweak [26]
processes at high energies constrains the SM [33]
Higgs boson mass to be less than around 770 GeV~\citep{higgstriviality}. [43]
Conversely, if $\mh$ is too small, [49]
then the Higgs potential of Equation~\ref{eqn:higgslagr} contains a  [57]
global minima at large values of the scalar field $\phi$. Additional [68]
physics, beyond that of the SM, would be required so that this global minimum [82]
corresponds to the observed vacuum with $v=246$ GeV. [90]
This places a loose lower bound on the SM Higgs boson mass of about 115 [105]
GeV~\cite{higgsreview2012}. [106]
[106]
\subsubsection{Direct Searches} [108]
% LEP SENTENCE [108]
The first direct constraints on the Higgs boson at higher masses [119]
were provided by the four experiments operating at the [128]
Large Electron-Positron (LEP) collider. By steadily increasing the centre of mass [139]
energy of the collisions, LEP was able to exclude masses of $m_{H} <114.4$ GeV at the [154]
95\% confidence level~\cite{lephiggs}. Prior to the LHC turn on, [163]
the CDF and D0 experiments at the Tevatron collider [172]
provided additional limits on the mass of the Higgs boson through direct [184]
searches in proton anti-proton collisions. [189]
The centre of mass energy available in these collisions, $\sqrt{s}=1.96$ TeV, [200]
provided sensitivity to Higgs boson masses between 90 GeV and 190. [211]
Priority at the Tevatron experiments was given to the $\Hww$ channel at high mass [225]
and $\Hbb$, with associated production of a $W$ or $Z$ boson, at low mass. [239]
By the shutdown of the Tevatron in 2011, the two experiments had collected combined [253]
datasets corresponding to a total integrated luminosity of $10fb^{-1}$. [262]
Figure~\ref{fig:tevatronlims} shows the 95\% confidence upper limits on the [271]
ratio of the excluded Higgs boson production cross-section to that predicted [282]
by the Standard Model as a function of $\mh$ obtained from this dataset. [295]
Mass hypothesis in the ranges $100\le\mh\le119 $ GeV and $141 \le \mh \le 184$ GeV [305]
are excluded at the 95\% confidence level~\citep{tevhiggscombinations}. [312]
\begin{figure} [312]
\begin{center} [312]
\includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{theory/pheno/tevsmbayes_june2012_withleplhc.pdf} [312]
\caption{The 95\% confidence upper limits on the ratio of Higgs boson production to the SM prediction [328]
as a function of $\mh$. [333]
The dotted line indicates the median expected exclusion assuming no [343]
SM Higgs boson exists while the solid line indicates the observed exclusion obtained [356]
from the data. Where this line falls below 1, a SM Higgs boson with that mass is excluded at the [376]
95\% confidence level as indicated by the green bands. The other coloured bands indicate [390]
exclusion limits resulting from direct searches for the SM Higgs boson conducted by other [404]
Collaborations before June 2012. The figure has been altered from its original [416]
source~\cite{tevhiggscombinations}.} [417]
\label{fig:tevatronlims} [417]
\end{center} [417]
\end{figure} [417]
[417]
\subsubsection{Precision Measurements} [419]
Collision data taken at the Tevatron are combined with precision measurements [430]
of electroweak observables performed at LEP [436]
and by the SLD Collaboration based at SLAC to constrain the mass of the [450]
Higgs boson. Figure~\ref{fig:blueband} shows the relative chi-square from a fit [460]
to these data as a function of $\mh$. The minimum of the curve is at 94 GeV [477]
with an experimental uncertainty of +29 and -24 GeV. The theoretical uncertainty [489]
is indicated by the blue band. The yellow bands indicate the excluded regions in [503]
$\mh$ provided by direct searches for the SM Higgs boson conducted at LEP [516]
and the LHC by March 2012. [522]
\begin{figure} [522]
\begin{center} [522]
\includegraphics[width=0.6\textwidth]{theory/pheno/w12_blueband.jpg} [522]
\caption{Delta chi-squared from global fit to combined data from CDF, D0, SLD and the LEP [537]
Collaborations as a function of $\mh$~\cite{lepewwgpage}. [543]
The solid line is the nominal fit with theoretical [552]
uncertainties indicated in blue while the dashed lines indicate alternative theoretical [563]
prescriptions. The yellow bands indicate the regions excluded at the 95\% confidence level [576]
from direct searches for the SM Higgs boson conducted at LEP and the LHC before March 2012.} [593]
\label{fig:blueband} [593]
\end{center} [593]
\end{figure} [593]
[593]
\subsection{Higgs Boson Production and Decay at the LHC} [8]
[8]
At the LHC, protons are accelerated to higher energies than previously available at the [22]
Tevatron. The increased centre-of-mass energy enhances the [29]
rate at which Higgs boson production occurs and improves the sensitivity to higher [42]
masses. The four main mechanisms by which a Higgs boson can be produced [55]
are shown at leading order in Figure~\ref{fig:higgsprodfeyn}. [62]
\begin{figure}[hbtp!] [62]
\begin{center} [62]
%\includegraphics[width=.49\textwidth]{theory/pheno/ggh.pdf} [62]
%\includegraphics[width=.49\textwidth]{theory/pheno/vh.pdf}\\ [62]
%\includegraphics[width=.49\textwidth]{theory/pheno/qqh.pdf} [62]
%\includegraphics[width=.4\textwidth]{theory/pheno/tth.pdf} [62]
\includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{theory/pheno/allprods_new.pdf} [62]
\caption{Dominant SM Higgs boson production mechanisms: Gluon-gluon fusion (top left), [72]
vector-boson fusion (bottom left), associated production with vector boson (top right) [83]
and top anti-top quark pair (bottom right).} [90]
\label{fig:higgsprodfeyn} [90]
\end{center} [90]
\end{figure} [90]
The dominant production mechanism is through gluon-gluon fusion ($ggH$). As the gluons [102]
are massless particles, the gluons couple to the Higgs boson via a quark-loop. [115]
The three other production mechanisms which dominate Higgs boson production are [126]
vector boson fusion ($qqH$) and production in association with [135]
a $W$ or $Z$ boson ($VH$) or top anti-top quark pair ($ttH$). [147]
Although these modes are at least an order of magnitude smaller in cross-section [160]
than gluon-gluon fusion, their specific topologies [166]
can be exploited experimentally to enhance the signal over background processes [177]
(see Chapter~\ref{chap:combinations}). [179]
Figure~\ref{fig:higgsprod} shows the production cross-sections and their theoretical [187]
errors for the four main production modes of the SM Higgs boson in  [200]
p-p collisions at the LHC~\citep{lhcxswg2011,lhcxswg2012}. [205]
\begin{figure}[hbtp!] [205]
\begin{center} [205]
\includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{theory/pheno/Higgs_XS_7TeV.pdf}\\ [205]
\includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{theory/pheno/Higgs_XS_8TeV_lx.pdf} [205]
\caption{SM Higgs boson production cross-sections at $\sqrt{s}=7~\mathrm{TeV}$ (top) [213]
and 8 TeV (bottom) of the four main production mechanisms, $pp\rightarrow H+X$, [224]
along with their theoretical uncertainties as a function of [233]
$\mh$~\citep{lhcxswg2011,lhcxswg2012}. The coloured bands indicate the theoretical [240]
uncertainties.} [241]
\label{fig:higgsprod} [241]
\end{center} [241]
\end{figure} [241]
The Higgs boson is an unstable particle so will be observable directly at the LHC [256]
only through its decay products. The relative decay rates (branching ratios) to [268]
different SM particles vary as a function of the Higgs boson mass. [280]
At low mass, $\mh<135$ GeV, Higgs boson decay to a $b$ anti-$b$ quark pair [295]
dominates. In proton-proton collisions, pairs of $b$-quarks are produced [305]
frequently making the background levels too high to compete with for an experimental [318]
search. For higher masses, $\mh>180$ GeV, the Higgs boson is heavy enough [330]
to facilitate production of real $W$ and $Z$ bosons which dominate its decay. [343]
As the gluon and photon are massless, they do not directly couple to the Higgs boson [359]
hence these decays are mediated by virtual loops of massive particles. [370]
The branching ratios of the Higgs boson to SM particles are shown as a function [385]
of $\mh$ in Figure~\ref{fig:higgsdecay} (left). [390]
[390]
For small $\mh$, the natural width of the SM Higgs boson, $\hwidth$, is several [404]
orders of magnitude smaller than its mass. Figure~\ref{fig:higgsdecay} (right) shows the [415]
value of the SM Higgs boson total width as a function of its mass. [429]
This means that for decays in which the products are fully reconstructible in particle [443]
detectors, the width of the invariant mass spectrum of the decay products will depend almost entirely [459]
on the experimental resolution. [463]
In particular the ATLAS and CMS detectors provide excellent energy and momentum resolution [476]
for electrons, muons and photons. [481]
Despite having lower branching ratios,  the $\Hgg$ and $\Hzzl$ channels [491]
are therefore of particular importance for direct detection of the SM Higgs boson [504]
at the LHC. [507]
[507]
[507]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [507]
\begin{center} [507]
\includegraphics[width=0.49\textwidth]{theory/pheno/YRHXS_BR_fig3.pdf} [507]
\includegraphics[width=0.49\textwidth]{theory/pheno/YRHXS_BR_fig2.pdf} [507]
\caption{Left: SM Higgs boson production branching ratios for [515]
the dominant decays as a function of $\mh$. Right: SM Higgs boson total width, $\hwidth$, as [531]
a function of $\mh$~\citep{lhcxswg2011}.} [535]
\label{fig:higgsdecay} [535]
\end{center} [535]
\end{figure} [535]
[535]

File: ./detector/detector.tex

\chapter{The LHC and the CMS Detector} [6]
\label{chap:detector} [6]
[6]
One of the many physics goals of the LHC is the establishment of the mechanism by which [23]
the fundamental fermions and bosons acquire mass in the SM. The discovery of the new particle [39]
announced by the ATLAS and CMS Collaborations in July 2012, if found to be the Higgs boson, will have provided [59]
a major step towards this goal. This of course could not have been achieved without the use [76]
of the particle detectors designed by those Collaborations. This Chapter is intended to serve as an [92]
introduction to the CMS detector, being the experiment the author worked at. Section~\ref{sec:cmsdetector} [105]
provides an overview of the components of the CMS detector, paying attention in particular to those [121]
which are the most relevant for the search for the Higgs boson in the two photon decay mode. [139]
Section~\ref{sec:l1trigger} will cover work performed by the author, as service to the CMS Collaboration, [153]
on improving the jet resolution in the GCT component of the L1 trigger. A set of calibrations (derived by [172]
the author) to be used online during CMS data-taking are described. [183]
[183]
\section{The LHC} [2]
The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN is the only collider experiment, currently in operation, [17]
designed to study physics at the TeV scale. The collider is an octagonal [30]
ring, 27 km in circumference, hosted in the former LEP tunnel in France/Switzerland.  [44]
Both proton-proton (pp) and heavy ion (PbPb) collisions are [53]
studied as part of the LHC physics programme with the former used [65]
for direct searches for new physics. Proton beams are formed inside the proton synchrotron [79]
from bunches of protons 50 ns apart with an energy of 26 GeV. The protons are then accelerated in the [99]
super proton synchrotron to 450 GeV before being injected into the LHC. [111]
Around 1200 superconducting dipole magnets maintain two beams of protons accelerating around [123]
the ring in opposite directions before being collided at one of the sites of the four major experiments; [141]
ALICE~\citep{aliceexperiment}, ATLAS~\citep{atlasexperiment}, CMS~\citep{cmsexperiment} [144]
and LHCb~\citep{lhcbexperiment}. Figure~\ref{fig:lhcring} is a cartoon of the accelerator [153]
indicating the sites of the four experiments. [160]
[160]
\begin{figure}[htb!] [160]
\begin{center} [160]
\includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{detector/CERN.jpg} [160]
\caption{LHC accelerator ring. The relative locations of the four main experiments [171]
are indicated along with their points of access to the beam.} [182]
\label{fig:lhcring} [182]
\end{center} [182]
\end{figure} [182]
[182]
The first major physics run began in May 2010 with a centre of mass energy [197]
$\sqrt{s}=7$ TeV and continued until November providing a dataset of $44pb^{-1}$. [208]
The LHC resumed collisions in April 2011 delivering a further $6fb^{-1}$ by the end [222]
of October. The centre of mass energy was increased to $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV for the 2012 pp [238]
collision run, improving the sensitivity of searches for new physics. A total of [251]
$6fb^{-1}$ of 8 TeV data were taken by July 2012 which were combined with earlier data resulting [268]
in the discovery of the new boson reported by ATLAS and CMS Collaborations at the ICHEP conference that year. [287]
[287]
\section{The CMS Detector} [3]
\label{sec:cmsdetector} [3]
The Compact Muon Solenoid (CMS) detector is one of two general purpose detectors at [17]
the LHC designed to search for new physics. [25]
Among the wide range of physics programs at CMS, the search for the SM Higgs boson [41]
has a high priority. The decay rates of the SM Higgs boson in different [55]
channels vary dramatically as a function of its mass ($\mh$). A key feature of the experiment's design [72]
was, therefore, the necessity to maintain a high sensitivity to the SM Higgs for a wide range of masses in as many [94]
decay channels as possible. To achieve this, several detector components are layered around [107]
the beam axis to reconstruct many types of particle produced at the interaction point. [121]
Each component consists of a cylindrical barrel section and two endcaps [132]
to provide an almost hermetic coverage of the outgoing particle flux. [143]
[143]
[143]
The tracker, providing measurements of the momentum of charged particles and the location of [157]
primary and secondary vertices (from decays of heavy flavour mesons), is the first layer of detection. [173]
This is followed by the electromagnetic calorimeter which is used to measure [185]
energy deposited in electromagnetic showers from particles such as electrons and photons. [197]
The hadronic calorimeter (HCAL) complements this by providing energy measurements of [208]
sprays of hadrons, known as jets, which deposit energy through nuclear interactions. [220]
The HCAL is a sampling calorimeter in that the active material (plastic scintillators) [233]
are sandwiched between dense absorbing material to increase the depth of the calorimeter to [247]
around 11 radiation lengths. The addition of the forward calorimeter (HF) extends the HCAL [261]
coverage in the forward regions.  [266]
The tracker and calorimeters are situated within a 4T axial magnetic field [278]
provided by the superconducting magnet surrounding them. [285]
The magnetic flux return is implemented within the  muon detector systems which lie outside [299]
the superconducting coil and form the outermost detection layers. Muons deposit very little energy [313]
throughout the detector and can carry on into the surrounding cavern. [324]
The barrel muon system is constructed from layers of drift-tubes (DT) interleaved with [337]
resistive plate chambers. The combination of the two provides high resolution [348]
timing and hit positions which are used to determine the trajectory of muons both from [363]
p-p collisions and cosmic sources for calibration. For the endcaps, the DTs are replaced [377]
with cathode strip chambers as the higher flux of particles along the beam line [391]
requires the use of radiation hard components. [398]
% ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ [398]
[398]
CMS uses a right-handed Cartesian coordinate system with the origin at the [410]
interaction point and the $z$-axis pointing along the beam axis. The $x$-axis points towards [426]
the centre of the LHC ring and the $y$-axis points vertically upwards. The azimuthal angle, [442]
$\phi~\epsilon~[-\pi,\pi]$, is defined with respect to the $x$-axis in the [453]
transverse ($x-y$) plane. The polar angle $\theta$ is measured from the $z$-axis. Commonly, [467]
the direction of an outgoing particle is defined by $\phi$ and its pseudo-rapidity $\eta$ [481]
defined as [483]
\begin{equation} [483]
\eta=-\log \tan \left( \frac{\theta}{2} \right). [484]
\end{equation} [484]
As hard collisions produce high momentum particles travelling perpendicular to the beam line, [497]
particles are often characterised [501]
by the magnitude of the projection of their momenta onto the transverse plane, [514]
$\pt=\sqrt{p_{x}^{2}+p_{y}^{2}}$. [515]
Similarly, the transverse energy is defined as $E_{T}=E\sin\theta$. [523]
Figure~\ref{fig:cms} shows the geometry of the CMS detector and its major components. [535]
[535]
\begin{figure} [535]
\centering [535]
\includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{detector/cmsdetector} [535]
\caption{Diagram of the CMS Detector. The arrows indicate the main detector elements. [547]
The figure has been altered from its original source~\citep{cmspub}.} [556]
\label{fig:cms} [556]
\end{figure} [556]
[556]
\subsection{Tracker} [1]
The CMS tracker is designed to reconstruct charged particle tracks [11]
which are ubiquitous in high energy [17]
p-p collisions. The tracker provides precise measurements of [25]
observables such as the momentum of charged particles and the location of the [38]
vertex at which they are produced. [44]
In addition to the high level of granularity required to make such measurements, the [58]
high rate of interaction at LHC requires a fast response from the tracking [71]
elements. [72]
The tracker is formed of a pixel detector component encased by layers of silicon strip detectors. [88]
The pixel detector is the closest tracking element to the interaction point. [100]
It is a composite of 66 million individual silicon pixels, $100\mathrm{\mu m} \times 150 \mathrm{\mu m}$ in size, [113]
forming three cylindrical layers around the beam line and two forward disks. [125]
The resolution of the pixel detector is around 10 $\mathrm{\mu}$m in the $\hat{r}$ and $\hat{\phi}$ [141]
direction and 17 $\mathrm{\mu}$m in $\hat{z}$~\citep{trckAC}. [148]
Outside the pixel detector, ten cylindrical layers of silicon strip detectors (TIB/TOB) [161]
and twelve discs (TID/TEC) extend the tracking system out to a radius of 120cm from the [178]
beam line. The tracker geometry, as shown in Figure~\ref{fig:trackergeom}, covers a pseudo-rapidity [190]
range $|\eta| < 2.5$. [192]
[192]
\begin{figure} [192]
\centering [192]
\includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{detector/trcker/trcker.pdf} [192]
\caption{Cross-section of the pixel and silicon strip detector [200]
components of the CMS tracker~\citep{Weber201159}.} [205]
  \label{fig:trackergeom} [205]
\end{figure} [205]
[205]
By making multiple precise measurements throughout the tracker system, the trajectories (tracks) of charged [219]
particles can be reconstructed. [223]
Tracks are associated to a common point of origin (primary vertex) by grouping those which are separated [240]
by less than 1cm in the $z$ coordinate of the point of closest approach to the beam line. [258]
The vertex resolution is dependant both on the number of tracks associated to the vertex and [274]
their average transverse momenta ($\bar{p}_{T}$). The resolution was measured in early data from 2010 [288]
by splitting tracks associated to a vertex randomly into two groups with equal kinematic distributions. [303]
The difference between the vertex locations calculated from the two groups was used to provide an estimate [320]
of the resolution~\citep{TRK-10-005}. [323]
Figure~\ref{fig:vtxreso} shows the resolution in $z$ as a function of the track multiplicity [336]
measured in data and simulation. The simulation provides a good description of both the trend with [352]
number of associated tracks and the improvement in resolution with $\bar{p_{T}}$ in the data. [366]
[366]
\begin{figure} [366]
\begin{center} [366]
\includegraphics[width=.6\textwidth]{detector/trcker/zresotrcker.pdf} [366]
\caption{Resolution of vertex $z$-position as a function of the number [377]
of tracks associated to the vertex measured in simulation and [387]
2010 data~\citep{TRK-10-005}. [389]
  The resolution is given for three different average track momenta.} [399]
\label{fig:vtxreso} [399]
\end{center} [399]
\end{figure} [399]
[399]
\subsection{Electromagnetic Calorimeter} [2]
The electromagnetic calorimeter (ECAL) is used to reconstruct energy deposits in electromagnetic showers [15]
from particles such as electrons and photons. [22]
It is constructed from high density lead tungstate (PbWO$_{4}$) crystals which [34]
form a barrel section (EB) and two endcaps (EE) outside the tracker. [46]
Two lead plates in front of a fine grained silicon strip detector are situated just before the [63]
endcaps forming the ECAL pre-shower (PS). [69]
Photons travelling at high $\eta$ will convert in the lead and the resulting electron-positron pair [84]
will produce tracks which can be used to pinpoint the position of the incoming photon. The additional [101]
information obtained using the two layers can be used to distinguish prompt photons from those produced [117]
in neutral pion decays. [121]
[121]
The ECAL is designed to cover a pseudo-rapidity range of $|\eta | < 3$. [132]
The crystals are arranged to form modules which surround the beam line in a non-projective geometry: [148]
the gaps between crystal modules are offset by 3$^{\circ}$, beyond the interaction point, with respect to [165]
the trajectories of particles which produced at the centre of the interaction point. [178]
Electrons and photons deposit most of their energy within [187]
the crystals as the depth of the crystals is equivalent to 25.8 radiation lengths~\citep{TDR1}. [201]
Electromagnetic showers produced by the interaction of electrons and photons in the ECAL crystals [215]
produce scintillation light which is collected to measure the energy of the particle. [228]
The scintillation output of the crystals is, however, low and temperature dependant [240]
($\sim$ 2.1\%/K at the ECAL operating temperature of 291 K). [251]
Avalanche photo-diodes (APDs) and vacuum [256]
photo-triodes (VPTs) are used to collect the scintillation light and amplify the signal in the [271]
calorimeter barrel and endcaps respectively. [276]
These technologies are chosen to withstand the high magnetic field inside CMS. [288]
For the endcaps, VPTs are used as they are less sensitive to the high radiation conditions  [304]
in the forward regions. Around 4.5 photo-electrons per MeV are produced in both APDs and VPTs. [320]
[320]
The energy resolution of the ECAL can be parametrised as the combination of three [334]
uncorrelated sources as given in equation~\ref{eqn:resofit}. [340]
The parameters $a$, $b$ and $c$ are the stochastic, noise and constant contributions respectively. [354]
These constants have been derived from test-beam data~\citep{AN-06-140}. [362]
The stochastic term ($a=2.83\pm0.3\%$) is very low for lead tungstate since the shower [375]
can be mostly contained within the crystals. [382]
As the noise term ($b=$124 MeV) is determined by the electronics, [394]
it is mostly the constant term ($c=0.26\pm0.04\%$) which will limit the ECAL accuracy at [408]
high energies. Maintaining a high resolution [414]
over the long term running of the LHC will allow for reconstruction of high energy photons, [430]
such as those produced by $H \rightarrow \gamma\gamma$ decays. [437]
\begin{eqnarray} [437]
\left( \frac{\displaystyle \sigma_{E}}{\displaystyle E} \right)^ 2 [438]
& = & \left( \frac{\displaystyle a}{\displaystyle \sqrt{E}} \right)^ 2 [438]
  + \left( \frac{\displaystyle b}{\displaystyle {E}} \right)^ 2 + c^ 2 [438]
\label{eqn:resofit} [438]
\end{eqnarray} [438]
[438]
[438]
\subsubsection{Electron and Photon Reconstruction} [442]
[442]
Electron and photon candidates are formed by clustering deposits of [452]
energy caused by electromagnetic showers in the ECAL. For unconverted [462]
photons, these clusters will likely be well localised in $\eta$ and $\phi$ [474]
around the incident photon. However, for photons which convert in the material in front of the [490]
calorimeter, the resulting electron-positron pair will deposit energy across several regions [501]
of the calorimeter. In the presence of the axial magnetic field, [512]
electrons radiate bremsstrahlung photons causing deposits which are [520]
spread over a wide range in $\phi$ while being fairly narrow in $\eta$. [533]
This characteristic is exploited by the ``Hybrid'' clustering algorithm [542]
used to reconstruct high energy electrons and photons in [551]
the ECAL barrel~\citep{cseez}. [554]
The values of the particular thresholds used for seeding clusters were tuned providing [567]
an efficiency for electrons with $p_{T}>7$ GeV greater than 99\%~\citep{dfutyan}. [577]
Figure~\ref{fig:hybridclustering} is an illustration of the Hybrid clustering algorithm. [586]
The algorithm proceeds as follows; [591]
\begin{itemize} [591]
\item Step 1: A seed crystal is determined to be a single crystal in the barrel with the highest [609]
$E_{T}$ satisfying $E_{T}>1$ GeV. [613]
\item Step 2: $1\times3$ ($\phi\times\eta$) crystal dominoes are formed with their central crystal [625]
aligned with the seed crystal in $\eta$. If the energy contained in the $1\times3$ domino is [641]
larger than 1 GeV, the domino is extended by two crystals in $\eta$. A maximum of 10 dominoes are [660]
added in each direction in $\phi$ starting from the seed crystal forming a sub-cluster. [674]
\item Step 3: Dominoes containing less than 100 MeV are removed and the remaining dominoes are [689]
grouped into sub-clusters providing each seeding domino for a sub-cluster contains more than 350 MeV. [704]
The final group of sub-clusters form a supercluster for the electromagnetic object. [716]
\end{itemize} [716]
[716]
\begin{figure} [716]
\begin{center} [716]
\includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{detector/ecal/clustering.png} [716]
\caption{Sub-cluster construction of the Hybrid algorithm used to reconstruct photons and [727]
electrons in the ECAL barrel.} [732]
\label{fig:hybridclustering} [732]
\end{center} [732]
\end{figure} [732]
[732]
In the ECAL endcaps, superclusters are built using the ``Multi5$\times$5'' algorithm which [746]
connects overlapping 5$\times$5 grids of crystals whose positions lie within [758]
0.3 radians in $\phi$~\citep{AN-09-164}. [762]
Additional information is used from the PS to enhance the energy reconstruction in the endcaps. [777]
[777]
Superclusters are associated to electron candidates [783]
where a track can be reconstructed from [790]
compatible hits in the tracker using a Gaussian sum filter algorithm~\citep{GSF_Electron_Reconstruction_CMS}.  [801]
This provides an additional measure of the electron's momentum which is used [813]
to improve the resolution of the electron energy. [821]
Aside from this, the reconstruction of photons and electrons is identical which is an [835]
important feature allowing for data driven calibrations and validations of photons using [847]
electrons such as those described in Chapter~\ref{chap:hgg}. [854]
[854]
[854]
\subsubsection{Laser Calibration} [856]
[856]
ECAL crystals suffer from loss of optical transmission when irradiated through [867]
the formation of crystal-lattice defects which absorb some of the scintillation light. Annealing [880]
acts to balance the damage from radiation which results in an equilibrium optical [893]
transmission which is dose-dependant~\citep{TDR1}. [897]
At the LHC, the dose varies during each run. This requires that the time varying optical transmission of the ECAL [917]
crystals be monitored to asses the impact on energy measurements. [927]
The crystal transparency is monitored by comparing the relative transmission in blue laser light (440 nm), [943]
which is close to the scintillation emission peak, to infra-red (796 nm), which is far from the [960]
peak and relatively unaffected by the radiation damage. [968]
Figure~\ref{fig:trans} shows the relative response to the blue laser of the monitoring system [981]
averaged over all the crystals in bins of $|\eta|$ throughout the 2011 data taking [995]
runs~\citep{CMS-DP-2012-007}. [996]
The time dependence of the response is stronger at higher values of $|\eta|$ due to the larger flux [1014]
of particles along the beam axis. [1020]
[1020]
\begin{figure} [1020]
\centering [1020]
\includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{detector/ecal/laser.pdf} [1020]
\caption{Relative ECAL crystal response to blue laser light (440 nm) in bins of pseudo-rapidity, [1034]
for the 2011 data taking period. The grey bands indicate periods during which there was no beam.} [1051]
\label{fig:trans} [1051]
\end{figure} [1051]
[1051]
The response of the crystals measured using the laser monitoring system is used to calibrate [1066]
the energy reconstruction of the ECAL. These calibrations are validated in $W\rightarrow e\nu$ data events [1080]
by comparing the electron energy ($E$) as measured by the ECAL to the momentum [1094]
($p$) of the electron measured in the tracker~\citep{CMS-DP-2012-007}. [1102]
Figure~\ref{fig:scaleeop} shows the relative variation in the ratio $E/p$ as a function of time [1116]
throughout 2011. A stable scale is achieved through application of the laser calibrations. [1129]
[1129]
\begin{figure} [1129]
\centering [1129]
\includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{detector/ecal/scaleeop.pdf} [1129]
\caption{Ratio $E/p$ in electrons reconstructed in the ECAL Barrel [1138]
from $W\rightarrow e\nu$ events in 2011 data as a function of time before [1150]
and after applying transparency corrections from the laser monitoring (LM) system. [1161]
The blue line indicates the correction applied per point averaged over all crystals used in the electron [1178]
energy measurement.} [1180]
\label{fig:scaleeop} [1180]
\end{figure} [1180]
[1180]
\subsection{Shower-shape and Isolation} [3]
In addition to providing a measurement of the energy of incoming electromagnetic particles, [16]
the ECAL's fine granularity provides additional information which can be used to characterise [29]
the supercluster and distinguish prompt electrons and photons from fakes.  [39]
The shape of the electromagnetic shower can be described by the ratio of the energy contained [55]
in the central $3\times3$ cluster surrounding the seed crystal to the total energy of the supercluster [71]
($\rnine$). Superclusters associated with real unconverted photons will typically have larger value of [84]
$\rnine$ than those which are in reality due to narrow $\pi^{0}$ decays. Another common variable used [100]
for identification is the energy weighted crystal width of the sub-cluster used to seed the supercluster  [116]
$\sigieie$, [117]
\begin{equation} [117]
\sigieie = \frac{\sum_{i}w_{i}(\eta_{i}-\eta_{sc})^{2}\Delta\eta^{2}_{xtal}}{\sum_{i}w_{i}}, [118]
\end{equation} [118]
where $\eta_{sc}$ is the pseudo-rapidity of the seed crystal, $\Delta\eta_{xtal}$ is the crystal width [132]
and $w_{i}$ is the crystals weight determined as $w_{i} = \mathrm{max}\left\{0,4.7+\log(E_{i}/E_{tot})\right\}$. [141]
Prompt photons will tend to have a more localised cluster leading to lower values of $\sigieie$. [157]
The distributions of $\rnine$ and $\sigieie$ are shown for a simulated sample of [170]
superclusters identified as photons from real and fake sources in Figure~\ref{fig:showershape}. [181]
The two distinct peaks in the $\sigieie$ distribution are due to the different superclustering algorithms [196]
used in the barrel and endcaps. [202]
[202]
\begin{figure}[hbt!] [202]
\begin{center} [202]
\includegraphics[width=0.49\textwidth]{detector/r9eg.pdf} [202]
\includegraphics[width=0.49\textwidth]{detector/sieieeg.pdf} [202]
\caption{Shower shape variable $\rnine$ (left) and $\sigieie$ (right) distributions [211]
for superclusters associated with simulated real and fake photons. The real photon is taken [225]
from simulated $\Hgg$ events while the fake photon is taken from a $\gamma+jet$ sample [239]
where the photon candidate is matched to a generated quark leg. In the right hand plot, [255]
two distributions can be distinguished. The narrower is from photons in the barrel and [269]
the wider from photons in the endcaps. } [276]
\label{fig:showershape} [276]
\end{center} [276]
\end{figure} [276]
[276]
Hard interaction processes tend to produce electromagnetic particles which are well [287]
isolated in the detector. A cone is defined around the candidate with radius $\Delta R$ defined as, [303]
\begin{equation} [303]
\Delta R = \sqrt{(\Delta\phi)^{2}+(\Delta\eta)^{2}} [304]
\end{equation} [304]
where $\Delta\phi$ and $\Delta\eta$ are defined as the $\phi$ and $\eta$ co-ordinates relative to the [319]
weighted centre of the supercluster. [324]
[324]
The sum of $E_{T}$ for each crystal inside the cone, after removing those associated [338]
to the supercluster itself, quantifies the isolation of the electron or photon candidate. [351]
Similar isolation variables are defined for the HCAL and tracker by [362]
summing over the $E_{T}$ and $p_{T}$ of HCAL deposits and tracks respectively. [374]
[374]

File: ./detector/l1trigger.tex

\section{Level-1 Trigger} [2]
\label{sec:l1trigger} [2]
[2]
In order to cope with the high collision rate, a two-tier trigger [14]
system is implemented at CMS. The trigger is able to use [25]
limited information from each event to decide whether or not [35]
to record the event. This allows for a large reduction in the rate [48]
of data-taking while maintaining a high efficiency to select events [58]
producing interesting physics objects. [62]
The first level, the Level-1 (L1) trigger, uses custom-built [71]
electronics in order to reduce the output rate from 40 MHz to 100 kHz~\citep{l1}. [85]
Events which satisfy some relatively loose set of criteria are passed to [97]
the second level, the high-level trigger (HLT), where more sophisticated [107]
algorithms, much closer to those used in the offline reconstruction, [117]
are used to decide whether or not to store an event~\citep{hlt}. [128]
[128]
The L1 calorimeter trigger is able to [135]
use coarse measurements of the energy deposited in the ECAL and HCAL [147]
to form candidate physics objects such as electrons, photons, tau leptons [158]
decaying hadronically and hadronic jets. With the exception of [167]
electrons and photons, all of the L1 algorithms run in the Global Calorimeter [180]
Trigger (GCT).  The following section is a description of [189]
a set of calibrations for the GCT designed to improve the resolution of [202]
the L1 jets.  [205]
[205]
\subsection{Jet Energy Calibration} [3]
\label{sec:jetenergyresponse} [3]
The response of the hadronic calorimeter varies [10]
considerably across its barrel, endcap and forward sections. [18]
The energies of jets are corrected offline to account for these effects, [30]
however, if left uncalibrated at L1, this can lead to inefficiencies in the [43]
trigger system. The response is measured in QCD Monte Carlo (MC) [54]
simulation by comparing the $p_{T}$ of L1 jet candidates to generated [65]
jets. The generated jets are reconstructed using an anti-$k_{T}$ jet finding algorithm~\citep{antikt}. [78]
L1 jets are matched [82]
to generator jets by determining the minimum separation, $\Delta R$, between [92]
each generator jet and any L1 jet candidate and requiring it be less than 0.7. [107]
This is much looser than typical matching requirements applied offline due to the coarser [121]
spatial resolution of the L1 jets. [127]
The generator and the closest of these L1 jet is defined as a matched pair [142]
and the response is calculated as $\Lonept/\Genpt$ for that pair. [152]
Figure~\ref{fig:respvseta} shows the response as a function of the pseudo-rapidity of the [164]
generated jet $|\Geneta|$. [167]
[167]
\begin{figure} [167]
\begin{center} [167]
\includegraphics[width=.8\textwidth]{detector/l1jet/bias.pdf} [167]
\caption{Response measured from matched generator-L1 jet pairs in MC [176]
as a function of the generator jet pseudo-rapidity $|\Geneta|$.} [185]
\label{fig:respvseta} [185]
\end{center} [185]
\end{figure} [185]
[185]
The response is measured in 11 $|\eta|$ bins which correspond to the 11 GCT regions. [200]
Corrections for each region are derived as a function of $\Lonept$ by determining [213]
the average response, $\left<\Lonept/\Genpt\right>$, and $\left<\Lonept\right>$ [219]
in 4 GeV bins of $\Genpt$ between 14 GeV and 200 GeV. Below 14 GeV, the resolution in $\Lonept$ restricts [239]
a proper measurement of the response while above 200 GeV, the response approaches unity. [253]
The average response is taken from the mean of a [263]
Gaussian fit to the distribution of $\Lonept/\Genpt$ while $<\Lonept>$ is taken as the mean [277]
average of the $\Lonept$ distribution. For low values of $\Genpt$, the response becomes very non-Gaussian [292]
due to the limited resolution of the L1 trigger, so in this case, the average response is taken [310]
as the mean of the $\Lonept/\Genpt$ distribution. The response is inverted to provide a [324]
corrective scale factor in each region as a function of $\Lonept$. This is then parameterised [339]
by performing a chi-squared fit of the functional form given in Equation~\ref{eqn:jecfit}. [351]
[351]
\begin{equation} [351]
\left<\Lonept/\Genpt\right>^{-1} = \Lonept \cdot \left ( p_{0} + [352]
\frac{p_{1}}{(\log \Lonept)^{2}+p_{2}}+p_{3} \exp(-p_{4} [352]
(\log \Lonept-p_{5} ) ^{2}) \right ) [352]
\label{eqn:jecfit} [352]
\end{equation} [352]
[352]
The functional form chosen provides a good description of the shape at low $\Lonept$ in the high $|\eta|$ regions [371]
and is the same as that used for offline jet calibration at CMS~\citep{jetcalib}. [384]
The parameterisation provides a multiplicative correction to be applied to L1 jets online. [397]
Figure~\ref{fig:egcorrfunc} is an example of the fit in the $0.348 < |\Geneta| < 0.695$ bin. [408]
The full set of fits in each of the 11 $\Genpt$ bins can be found in Appendix~\ref{app:jecfits}. [425]
[425]
\begin{figure} [425]
\begin{center} [425]
\includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{detector/l1jet/egcorrfunc.pdf} [425]
\end{center} [425]
\caption{Correction function for the $0.348 < |\Geneta| < 0.695$. The points represent the average [435]
quantities as measured in MC. The blue line is a parametric fit to the points [450]
using a chi-squared minimisation. The error bars, estimated from the number of MC events, are too small [467]
to be visible in this plot.} [473]
\label{fig:egcorrfunc} [473]
\end{figure} [473]
[473]
\subsection{Calibration Performance} [2]
The calibrations derived were applied using the GCT emulation software to the same MC sample [17]
used to derive them to provide a closure test of their performance. [29]
The response is shown in Figure~\ref{fig:closure} [35]
as a function of $\Lonept$ and $\Geneta$. The points in each figure are calculated from a Gaussian fit to the distribution [56]
of $\Lonept/\Genpt$ in bins of $\Lonept$ and $\Geneta$ respectively. [65]
The results show that the procedure closes [72]
to a precision of between 5\% and 10\%. The improvement in L1 jet resolution expected from MC [89]
is demonstrated in Figure~\ref{fig:mcresolutionl1}. The resolution, calculated by fitting a Gaussian to the distribution [103]
of the difference in $E_{T}$ measured at L1 to that of the generator jet [117]
in bins of $\Lonept$ (see Appendix~\ref{app:closurefits}), for L1 jets is shown before and after applying the [133]
corrections. [134]
[134]
\begin{figure} [134]
\begin{center} [134]
\includegraphics[width=0.49\textwidth]{detector/l1jet/rspvspt.pdf} [134]
\includegraphics[width=0.49\textwidth]{detector/l1jet/rspvseta.pdf} [134]
\end{center} [134]
\caption{Closure tests performed in MC as a function of $\Lonept$ (left) and $\Geneta$ (right). [148]
The test shows that after applying the corrections, the response is within 10\% (dashed lines) of unity. [165]
The error bars are too small to be visible in these plots.} [177]
\label{fig:closure} [177]
\end{figure} [177]
[177]

\subsubsection{Performance in Data} [210]
The corrections derived in MC were applied to data online during and since run 2011B. [225]
The resolution as a function of $\Lonept$ was measured using events in data from that run period [242]
using the following method. [246]
First, the fraction of L1 jets above some threshold in $\Lonept$ is determined as a function [262]
of the fully reconstructed jet $E_{T}$ in data.  [270]
This is then fit with an error function of the form, [281]
\begin{equation} [281]
\mathrm{erf}(x)\propto \int_{0}^{\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma}} e^{-t^{2}}dt, [282]
\end{equation} [282]
to provide a measure of the average energy in the calorimeters [293]
for jets which just pass the threshold at L1 ($\mu$) and the resolution of those jets ($\sigma$). [310]
As the full energy reconstruction for jets at CMS is much [321]
more accurate than the value reconstructed at the L1 trigger, the effects of the jet energy resolution [338]
after applying the full jet reconstruction are negligible. This is repeated for different thresholds in $\Lonept$. [354]
Figure~\ref{fig:l1dataresolution} shows the resolution as a function [361]
of $E_{T}$, where the value of $E_{T}$ is taken from the $\mu$ parameter of each fit. [377]
The uncertainties on each point represent the statistical uncertainty from the error function fits. [391]
The points are fit with the parameterisation given in Equation~\ref{eqn:resofit} to extract the parameters which describe the [408]
resolution of the calorimeter. The energy resolution of the L1 jets is improved after applying these [424]
calibrations in the GCT~\citep{l1triggernote}. [428]
%An independent set of corrections were derived and applied during Run2011A but [428]
%were found to give worse performance than the ones described here in particular for jets with [428]
%$E_{T}>130$ GeV. [428]
[428]
\begin{figure} [428]
\begin{center} [428]
\includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{detector/l1jet/DataResolution.pdf} [428]
\end{center} [428]
\caption{Energy resolution, $\sigma_{E}$, of L1 jets as a function of transverse energy deposited in the [443]
calorimeter, $E_{T}$. The coefficients of the functional form shown are the result of a fit to the points.} [461]
\label{fig:l1dataresolution} [461]
\end{figure} [461]

\chapter{Higgs Boson Decay to Two Photons} [6]
\label{chap:hgg} [6]
[6]
The two photon channel is one of the most promising decay modes in [19]
the search for the SM Higgs boson at the LHC. [29]
Despite having a relatively small branching ratio, the decay $\Hgg$ [39]
provides a very clean final state in which the kinematics of the Higgs boson are [54]
fully reconstructed. It is, therefore, [59]
one of the most sensitive channels at low mass. [68]
The dominant source of background is from real, prompt diphoton events from QCD [81]
processes, $pp\rightarrow\gamma\gamma$ (prompt-prompt). [84]
In addition, there are contributions from $pp\rightarrow\gamma+jet$ (prompt-fake) and [93]
$pp\rightarrow jet+jet$ (fake-fake) in which jets are mis-identified as photons. [102]
In high-priority analyses such as the search for the Higgs boson, cross-checking of analysis [116]
techniques is essential to ensure a robust result. At CMS, it is the policy to designed at least two [135]
different techniques for the same analysis ideally implemented in independent code bases. [147]
In particular, as the signal rate in the $\Hgg$ decay mode is small compared to the background rates, [165]
the sensitivity of the search is heavily influenced by how well the backgrounds are understood. [180]
For these reasons, two data-driven techniques for extracting the signal were developed. [192]
The first (method A) uses a fully parametric description of the background which is fit to the data. [210]
The type of parameterisation and the number of parameters are chosen so that the systematic uncertainty [226]
introduced by potentially choosing the wrong functional form is less than $\frac{\displaystyle 1}{\displaystyle 5}$ [238]
of the statistical uncertainty in the fit~\citep{HIG-11-033}. [245]
The second (method B) uses a binned model constructed from [255]
sidebands in the diphoton invariant mass spectrum. [262]
Method B was developed by the author and serves as an independent [274]
cross-check of the former. In particular, this is achieved though allowing direct [286]
inclusion of the background modelling systematic uncertainties in the signal extraction thereby building [299]
confidence in the understanding of the background. [306]
This chapter describes a search for a Higgs boson decaying to two photons [319]
which was performed on the full 2011 dataset corresponding to \clumi of proton-proton collisions [332]
recorded at CMS at a center of mass energy of 7 TeV. [344]
In Sections~\ref{sec:datasamples} to~\ref{sec:eventselection}, the reconstruction and [350]
selection of events used for this analysis is detailed. Section~\ref{sec:signalextraction} [360]
then describes method B for modelling the background for the purposes [371]
of extracting a potential signal and statistical interpretations of the data. [382]
%Figure~\ref{fig:mvaoverview} is a flow chart of the analysis strategy indicating the point [382]
%at which the two methods diverge. [382]
Results from the 2011 dataset are given in Section~\ref{sec:hggresults2011} and the update for the ICHEP conference in July 2012 [401]
at which the discovery announcement of the new boson was made is given in~\ref{sec:8tev}. [415]
[415]
\begin{figure} [415]
\includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/generalPlots/mvaflowchart.pdf} [415]
\caption{Flow chart of the $\Hgg$ analysis performed on the 2011 dataset. The blue boxes [429]
indicate stages which involve the use of a boosted decision tree (BDT). The red boxes indicate [445]
inputs from the common CMS reconstruction and are not detailed in this chapter. The two [460]
methods for signal extraction, labelled A and B, are indicated by the green boxes.} [474]
\label{fig:mvaoverview} [474]
\end{figure} [474]
[474]
\section{Data Samples} [2]
\label{sec:datasamples} [2]
[2]
The dataset used for this analysis is taken from a combination of the 2011A [16]
(March-August) and 2011B (September-October) proton-proton collision runs. [23]
The selection of the dataset is based around dedicated diphoton triggers [34]
which select events satisfying one of two sets of criteria. [44]
The first set requires two HLT photon candidates, one with $\pt>26$ GeV and the other with [60]
$\pt>18$ GeV, which are well isolated in the calorimeter~\citep{AN-12-048}. The second has a lower threshold on [76]
the first photon, $\pt>22$ GeV but requires that both photons have localised showers in the ECAL [92]
($\rnine>0.8$ in 2011A and $\rnine>0.9$ in 2011B). [99]
Additionally, the invariant mass of the two trigger objects is required to be [112]
greater than 60 (70) GeV in the 2011A(B) datasets. [122]
Events which would pass the full offline selection but fail to trigger at the HLT lead to an inefficiency, [141]
reducing the number of signal events with respect to that expected from an integrated luminosity of \clumi. [157]
However, the thresholds applied offline are chosen to be much tighter than those of the trigger; [173]
the trigger efficiency is $>$99\% with respect to the analysis selection~\citep{AN-12-048}. [185]
[185]
Signal Monte Carlo (MC) events are generated for a Higgs boson decaying to two photons via the four main [204]
production processes, gluon-gluon fusion ($ggH$), vector boson fusion ($qqH$) and associated $W/Z$ ($VH$) [217]
and $\ttbar$ ($ttH$) production. [221]
The gluon-gluon fusion and vector boson fusion processes were generated with \texttt{POWHEG}~\citep{powheg} with [234]
next-to leading order (NLO) contributions whereas [240]
the two associated production processes were generated to leading order (LO) only. [252]
The $\pt$ spectrum of the Higgs boson ($\pt^{H}$) from gluon-gluon fusion was calculated at [266]
next-to-next-to leading plus next-to leading log resummed order (NNLO+NLL) using the \texttt{HqT} program~\citep{hqt}. [280]
The production cross-sections and branching ratios are taken from the LHC Cross-section Working Group~\citep{lhcxswg}. [294]
[294]
Background processes were generated at LO using \texttt{POWHEG} interfaced with \texttt{PYTHIA}~\citep{pythia}. [305]
The QCD dijet and $\gamma+jet$ samples were filtered by requiring the generated photons, electrons and neutral [321]
mesons with $\pt>15$ GeV have at most one charged particle in a cone, $\Delta R<0.2$, to increase the [338]
production efficiency with respect to the tracker isolation requirements of the full selection. [351]
The background samples considered for this analysis are summarized in Table~\ref{tab:backgroundmc}. [362]
A full simulation of the CMS detector is provided in \texttt{GEANT4} which is used for all signal [379]
and background MC samples~\citep{geant4}. The MC includes a simulation of additional interaction vertices expected in data [395]
from pileup. This is where multiple pp collisions occur within a single bunch crossing which results in several [413]
primary vertices being reconstructed. The distribution in the number of reconstructed vertices in [426]
MC is corrected to match that observed in data. [435]
[435]
\begin{table} [435]
\begin{tabular}{|l r|c|c|} [435]
\hline [435]
\textbf{Process}  & &  \textbf{Cross-section} ($pb$) & \textbf{Luminosity} ($pb^{-1}$)\\ [435]
\hline [435]

\hline [435]
DiPhoton Box & $\hat{\pt}~25-250$ & 12.37 & 41900 \\ [435]
\hline [435]
