\end{tabular} [435]
\caption{Background MC used throughout the analysis with production cross-sections and [445]
corresponding equivalent integrated luminosity. The prompt-prompt ($\gamma\gamma$) sample [453]
comprises events from the DiphotonJets and Diphoton Box samples. Both the QCD dijet and Gamma+Jet [469]
contain prompt-fake ($\gamma j$) events. The samples are filtered to avoid double counting [481]
of this background. Fake-fake ($jj$) events are taken from the QCD Dijet sample.} [494]
\label{tab:backgroundmc} [494]
\end{table} [494]
[494]
\section{Object Reconstruction and Identification} [4]
\label{sec:objectrecoandid} [4]
[4]
The reconstruction of all objects used for this analysis, in both data and MC, [18]
is based on the standardized CMS reconstruction software \texttt{\cmssw}~\citep{cmssw}. [26]
Additional sensitivity can be gained by refining the object selection and reconstruction specifically [39]
to the search for $\Hgg$. [44]
[44]
\subsection{Boosted Decision Trees} [3]
\label{sec:bdts} [3]
Boosted decision trees (BDT) are used in the $\Hgg$ search described in this [16]
chapter in order to achieve the maximum sensitivity to a potential signal. [28]
For most of the BDTs used in this analysis, the BDT is used to provide separation between signal and background processes. [49]
The first step in producing a BDT of this type is to identify a list of ``input'' [66]
variables which describe the event objects and provide discrimination [75]
between signal and background.  [79]
These can be variables such as the $\rnine$ and $\sigieie$ [89]
of the photon superclusters or kinematic variables of the event such as [101]
the transverse momentum of the diphoton system ($\ptgg$). [109]
Additional variables, such as the positions of the photons within the detector, [121]
are included so that the BDT can account for correlations between the [133]
input variables due to detector effects. [139]
[139]
A decision tree (DT) is then trained on a MC simulation sample of signal and background [155]
events. The DT splits the events into two sub-samples by applying a series of cuts [170]
on the input variables. The purity, $p$, of each sub-sample is defined as [183]
the fraction of the events which are signal, [191]
\begin{equation} [191]
p = \frac{N_{s}}{N_{s}+N_{b}}, [192]
\end{equation} [192]
where $N_{s}$ and $N_{b}$ are the sum of weights for the signal and background samples. [207]
A separation criterion is defined to decide whether or not to further sub-divide [220]
that subset. A number of criterion definitions exist, though commonly the [231]
Gini index, $p(1-p)$ is used. Values which are close to one indicate [243]
the sample is polluted by background, so above some configurable threshold, [254]
the sub-sample is further split and the process continues. [263]
This continues until either all sub-samples are below the threshold or the [275]
user-defined maximum number of splitting levels (tree depth) is reached. [285]
Each MC event is then assigned a value of -1 or +1 depending on whether it is [302]
or is not in a sub-sample with $p>0.5$. The DT is trained by varying the cuts [318]
applied in order to maximise the purity in each sub-sample. [328]
Several events will be incorrectly classified by simply taking the output of the DT. [342]
This is mitigated by training a set of DTs on the same sample and modifying the [358]
contribution from each DT through a processes known as ``boosting''. [368]
A weight is applied simultaneously to all of the DTs by minimising the [381]
binomial log-likelihood loss function for the sample of $K$ events, [391]
\begin{equation} [391]
L(F,y) = \sum_{k=1}^{K} \ln\left(1+e^{-2 Fy} \right), [392]
\end{equation} [392]
where $y=-1$ for a background event and $y=+1$ for a signal event. [404]
Each DT can be considered as a member of a family of functions $f(\mathbf{x};\mathbf{b}_{n})$ [418]
for a particular set of cut values $\mathbf{b}=\mathbf{b}_{n}$~\citep{friedmanbdt}. [426]
The function $F$ is the weighted average over the individual DTs given by, [439]
\begin{equation} [439]
F(\mathbf{x};\mathbf{a},\mathbf{b}_{n}) = [440]
\sum_{n=0}^{N}a_{n}f(\mathbf{x};\mathbf{b}_{n});~\mathbf{a}=(a_{1},a_{2}\cdots a_{N}). [440]
\end{equation} [440]
Although other weighting schemes can be used, for the BDTs trained in this analysis, [454]
the scheme described, known as gradient boosting, was found to give the best performance [468]
(see Section~\ref{sec:signalextraction}). [470]
The resulting set of trees is known as a boosted decision tree. [482]
All of the BDTs used for this analysis were trained using the \texttt{TMVA} [495]
toolkit~\citep{tmva} available within the \texttt{ROOT} framework. [501]
\subsection{Supercluster Energy Correction} [3]
\label{sec:superclusterenergyreconstruction} [3]
[3]
As the natural width of the Higgs boson is around 100 MeV at low $\mh$, [18]
the width of a reconstructed mass peak from [26]
a $\Hgg$ decay is driven by the experimental energy resolution of the photons. [39]
This resolution can be improved dramatically by correcting the raw energy of the supercluster [53]
at the per-photon level. These corrections are derived using a multivariate technique [65]
in which a regression BDT is trained on prompt photons in the gamma+jet MC sample using the [83]
ratio of the generated photon energy to the raw energy of the reconstructed supercluster~\citep{AN-12-160}. [97]
As this ratio can vary across different regions of the detector, [108]
the input variables include both the $\eta$ and $\phi$ positions of the supercluster. [121]
In addition, several variables are included which describe the shower shape: $\rnine$, [133]
the energy weighted widths in $\eta$ and $\phi$ of the supercluster, the energy [146]
weighted crystal width ($\sigieie$) and the ratio of hadronic energy behind the supercluster [159]
to the energy of the supercluster itself ($\hoe$). [167]
In the endcaps, there is additional information [174]
available from the pre-shower measurement so the ratio of the energy in [186]
the pre-shower to the raw supercluster energy is included. [195]
Figure~\ref{fig:mcregrcomparison} shows the improvement [199]
in resolution after applying the regression corrections (Raw + Regression) compared to the standard [212]
calibrations used at CMS (Standard). In parallel, a similar set of corrections were derived by [227]
fitting an analytical expression (Standard + IC Residual) to the residual energy difference between the [241]
generated and reconstructed photon energy as a function of [250]
supercluster energy, position and $\rnine$~\citep{AN-11-343}. [255]
The regression technique reduces the effective resolution of the Higgs mass peak ($\sigma_{\mathrm{eff}}$) [268]
resolution by around 30\% over using the raw supercluster energy [278]
compared to the analytic fit which improves the resolution by 15\%. [289]
[289]
\begin{figure} [289]
\includegraphics[width=.6\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/generalPlots/regrresall.pdf} [289]
\caption{Comparison of the diphoton mass peak in Higgs MC with a mass of 120 GeV using different [306]
measurements of the photon energy. The black line [314]
is from using the raw energy of the supercluster, the blue is from using the analytic fit method [332]
(Standard + IC Residual) [335]
and the red from using the regression method (Raw + Regression). The quantity $\sigma_{eff}$, [348]
the narrowest range in $\mgg$ which contains 68\% of the distribution, is given for each peak~\citep{AN-12-048}.} [364]
\label{fig:mcregrcomparison} [364]
\end{figure} [364]
[364]
An estimate of the per-photon energy resolution, $\sigma_{E}$, is obtained by training a second [378]
regression BDT targeting the absolute deviation between the correction estimated by the [390]
first BDT and the true correction to generator level. This second BDT is trained on an independent [407]
set of events to the first. The per-photon resolution is used to calculate an estimate of the [424]
per-event mass resolution, $\sigma_{\mgg}$, which is used during the event selection [435]
(Section~\ref{sec:eventselection}). [436]
[436]
\subsubsection{Energy Scale Measured in Data} [441]
Despite correcting the energy of the photons using the regression technique, discrepancies between data and [456]
MC are still observed. This is due to additional detector effects which may not be simulated, such as the [475]
time dependence of the ECAL crystal transparency~\citep{CMS-DP-2012-007}. Further corrections are [485]
derived based on $\Zee$ events which provide an invariant mass peak (with almost no background) constructed from [502]
electromagnetic objects reconstructed using a similar procedure to photons. [511]
An additional regression BDT is trained on $\Zee$ MC which is used [523]
to compare the supercluster energy scale in data and MC~\citep{AN-12-048}. [533]
The energy scale of the superclusters is measured by matching the electron [545]
invariant mass peak in data to that in MC. This is achieved using an analytic fit to the $\Zee$ peak in data and MC [569]
separately. The natural peak of the $Z$ is described using a Breit-Wigner distribution whose parameters are fixed [586]
to those given by the Particle Data Group, $m_{Z}=91.188,~\Gamma_{Z} = 2.495$~\citep{pdg}. This is then convoluted [599]
with a Crystal Ball (CB) which describes the resolution effects of the calorimeter and energy losses from [616]
bremsstrahlung before the ECAL~\citep{crystalball}. [620]
The CB parameter $\Delta m$ is a free parameter of the fit giving the [633]
offset of the peak position from the $Z$ pole. [642]
[642]
The values of these fitted parameters varies with the position of the supercluster ($|\eta|$). Moreover the [658]
variation in data is strongly dependant on the run during which the data were taken. The scale is extracted in [678]
six run ranges and four $|\eta|$ regions to account for this effect, providing a first set of corrections. [696]
The difference between MC and data is dependent on whether the electron showered in the material before the calorimeter [715]
or not which is characterised by the $\rnine$ of the supercluster. [726]
The data-MC difference in each $|\eta|$ region is therefore measured [736]
a second time after applying the first set of corrections to the data and obtaining the residual difference [754]
for electrons with $\rnine<0.94$ and $\rnine>0.94$ separately. This dependency, [763]
unlike that with $|\eta|$, is found to be constant with time. The final energy scale correction is then defined [782]
as the product of the two corrections. The relative correction, [792]
\begin{equation} [792]
1-\Delta P = 1 - \frac {\displaystyle \Delta m_{data} - \Delta m_{MC} }{\displaystyle m_{Z} }, [793]
\end{equation} [793]
is applied to the photons in data. The values for the scale in each category, $\Delta P$, are given in [812]
Tables~\ref{tab:escale2011eb} and~\ref{tab:escale2011ee} of Appendix~\ref{app:escaleandresolutiontabs}. [816]
The uncertainties on these measurements are primarily due to [825]
the difference in the $\rnine$ distribution of electrons and photons. In addition, smaller systematics [839]
are included due to the variation of the measurements when changing the electron selection and [854]
between using the electron-trained and photon-trained regression corrections. [862]
These uncertainties are incorporated into the signal model for the purposes of [874]
signal extraction as described in Section~\ref{sec:signalmodel}. [880]
[880]
\subsection{Vertex Selection} [2]
\label{sec:vertexselection} [2]
[2]
The assignment of the correct vertex to the diphoton pair is an important step in the reconstruction of [20]
its invariant mass. Figure~\ref{fig:higgsrightwrongvertex} shows the invariant mass distributions from a SM [32]
Higgs boson for events in which the vertex selected is within 10mm of the generated vertex [48]
compared to those in which an incorrect vertex is assigned. [58]
Since photons do not leave tracks, computing the angle between the two photons [71]
depends strongly on determining the vertex at which they were produced. [82]
[82]
\begin{figure} [82]
\includegraphics[width=.8\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/generalPlots/rightwrongvtxpeak.pdf} [82]
\caption{Invariant mass peak in $\Hgg$ MC with $\mh=125$ GeV. The blue histogram is from events in which [99]
the generated vertex is within 10mm of the vertex assigned to the diphoton pair. The red histogram is [117]
from events in which the incorrect vertex is assigned. Both distributions are normalised to unit area for [134]
ease of comparison.} [137]
\label{fig:higgsrightwrongvertex} [137]
\end{figure} [137]
[137]
A BDT was trained to rank the standard collection of reconstructed vertices. [149]
The input variables are chosen to exploit the correlation between the diphoton system and the recoiling tracks. [166]
These are the $\pt$-balance, [171]
\begin{eqnarray} [171]
-\sum_{all tracks} \left(\ptvec^{track}\cdot \frac{\displaystyle \ptggvec}{\displaystyle \ptgg}\right), [172]
\end{eqnarray} [172]
and the $\pt$-asymmetry calculated as, [178]
\begin{eqnarray} [178]
\frac{\displaystyle |\sum_{all tracks} \ptvec^{track}| - \ptgg }{ \displaystyle|\sum_{all tracks} \ptvec^{track}|}. [179]
\end{eqnarray} [179]
In addition, the sum of the square of the transverse momenta of all the tracks associated [195]
to a given vertex is included to preferentially select hard interactions. If at least one of the [212]
photons converts to an $e^{+}e^{-}$ pair, the difference between the position in $z$ as calculated [227]
using the electron-positron pair and that from the standard vertex, relative to the resolution in $z$ [243]
is included as an input variable. The BDT was trained on $\Hgg$ MC with a mass of 120 GeV. [262]
Figure~\ref{fig:vtxeffhmc} shows the fraction of events in a gluon-gluon MC sample in which [275]
the vertex with the highest BDT score is within 10mm of the true vertex as a function of $\pt^{H}$. [294]
\begin{figure} [294]
\includegraphics[width=.8\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/generalPlots/vtxEffHMC.pdf} [294]
\caption{Fraction of simulated gluon-gluon fusion events in which the $z$ position of the selected vertex [309]
is within 10mm of the true vertex as a function of Higgs boson $\pt$. The red histogram is the average [329]
probability to select the correct vertex in each bin estimated from the per-event BDT.} [343]
\label{fig:vtxeffhmc} [343]
\end{figure} [343]
The fraction of events in which this occurs in data is measured using $\Zmumu$ events [358]
as a function of the $\pt$ of the $Z$ boson~\citep{AN-12-048}. This is used to correct the Higgs signal MC for [378]
the purpose of signal modelling. [383]
[383]
A second, per-event, BDT is trained using the output of the first to identify [397]
under which conditions the correct vertex is selected. The output of this BDT is then used to [414]
calculate the probability in a given event that the correct vertex is assigned. The red line in Figure~\ref{fig:vtxeffhmc} [432]
shows a comparison of the per-event vertex probability estimated from the second BDT against the [447]
fraction of the events in which the selected vertex is located within 10mm from the true vertex. The per-event vertex probability [468]
estimate provides a good model of the actual fraction of events in which the correct vertex is selected. [486]
[486]
\subsection{Photon Identification} [2]
\label{sec:photonidentification} [2]
[2]
A large portion of the fake background in the $\Hgg$ search is due to high momentum neutral mesons [20]
which decay to two photons where both the photons are combined into the same supercluster~\citep{HIG-11-033}. [35]
Information from the shower shape of the photon supercluster can be used, in addition to the [51]
energy isolation within the calorimeter, in order to distinguish these from prompt photons [64]
from the primary interaction point. A BDT was trained on MC events to combine the relevant information [81]
into a single photon identification (ID) discriminator. The signal used for the training was taken from [97]
simulated $\Hgg$ events with a Higgs boson mass of 121 GeV while the background was [112]
taken from non-prompt photons in the gamma+jet (prompt-fake) sample. [122]
Before training, events are required to pass a loose pre-selection designed to avoid training [136]
where the MC is unable to properly describe the data and to match the variables used in the trigger~\citep{AN-12-048}. [155]
In addition, photon candidates are removed if there is a reconstructed electron matched to the [170]
photon supercluster with no matching conversion reconstruction. This greatly reduces the contribution [182]
from electrons in $\Zee$ faking photons. The same pre-selection is applied to all MC and data for extracting the signal. [202]
The efficiency of the pre-selection for signal was measured in $\Zee$ data and MC using a tag-and-probe [219]
method~\citep{AN-12-116}. [220]
[220]
The measurement is made using events which are selected using a dielectron [232]
trigger with supercluster transverse energies of at least 20 GeV. The two objects are then [247]
randomly assigned as either the ``tag'' or ``probe'' candidate. The tags are then required to [262]
pass a tight electron selection based on its isolation and supercluster shower shape. [275]
Events are then split into those in which the probe candidate passes or fails the pre-selection [291]
and the ratio of signal events, after background subtraction, in each class provides the [305]
efficiency measurement of the pre-selection. For the pre-selection efficiency measurement, [315]
the background subtraction is performed using a likelihood fit to the invariant [327]
mass of the tag-probe pair, modelling the signal with a Breit-Wigner convoluted with a [341]
Crystal Ball and the background with an exponential function. [350]
Both models are multiplied by an error function of the form, [361]
\begin{equation} [361]
\mathrm{erf}(x)\propto \int_{0}^{\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma}} e^{-t^{2}}dt, [362]
\end{equation} [362]
with parameters $\mu$ and $\sigma$ freely floating. The measurement is performed [373]
in four probe categories depending on the $\rnine$ and $|\eta|$ of its supercluster. [386]
The results are shown in Table~\ref{tab:sigeffpresel}. [392]
[392]
\begin{table} [392]
\begin{tabular}{| l | c | c | c |} [392]
\hline [392]
\textbf{Category} & \textbf{Data} & \textbf{MC} & \textbf{Data/MC} \\ [392]
\hline [392]
EB $\rnine>0.9$ & 0.927 $\pm$ 0.001 & 0.928 $\pm$ 0.001 &0.999 $\pm$ 0.001 \\ [392]
EB $\rnine<0.9$ & 0.888 $\pm$ 0.002 & 0.903 $\pm$ 0.001 &0.984 $\pm$ 0.003 \\ [392]
EE $\rnine>0.9$ & 0.944 $\pm$ 0.001 & 0.938 $\pm$ 0.001 &1.006 $\pm$ 0.001 \\ [392]
EE $\rnine<0.9$ & 0.864 $\pm$ 0.001 & 0.852 $\pm$ 0.001 &1.014 $\pm$ 0.001 \\ [392]
\hline [392]
\end{tabular} [392]
\caption{Signal efficiency for the preselection measured in data and MC using tag-and-probe in [405]
$\Zee$ events. The Data/MC ratios are applied as corrections to the signal MC for the purposes [422]
of signal modelling. The uncertainties listed here are statistical only.} [432]
\label{tab:sigeffpresel} [432]
\end{table} [432]
[432]
The input variables are chosen to be insensitive to the kinematics of the diphoton system itself [448]
including the diphoton invariant mass. The first set of variables describe the shower shape of the [464]
supercluster: $\hoe$ (the ratio of energy deposited in the HCAL behind the ECAL to that of the supercluster), [482]
$\sigieie$, $\rnine$ and the energy weighted widths of the supercluster in [493]
$\eta$ and $\phi$ ($\sigma_{\eta},~\sigma_{\phi}$). The $\eta$ of the supercluster is [503]
included as the shower shape is dependant on the position within the calorimeter. [516]
The second set of input variables describe the [524]
isolation of the photon in the calorimeter and tracker scaled to account for [537]
the additional expected energy density due to pileup, $\rho$~\citep{2011JInst611002C}. [546]
These are: the sum of the track isolation, [554]
calculated relative to the chosen vertex and the vertex giving the maximum track isolation, [568]
ECAL and HCAL isolations in cones with $\Delta R<0.3$ minus $\rho$ times the effective area [582]
of the cone~\citep{2011JInst611002C}; [585]
and the absolute ECAL and HCAL isolations within cones of $\Delta R <0.3$ and $\Delta R<0.4$ [598]
respectively. In addition, the number of reconstructed vertices in the bunch crossing is included [612]
to reduce the pileup dependence of the isolation variables. [621]
[621]
Separate BDTs are trained for the ECAL barrel and endcaps as the shower [634]
shape and isolation variables are rather distinct between the two. [644]
A cut is made on the photon ID BDT output to select events used for the signal extraction which [663]
keeps practically all ($>99\%$) of the signal while removing around 22\% of background events. [677]
The cut is chosen to be loose as the output of the photon ID will be used as an input to the [699]
event selection (diphoton BDT) as described in Section~\ref{sec:diphotonbdt}. [707]
[707]
\section{Event Selection} [2]
\label{sec:eventselection} [2]
[2]
In addition to passing the pre-selection, the two photons are required to pass mass-dependant transverse [17]
momenta cuts, $p_{T}/\mgg > 1/3, ~1/4$ for the leading and sub-leading photon respectively. [27]
Where more than one diphoton pair in an event satisfies these criteria, the pair which has the largest [45]
sum of photon transverse momenta is selected as the Higgs boson candidate. [57]
The final selection of diphoton candidates used for the signal extraction is based on using as much information [75]
in the event as possible to distinguish likely signal candidate events from the background. Although the [91]
photon ID BDT is successful at rejecting fake backgrounds, a large portion of the background is due to [109]
real prompt diphotons from QCD processes. In order to distinguish these from a Higgs signal, [124]
the specific kinematics and topology of the event are exploited. [134]
[134]
\subsection{Diphoton BDT} [2]
\label{sec:diphotonbdt} [2]
A BDT was trained to utilise the kinematics of the selected diphoton pair to discriminate prompt photons [19]
from QCD background from those produced by the decay $\Hgg$. The BDT was trained using the prompt-prompt, prompt-fake [37]
and fake-fake samples for background and Higgs MC with a mass of 123 GeV for signal. [53]
As the mass of the Higgs boson is unknown, the search is performed under different mass hypotheses. [70]
In order to allow for the application of the same selection to the data under any mass hypothesis, [88]
the input variables to the BDT are chosen to be mass-independent. In addition, this allows [103]
for a fully data-driven estimation of the background shape as described in Section~\ref{sec:backgroundmodel}. [116]
The input variables which describe the kinematics are: [124]
the relative transverse momenta of the leading and sub-leading photons ($\pt^{1}/\mgg,~\pt^{2}/\mgg$ respectively), [136]
their pseudo-rapidities, $\eta^{1},~\eta^{2}$ and the cosine of the [144]
angle between the two photons in the transverse plane $cos(\Delta\phi)=cos(\phi^{1}-\phi^{2})$. [154]
In addition, information regarding the quality [160]
of the objects, the two photons and the selected vertex, is included in the form of the output of the [180]
photon ID and the vertex probability BDTs. The per-photon resolution estimate, $\sigma_{E}$ is combined for [195]
each photon to produce a per-event mass resolution estimate under the assumption that [208]
the correct vertex is selected, $\sigma_{\mgg}(\mathrm{right-vertex})$, [214]
\begin{equation} [214]
\sigma_{\mgg} (\mathrm{right-vtx}) = \frac{\displaystyle \mgg}{\displaystyle 2} [215]
\sqrt{ \left( \frac{\displaystyle {\sigma_{E}^{1}}}{\displaystyle E^{1} } \right)^{2} [215]
    + \left( \frac{\displaystyle {\sigma_{E}^{2}}}{\displaystyle E^{2} } \right)^{2} [215]
    } [215]
\end{equation} [215]
where $E^{1}$ and $E^{2}$ are the energies of the two photons. [226]
[226]
Since the correct vertex is not always selected, the mass resolution assuming the incorrect vertex is chosen [243]
is calculated using the average length of the region in which the two proton beams collide in data, $\sigma_{Z}=5.8$cm. In this case, the distance [268]
between the selected and true vertex will be distributed as a Gaussian with width $\sqrt{2}\sigma_{Z}$. [283]
The contribution to the resolution, $\sigma_{\mgg}^{vtx}$, can be calculated analytically given the positions of [297]
the two photons. The mass resolution estimator under the assumption that the incorrect vertex is chosen is [314]
given by the sum in quadrature of $\sigma_{\mgg}^{vtx}$ with the mass resolution assuming the correct vertex is chosen. [332]
Both estimators for the mass resolution relative to the invariant mass, $\sigma_{\mgg}/\mgg~$ right/wrong-vtx, [346]
are included as inputs to the diphoton BDT.  [354]
Figures~\ref{fig:diphotonbdtvars1} and~\ref{fig:diphotonbdtvars2} show the input variables from the [362]
final set of selected diphoton candidates in data and MC. [372]
The expectation in each plot from a SM Higgs boson with a mass of 125 GeV, scaled by 10, is shown in red. [395]
The invariant mass distribution in data and MC for events passing the full [408]
selection is given in Figure~\ref{fig:massmcdata}. After the application of the full selection, [420]
the total background contains around 76\% prompt diphoton events. [429]
Figure~\ref{fig:diphotonBDT} shows the diphoton BDT distribution in data and MC. [439]
The final events used for the signal extraction are selected as those with a diphoton BDT output greater than 0.05. [459]
This cut was chosen following an optimization study to minimize the expected exclusion limit in the absence of signal. [478]
Events below this cut value were found to provide negligible improvement in the expected limit~\citep{AN-12-048}. [493]
[493]
\begin{figure}[hbt!] [493]
  \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/variablePlots/pt_1om} [493]
  \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/variablePlots/pt_2om}\\ [493]
 \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/variablePlots/phoeta_1} [493]

 \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/variablePlots/cosdphi} [493]
\caption{Kinematic inputs to the diphoton BDT in data and MC. [503]
  The distributions are for events which pass the full selection [513]
  including a cut on the diphoton BDT output of 0.05. [523]
    The expectation from a SM Higgs boson with 125 GeV is shown in red.} [537]
\label{fig:diphotonbdtvars1} [537]

  \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/variablePlots/phoid_2}\\ [537]

\subsubsection{Diphoton BDT Validation with $\Zee$ Data} [653]
By using a BDT for the full event selection, subtle correlations between the input variables are accounted for [671]
which improve the separation between the signal and background. [680]
Unlike the background model, the signal model is derived from corrected MC. [692]
It is important therefore to ensure that the BDT will respond in the same way in data as for the signal MC [714]
used for the signal extraction. The MC can be validated using $\Zee$ data-MC [727]
comparisons by inverting the electron veto and treating the electrons as though they were photons. [742]
This is done by using the supercluster associated to the electron for the electron's energy measurement [758]
and ignoring the track information. In this way, the reconstruction of the electrons is the same as that [776]
of the photons allowing for validation of the BDT's response to real photons from a resonant decay. [793]
Figure~\ref{fig:zeevaliddiphomva} shows the diphoton BDT distribution in $\Zee$ MC and data after applying [806]
the full selection using this technique. The discrepancies between MC and data are well covered by the [823]
systematic uncertainties on the photon ID BDT output and $\sigma_{E}$ which are included in the final signal model. [841]
[841]
\begin{figure} [841]
 \includegraphics[width=.8\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/zeeValidation/zeevalidationdipho.pdf} [841]
\caption{Diphoton BDT output distribution in $\Zee$ MC and data after the full selection [854]
treating the electrons as photons for the purposes of energy reconstruction. The electron [867]
veto is inverted to preferentially select electrons.} [874]
\label{fig:zeevaliddiphomva} [874]
\end{figure} [874]
[874]
Both the photon ID and regression BDT rely on a detailed simulation of electromagnetic showering  [889]
in MC to correctly describe the data. Due to imperfections of this simulation, systematic [903]
uncertainties are included in the signal model to cover the residual difference observed between MC and data [920]
for high $\pt$ photons. [924]
These uncertainties are validated using $\Zee$ data in the same way as the diphoton BDT. [939]
Figures~\ref{fig:zeevalidsigmaE} and~\ref{fig:zeevalidphoidmva} show the distributions of the [946]
per photon energy resolution estimator $\sigma_{E}$ relative to the photon energy and the output of the [962]
photon ID BDT in $\Zee$ MC and data treating the electrons as photons. The red lines [978]
show the $\pm 1\sigma$ error envelope attributed to the systematic uncertainty on the shower simulation.  [992]
These uncertainties are propagated through the diphoton BDT and included in the signal model as described in [1009]
Section~\ref{sec:signalmodel}. [1010]
[1010]
\begin{figure} [1010]
 \includegraphics[width=.48\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/zeeValidation/sigmaE_EB.pdf} [1010]
  \includegraphics[width=.48\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/zeeValidation/sigmaE_EE.pdf} [1010]
\caption{Per-photon resolution estimator, $\sigma_{E}$, relative to the measured energy in $\Zee$ [1021]
MC and data [1024]
treating the electrons as photons in the barrel (left) and endcaps (right). [1036]
The red lines show the $\pm 1\sigma$ systematic error envelope obtained by scaling the value of [1051]
$\sigma_{E}$ by $\pm 10\%$.} [1054]
\label{fig:zeevalidsigmaE} [1054]
\end{figure} [1054]

\subsection{Dijet Tagging} [2]
\label{sec:dijettagging} [2]
[2]
The contribution to Higgs boson production from vector boson fusion is around a factor ten smaller than that [20]
of gluon-gluon fusion. However, additional information from the two jets associated [31]
with $qqH$ production allows for further reduction of the diphoton background~\citep{HIG-11-033}. [42]
Events containing two jets which pass the full selection and in addition [54]
satisfy a series of criteria designed to target the specific dijet topology are [67]
tagged as likely to have originated from $qqH$ production. For example, Figure~\ref{fig:vbfdeta} shows the [81]
separation in $\eta$ between the two jets. Signal events from vector boson fusion production are [96]
more likely to have a large separation than those from background processes. The full set of [112]
criteria is given in Table~\ref{tab:vbfcuts}. [117]
The dijet tagged events are categorized separately to [125]
the remaining events, thereby exploiting their high signal to background ratio for the purpose of signal [141]
extraction. [142]
[142]
\begin{table} [142]
\begin{tabular*}{0.5\textwidth}{@{\extracolsep{\fill}}|l|c|} [142]
\hline [142]
\textbf{Variable} & \textbf{Cut Value} \\ [142]
\hline [142]
\hline [142]
$E_{T}^{j^{1}}$ & $>$ 30 GeV \\ [142]
$E_{T}^{j^{2}}$ & $>$ 20 GeV \\ [142]
$m_{jj}$  & $>$ 350 GeV \\ [142]
$|\eta_{j^{1}} - \eta_{j^{2}}|$ & $>$ 3.5 \\ [142]
$|\phi_{jj} - \phi_{\gamma\gamma}|$ & $>$ 2.6 \\ [142]
$|\frac{1}{2}(\eta_{j^{1}} + \eta_{j^{2}}) - \eta_{\gamma\gamma}|$ & $<$ 2.5 \\ [142]
\hline [142]
\end{tabular*} [142]
\caption{Dijet selection criteria for the two $qqH$ jets. The leading and sub-leading $E_{T}$ jets [156]
are denoted $j^{1}$ and $j^{2}$ respectively.} [162]
\label{tab:vbfcuts} [162]
\end{table} [162]
[162]

\includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/variablePlots/cut_VBF_dEta_sequential_cat0.pdf} [162]

File: ./hgg7TeV/signalextraction.tex

\section{Signal Extraction} [2]
\label{sec:signalextraction} [2]
The signature for the decay $\Hgg$ is the presence of a narrow peak on a smoothly falling background in [21]
the invariant mass spectrum. [25]
The signal to background ratio can be dramatically increased by focusing on events falling in a window [42]
around the mass of the Higgs boson, $m_{H}$. Since this mass is not predicted in the Standard Model, [60]
the search is performed for a range of mass hypotheses effectively sliding the signal window across [76]
the diphoton invariant mass spectrum, $\mgg$. [82]
As the signal yield for a SM Higgs boson decaying to two photons is small, [97]
additional event information from the detector and the kinematics of the diphoton system can be used to [114]
increase the sensitivity of the search. [120]
[120]
This section describes a multivariate analysis (MVA) based approach to extracting the signal, categorizing events within a sliding [138]
signal window based on a single event discriminator (categorisation BDT). The approach allows for use of data in sidebands [157]
to determine expected event yields within the signal region, making few assumptions about the specific [172]
composition and kinematics of the background. This approach is the second of the two methods (method B) for extracting the signal, used by the CMS $\Hgg$ group. [199]
[199]
\subsection{Definition of the Signal Region} [5]
[5]
Once the expected resolution of the $\Hgg$ peak is determined, the choice of signal window can be optimized [23]
to reduce the uncertainty on the background while selecting as many signal events as possible. [38]
The size of the signal window is chosen using a simplified analysis in which the number of signal events [57]
from a SM Higgs boson with hypothesised mass $m_{H}$ expected within the range $|\Delta M/M_{H}|=|(\mgg-m_{H})/m_{H}| < w$ [71]
is compared to the uncertainty on the total number of events (from background and signal) in that range. [89]
The figure of merit, $N_{S}/\sigma = N_{S}/\sqrt{\sigma_{S}^{2} + \sigma_{B}^{2}}$, is calculated as [97]
a function of signal region cut value, $w$, for a range of mass hypotheses as shown in Figure~\ref{fig:sigwindowopt}. [115]
The error on the number of background events, $\sigma_{B}$, is calculated using the procedure described in [131]
Section~\ref{sec:backgroundmodel} whereas the error on the signal is purely statistical. [141]
For this analysis, $w=0.02$ was chosen as the optimal signal region cut value. [154]
[154]
\begin{figure} [154]
\begin{center} [154]
 \includegraphics[width=0.9\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/fom.pdf} [154]
\end{center} [154]
  \caption{Figure of merit for selection of the signal region cut value, $w$. Each colour shows the evaluation [171]
  under different Higgs boson mass hypotheses.} [177]
 \label{fig:sigwindowopt} [177]
\end{figure} [177]
[177]
[177]
\subsection{Event Categorisation BDT} [3]
\label{sec:bdteventdiscriminator} [3]
[3]
The inputs to the diphoton BDT contain information from the event kinematics and the quality of the photons [21]
and vertex location in the form of the photon ID BDT output and event resolution estimators. [37]
The output of the diphoton BDT combined with the invariant mass of the diphoton system therefore provides [54]
the necessary information to separate signal from background. [62]
[62]
Figure~\ref{fig:bdtplane} [63]
shows the variation in the signal to background ratio ($S/B$) across different regions in the [78]
two-dimensional plane defined by the output of the diphoton BDT and $\dmom$. [90]
Events close to the centre of the peak ($\dmom=0$) with a high score in the diphoton BDT are more [109]
likely signal events than those far from the high $S/B$ regions. [120]
[120]
\begin{figure} [120]
\begin{center} [120]
 \includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/bdt2dplot.png} [120]
\end{center} [120]
\caption{Signal to background ratio as a function of diphoton BDT output and $\dmom$. [133]
The red lines indicate the cuts applied before the training and for applying the event selection. [149]
Darker shades indicate a regions with a higher signal to background ratio. The seven shades indicate the [166]
region contained in each of the seven BDT bins used for the signal extraction at $m_{H}= 123$ GeV.} [183]
\label{fig:bdtplane} [183]
\end{figure} [183]
[183]
The two variables are combined to produce a single event discriminator by training a BDT using the [200]
diphoton BDT output and $\dmom$ as inputs. [207]
The BDT is trained with Higgs signal MC with $m_{H}=123$ GeV including all four production processes [223]
and background MC including prompt-prompt, prompt-fake and fake-fake events. [232]
The performance of several different training methodologies was compared to find which gave the [246]
optimum separation of signal and background. [252]
Two different choices of boosting were studied, adaptive and gradient boosting, both of which [266]
weight decision trees to optimize the performance in terms of signal-background separation~\citep{tmva}. [278]
In addition, these were compared to a simple likelihood [287]
which does not account for correlations between the [295]
diphoton BDT and $\dmom$ as shown in Figure~\ref{fig:mvacomparisons}. [303]
The gradient boosting method was found to give the best performance although the variation between [318]
methodologies is small. [321]
[321]
\begin{figure} [321]
\begin{center} [321]
 \includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/roc} [321]
\end{center} [321]
\caption{Signal efficiency vs background rejection curves for three different MVA techniques used to train [335]
the signal-background event discriminator. The curves give the (in)efficiencies for signal (background) [348]
after applying sequentially tighter cuts on the discriminator output.} [357]
\label{fig:mvacomparisons} [357]
\end{figure} [357]
[357]
With finite statistics, a BDT can be over-trained by allowing the training to emphasise statistical fluctuations which are not physical and will not necessarily be [382]
representative of the data. To test for this, the MC samples are split into two equal samples, the first of which is used to train the BDT. The distribution [411]
of the output values of the BDT from the second set is compared to that of the training sample as shown in Figure~\ref{fig:bdttraining}. The comparison [436]
is shown using both an arbitrary binning scheme and the final set of bins derived in [452]
Section~\ref{sec:binningofthebdtoutputdistribution}. [453]
A $\chi^{2}$ test was performed on the distributions with the final bins giving p-values of 0.06 [469]
for the background and 0.95 for the signal indicating that over-training has not occurred. [483]
[483]
\begin{figure} [483]
\begin{center} [483]
 \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/testvstrain_nolegend} [483]
  \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/testvstrain-finalbins-neat} [483]
\end{center} [483]
\caption{Signal and background BDT output distribution with the training sample (points) [494]
and testing sample (solid area) superimposed. The comparison is shown [504]
using an arbitrary uniform binning (left) and the bins used for extracting the signal (right).} [519]
\label{fig:bdttraining} [519]
\end{figure} [519]
[519]
In this analysis, the background is estimated entirely from data. This means that disagreement between [534]
data and background MC will effect the performance of the BDT rather than the validity of the final results. [553]
The agreement between the data and MC is shown in Figure~\ref{fig:datamcagreement_sidebandBDT} for the mass [567]
hypothesis, $m_{H}=125$ GeV. The level of agreement is sufficient so as not to require in-depth study of the [585]
BDT output distributions of the background MC. [592]
[592]
\begin{figure} [592]
\begin{center} [592]
 \includegraphics[width=.8\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/data-mc-sbsum-mh125} [592]
\end{center} [592]
\caption{Comparison of the distributions of BDT output at $m_{H}=125$ GeV for data and background MC. [607]
The distributions are arbitrarily binned for the purposes of comparison only.} [618]
\label{fig:datamcagreement_sidebandBDT} [618]
\end{figure} [618]
[618]
\subsection{Binning of the BDT Output Distribution} [6]
\label{sec:binningofthebdtoutputdistribution} [6]
[6]
The BDT provides a single variable with which to classify events based on their signal to background [23]
ratio, $S/B$, which will have a discrete number of response values based on the number of [39]
trees used. The boosting procedure provides a pseudo-continuous distribution which is used [51]
to model the signal and background. However, the resulting distribution will still be only [65]
pseudo-continuous. In addition, the BDT response does not directly correspond to a physical [78]
distribution and it is therefore difficult to motivate any parameterisation of either the signal [92]
or background distributions. To overcome these issues, a binning procedure is defined to [105]
construct templates which are used as models for the signal and background expectation as a [120]
function of BDT response range (BDT bin). This procedure is designed firstly to ensure that no [136]
bin has zero background expectation and secondly that as few bins as possible [149]
are used without reducing the sensitivity of the BDT. [158]
These requirements are desirable such that [164]
the expected background yield in each bin can be derived using data outside of the signal region [181]
as described in Section~\ref{sec:backgroundmodel}. [185]
[185]
A scan is performed in which the definitions of the bin boundaries are varied in order to [202]
find the maximum expected significance in the presence of a SM Higgs signal. For $N$ bins [218]
($N-1$ boundaries) with background and signal expectation yields $b_{i}$ and $s_{i}$ respectively, [230]
the expected significance, $\sigma_{exp}$, is given by [237]
[237]
\begin{equation} [237]
\sigma_{exp} = \sqrt{2} \left( \sum_{i=1}^{N} (s_{i}+b_{i})\ln\left(\frac{\displaystyle s_{i}}{\displaystyle b_{i}} +1\right) - s_{i} \right), [238]
\label{eqn:expectedsig_bins} [238]
\end{equation} [238]
using the log-likelihood ratio for Poisson likelihoods. [245]
The binning procedure is defined as follows: [252]
[252]
\begin{enumerate} [252]
[252]
\item The distribution of background MC is binned very finely to provide an almost discrete [266]
dataset (5000 equally spaced bins are used). The background is re-binned such that there are 20 [282]
expected events per bin at a luminosity of \clumi. [290]
\item Smoothed versions of the signal (at each 5 GeV step mass) and background MC templates are produced [307]
in order to obtain a stable model of $S/B$ as a function of BDT bin. [322]
The smoothing procedure is done via binning a fit (of a 9th order polynomial) to the signal [339]
distribution. [340]
\item $N$ bin edges (boundaries), $b_{i}$, are defined on the remaining bins such that $N+1$ bins [355]
are formed with $b_{1} < b_{2} < \ldots < b_{N}$. The first bin is defined as $[-1,b_{1})$ and the last [369]
is defined as $[b_{N},1]$. The $N$ dimensional scan is performed varying these [381]
bin edges to find the maximum expected significance in the presence of a SM Higgs signal. [397]
\item An extra boundary is added and the scan is repeated and the maximum expected [411]
significance is found for $N+1$ boundaries. If the maximum expected significance  [422]
is increased by more than 0.1\% compared to that of step 3, the new boundary is kept and step 4 [442]
is repeated, if not, the procedure terminates. [449]
\end{enumerate} [449]
[449]
The scan in step 3 is split into two parts, first using a large step size to find the [468]
region where the maximum lies followed by a fine scan in small steps within that region. [484]
The ratio of small to large step size is chosen to be that [497]
which minimizes the total number of iterations in the scan to reduce the time taken for the procedure. [515]
An example of the binning procedure is shown in Figure~\ref{fig:binningscheme}. [525]
The red histogram is the $S/B$ distribution after step 1, the [536]
blue after step 2 and the black vertical lines show the final set of 7 bins chosen for this analysis. [556]
Dijet tagged events are treated in the same way as the rest of the events in the analysis [574]
by introducing an eighth bin containing events from any BDT output bin inside the range $\dmom < w$ [590]
which pass the dijet tag. [595]
[595]
\begin{figure} [595]
\begin{center} [595]
 \includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/binningscheme.pdf} [595]
\end{center} [595]
\caption{Signal to background ratio as a function of BDT output bin. [606]
The red and blue histograms show the distribution after applying step 1 of the binning procedure before [623]
and after smoothing respectively. The black vertical lines indicate the boundaries of the final [637]
binning choice from the full procedure.} [643]
\label{fig:binningscheme} [643]
\end{figure} [643]
[643]
[643]
\subsection{Background Model} [2]
\label{sec:backgroundmodel} [2]
[2]
The SM background is expected to have a smoothly varying invariant mass spectrum. [15]
However, detector effects such as selection, trigger efficiencies and energy resolution [26]
shape this distribution in ways which are imperfectly modelled in MC simulation. [38]
Moreover, the background contains fakes whose contribution varies as a function of $\mgg$. [51]
This means the exact composition of the background is needed to model the shape with MC. [67]
In order to remove the impact of systematic uncertainties associated with this, an entirely data-driven [82]
approach for modelling the background is used. [89]
[89]
For a given mass hypothesis, the shape and normalization of the background model are obtained separately. [105]
The shape, meaning the fraction of events in each BDT output bin, is extracted [119]
from the BDT output distributions in mass-sidebands, while the overall normalization is obtained [132]
from a parametric fit to the mass distribution for all selected events excluding the signal region. [148]
[148]
Figure~\ref{fig:fullmassspec} shows the invariant mass distribution after event selection in the range [160]
$100 < \mgg < 180$ GeV for the full 2011 dataset. The red band indicates the signal region for [175]
$\mh=124$ GeV, while the six blue bands indicate the corresponding sidebands used to determine the shape [191]
of the background model. [195]
The blue line indicates the fit of a sum of two power laws which is used to determine the normalisation of the [217]
background in the signal region. [222]
[222]
\begin{figure} [222]
\begin{center} [222]
 \includegraphics[width=.8\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/fits/massfit.pdf} [222]
\end{center} [222]
\caption{Invariant mass distribution of the full 2011 dataset after selection over the mass range used in [238]
the analysis (100 to 180 GeV). The $\pm 2\%$ signal region for $\mh=124$ GeV is indicated in red, while the six [258]
corresponding sidebands are indicated as blue bands. The blue line is the double power law fit to the data for [278]
the background normalisation for this mass hypothesis.} [285]
\label{fig:fullmassspec} [285]
\end{figure} [285]
[285]
\subsubsection{Obtaining the Normalisation of the Background} [291]
\label{sec:backgroundnormalisation} [291]
[291]
The normalisation of the background model is estimated using an un-binned maximum likelihood fit of [306]
a parametric function to the diphoton invariant mass distribution in the range $100 < \mgg < 180$ GeV. [320]
The normalisation [322]
of the background model is given by the integral of the function over the $\pm2\%$ signal region [339]
for each mass hypothesis. The  signal region is excluded from the fit to avoid potential bias in the [357]
presence of a signal. [361]
[361]
The particular parameterization used was chosen following a study of different parametric forms which also provide a good [379]
fit to the data. Since the actual functional form is unknown, the choice of parameterization is taken to be [398]
that which minimises the total uncertainty when comparing to the other functional forms. [411]
Twelve different functional forms were considered, which can be grouped into four general classes: [425]
exponentials, power laws, real Laurent polynomials and standard polynomials. Within each of these [438]
classes, three functions were used. For the exponentials and power law cases, these were sums [453]
of one, two or three exponential or power law ($\mgg^{-r}$) terms, while only first, third and fifth order [471]
standard polynomials were used. [475]
For the Laurent polynomials, the functions were sums of two, four or six terms, specifically [490]
\begin{eqnarray*} [490]
\mgg^{-4}+a\mgg^{-5},\\ [491]
\mgg^{-4}+a\mgg^{-5}+b\mgg^{-3}+c\mgg^{-6},\\ [491]
\mgg^{-4}+a\mgg^{-5}+b\mgg^{-3}+c\mgg^{-6}+d\mgg^{-2}+f\mgg^{-7}. [491]
\end{eqnarray*} [491]
For each class therefore, the three functions have one, three or five parameters for the shape. [507]
[507]
To asses the bias introduced through choosing one particular parameterisation, pseudo-experiments are [519]
generated from each functional form and the invariant mass of those experiments are [532]
fit with the other functional forms. The parameters for generation of the pseudo-experiments are [546]
fixed by fitting each functional form to the data in the full mass range. [560]
In each pseudo-experiment, the integral of a particular fitting function, A, over the signal region is [576]
compared to that from a generating function, B. The distribution of the difference between the two values [593]
across all of the pseudo-experiments is used to determine the bias introduced from choosing function A when B was the true function. [615]
The distributions are then weighted according to the probability of the initial fit to the data [631]
and combined so that the total uncertainty from choosing a particular function is computed as the RMS from [649]
zero of the weighted summed distributions for all generating functions. Since one of the generating functions [665]
can also be the fitting function, the error includes both the statistical uncertainty from the limited data sample [683]
and the systematic uncertainty due to an incorrect choice of parameterisation. [694]
This study is repeated at 5 GeV intervals in $m_{H}$ as the overall uncertainty varies as a function of [713]
mass hypothesis. Figure~\ref{fig:totalerrorallfunc} shows the total error determined for each of the twelve functions [727]
at each value of $m_{H}$ tested. The sum of two power laws was found to give a low total uncertainty while also demonstrating [750]
good fit stability in the pseudo-experiments. The total error on the background normalisation [763]
is included as a single systematic uncertainty for the purpose of signal extraction [776]
(Section~\ref{sec:statisticalinterpretations}). [777]
[777]
\begin{figure} [777]
\begin{center} [777]
 \includegraphics[width=.8\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/fits/totalErrors} [777]
\end{center} [777]
\caption{Total error on the background normalisation as a function of $m_{H}$ from different choices of the [793]
background shape parameterisation of $\mgg$. The total error for the one-parameter exponential and polynomial functions are off the scale of this plot.} [815]
\label{fig:totalerrorallfunc} [815]
\end{figure} [815]
[815]
[815]
\subsubsection{Obtaining the Shape of the Background} [821]
\label{sec:backgroundshape} [821]
[821]
As the signal yield expected from a SM Higgs boson is small compared to the background, [837]
the sensitivity of the search is strongly dependant on how well the relative contribution [851]
from the background in each bin is understood. [859]
Both inputs to the BDT are designed to be insensitive to the invariant mass of the diphoton system, [877]
therefore the BDT output distribution should be the same for any region of the $\mgg$ spectrum. [893]
Since the background composition remains relatively constant across the range 100 to 180 GeV, [907]
data in sidebands of $\mgg$, away from the signal, can be defined to determine the [922]
distribution of the background inside the signal region. For a particular $\mh$, a contiguous [936]
set of lower/upper sidebands are defined to be the ranges $|\dmomsb| < w$ [948]
centered on $\mhsb$ as given in Equation~\ref{eqn:sbdefsu} where $w=0.02$. [957]
\begin{eqnarray} [957]
\mhsb = \mh \left( \frac {\displaystyle 1-w }{1+w} \right)^{i} [958]
\label{eqn:sbdefsu} [958]
\end{eqnarray} [958]
The two sidebands adjacent to the signal window [966]
(corresponding to $i=\pm1$ in Equation~\ref{eqn:sbdefsu}) are not used in order [976]
to avoid signal contamination. Dijet tagged events are treated in the same way as the rest of the events by introducing an eighth bin [1000]
containing dijet tagged events inside the range $\dmom < w$. [1008]
The distributions for the two input variables, diphoton BDT output and $\dmom$, [1020]
for each of the six sidebands corresponding to $\mh=125$ are [1030]
shown in Figure~\ref{fig:datasidebandsinput}. Each distribution is normalised to unit area. The [1041]
resulting BDT output distributions are shown in Figure~\ref{fig:datasidebandsoutput}. [1049]
The distributions from each sideband are not distinguishable within the statistical [1060]
uncertainties. [1061]
[1061]
\begin{figure} [1061]
\begin{center} [1061]
 \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/datasidebands_diphobdt} [1061]
  \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/datasidebands_dmom}\\ [1061]
\end{center} [1061]
\caption{Distribution in data from the six sidebands corresponding to $\mh=125$ GeV of the two BDT [1076]
input variables, diphoton BDT (left) and $\dmom$ (right).} [1084]
\label{fig:datasidebandsinput} [1084]
\end{figure} [1084]
\begin{figure} [1084]
\begin{center} [1084]
 \includegraphics[width=.8\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/datasidebands_finalbdt} [1084]
\end{center} [1084]
\caption{Distribution in data from the six sidebands corresponding to $\mh=125$ GeV of the BDT output [1099]
binned in the 7 BDT output bins used for signal extraction.} [1110]
\label{fig:datasidebandsoutput} [1110]
\end{figure} [1110]
[1110]
The residual variation in BDT output is due to the small variation in background composition with mass. [1127]
This is mostly due to the photon ID BDT distribution being sensitive to the fake component which [1144]
varies with mass. In order to account for this variation, the background model is constructed using [1160]
a simultaneous linear fit to the BDT output shape in the data sidebands. [1173]
The expected fraction of events in each bin, $f_{j}$, for a given mass hypothesis, $\mhsb$, is given [1190]
by Equation~\ref{eqn:sbfitdef}, where [1193]
$j\epsilon\{1,8\}$ and $i\epsilon\{\cdots,-4,-3,-2,2,3,4\cdots\}$. [1196]
\begin{equation} [1196]
f_{j} = p_{0,j} + p_{1,j}(\mhsb - \mh) [1197]
\label{eqn:sbfitdef} [1197]
\end{equation} [1197]
Since the normalisation for the background model is determined independently, [1207]
the sum over all bins is constrained to be one. [1217]
The expectation value for the background in each bin, $j$, is then determined as $Nf_{j}$ where $N$ is the [1236]
normalisation estimated in section~\ref{sec:backgroundnormalisation}. [1240]
This constraint is imposed for all $\mhsb$ by fixing [1249]
\begin{eqnarray} [1249]
p_{0,1} = 1-\sum_{i=2}^{8} p_{0,j} &&  p_{1,1} = - \sum_{j=2}^{8}p_{1,j} [1250]
\end{eqnarray} [1250]
The coefficients $p_{0,j},p_{1,j}$ of Equation~\ref{eqn:sbfitdef} are determined by performing a binned [1261]
maximum likelihood fit to the observed fractions in the data assuming the contents of each bin in each [1279]
sideband are Poisson distributed. The results of the fit for $\mh=124$ GeV are shown in [1294]
Figure~\ref{fig:examplesbfits} and the resulting covariance matrix obtained is shown in [1304]
Figure~\ref{fig:covariance}. [1305]
The fit was performed using \texttt{TMinuit} under \texttt{ROOT 5.2.0}~\citep{minuit}. [1314]
[1314]
\begin{figure} [1314]
\begin{center} [1314]
 \includegraphics[width=0.46\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/fits/m124_bg_bdt_bin_1} [1314]
  \includegraphics[width=0.46\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/fits/m124_bg_bdt_bin_2}\\ [1314]
 \includegraphics[width=0.46\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/fits/m124_bg_bdt_bin_3} [1314]
  \includegraphics[width=0.46\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/fits/m124_bg_bdt_bin_4}\\ [1314]
 \includegraphics[width=0.46\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/fits/m124_bg_bdt_bin_5} [1314]
  \includegraphics[width=0.46\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/fits/m124_bg_bdt_bin_6}\\ [1314]
 \includegraphics[width=0.46\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/fits/m124_bg_bdt_bin_7} [1314]
  \includegraphics[width=0.46\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/fits/m124_bg_bdt_bin_8} [1314]
\end{center} [1314]
\caption{Simultaneous fits to the six sidebands in data to determine the background shape for [1328]
$\mh=124$ GeV. There are eight panels showing the result in each of the seven BDT bins plus one for [1347]
the dijet tagged bin. The six black points in each panel are the fractional populations [1362]
of the data in each sideband. The blue line represents the linear fit used to determine the fraction [1380]
of background in each bin.} [1385]
\label{fig:examplesbfits} [1385]
\end{figure} [1385]
[1385]
\begin{figure} [1385]
\begin{center} [1385]
 \includegraphics[width=.8\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/fits/covariance_m124} [1385]
\end{center} [1385]
\caption{Covariance matrix from the sideband fit to determine the background shape at [1397]
$\mh=124$ GeV. The covariance matrix includes the additional 20\% systematic attributed to possible second [1411]
order variations in the BDT output background distribution with mass.} [1421]
\label{fig:covariance} [1421]
\end{figure} [1421]
[1421]
There are seven degrees of freedom (eight bins minus one constraint) which are correlated in the simultaneous fit. [1439]
In order to account for the statistical uncertainty on this fit, a set of seven uncorrelated variables [1456]
are determined from the covariance matrix using eigenvector decomposition~\citep{pca}. These variables [1467]
are treated as seven independent sources of systematic uncertainty on the background shape [1480]
for the purpose of signal extraction (Section~\ref{sec:statisticalinterpretations}). [1487]
Figure~\ref{fig:relativefiterrorvsnsidebands} shows the total relative fit error for each bin, [1497]
at $\mh=130$ GeV, as the number of [1504]
sidebands, is varied. [1507]
Increasing the number of sidebands beyond six, three on each side of the signal region, [1522]
provides negligible reduction in the statistical uncertainty. [1529]
In order to avoid contamination from $\Zee$ at the lower mass hypotheses [1541]
any lower sideband whose lower boundary is less that 100 GeV is removed and an additional higher [1558]
sideband is introduced. Consequently mass hypotheses in the range $111 \le \mh < 115.5$ have [1569]
two lower and four upper sidebands and mass hypotheses in the range $110 \le \mh < 111$ have [1583]
one lower and five upper sidebands. [1589]
[1589]
\begin{figure} [1589]
\begin{center} [1589]
 \includegraphics[width=.8\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/fits/fracErrorvsNsidebands.pdf} [1589]
\end{center} [1589]
\caption{Relative total fit uncertainty on the background model in each bin at $\mh=130$ GeV as a function of the [1608]
number of sidebands used in the fit to determine the shape of the background.} [1622]
\label{fig:relativefiterrorvsnsidebands} [1622]
\end{figure} [1622]
[1622]
At most linear variations with mass are considered for the background BDT output distribution. [1636]
This corresponds to evaluating the first term in a Taylor series for the true shape of the distribution [1654]
about $\mh$. Higher terms can be introduced but the statistical precision of the fit will be reduced in [1672]
doing so. To check for potential significant deviations in the data from linearity, pseudo-experiments [1686]
were generated in which the expected fractions, $f_{i}$ are assumed to follow, [1698]
\begin{equation} [1698]
f_{j} = p_{0,j} + p_{1,j}(\mhsb - \mh) + \frac{\displaystyle 1}{\displaystyle 2} p_{2,j}(\mhsb-\mh)^{2}. [1699]
\label{eqn:sbfitdefho} [1699]
\end{equation} [1699]
The parameter values, $p_{0,j},p_{1,j}$ and $p_{2,j}$ and their uncertainties were determined [1710]
by fitting over a larger [1715]
number of sidebands for a particular mass hypothesis. This is done by extending the range of $j$ to allow [1734]
any sideband which is contained inside the range $100 < \mgg < 180$ GeV. For most mass hypotheses, this [1749]
corresponds to fifteen sidebands in total. For each pseudo-experiment, the parameters were varied [1762]
within their uncertainties (accounting for correlations) thereby systematically altering the expectation [1773]
value for the number of events in each bin before generating a Poisson toy for the observed number of [1792]
events per bin in each sideband. The usual linear fit is then performed and the fraction of events in each [1812]
bin for the signal region is extracted and compared to the true generating fraction. The difference between these [1830]
two values can be used to determine the total error under the assumption [1843]
that a second term in the Taylor expansion is present in the data. This error is taken as the root mean square [1865]
(RMS) around zero [1868]
of the difference between the true and fitted values for $f_{i}$ in 10,000 pseudo-experiments. When compared [1885]
to the error from the linear fits, it was found that the total uncertainty was covered by inflating [1903]
the errors systematically by 20\%. The value of 20\% is a conservative choice being the largest value [1920]
found when repeating the study over a range of mass hypotheses. [1931]
[1931]
\subsection{Signal Model} [2]
\label{sec:signalmodel} [2]
[2]
The signal model for the Higgs boson decay to two photons at a given mass is constructed by [20]
binning the BDT response from MC simulation of the four production processes, $ggH$, $qqH$, $VH$ and $ttH$. [37]
The simulation is corrected using auxiliary [43]
measurements from $\Zee$ events in data to account for imperfect modeling of the detector. [57]
These corrections are applied to the Monte Carlo event by event and can be categorized into [73]
photon and diphoton level corrections. [78]
[78]
\subsubsection{Photon Level Corrections} [81]
The energy resolution of the calorimeter is measured in data using $\Zee$ events in [95]
categories defined by the position and $\rnine$ of the supercluster. [105]
Photons in the central region of the detector [113]
with $\rnine > 0.94$ are further divided into those whose supercluster seed lies close to a module [128]
boundary and those whose does not. [134]
The additional energy smearing required for the Monte Carlo in each category is determined [148]
by smearing $\Zee$ MC until the $e^{+} e^{−}$ invariant mass distribution matches that [160]
of the data. [163]
This additional resolution is included in the Higgs MC by scaling the energy of each photon by [180]
$G(1,\sigma_{cat})$ where $G$ is a Gaussian distributed random variable centered [190]
at 1, and $\sigma_{cat}$ is the additional resolution required to match the data in a particular category. [207]
The exact definitions of the photon-level categories and the additional resolution measured in each category [222]
are given in Table~\ref{tab:eres2011}. [226]
[226]
The efficiency for a photon to pass the pre-selection is measured in $\Zee$ data in four categories. [243]
These are defined by whether or not the supercluster is in the ECAL barrel or either endcap and the value [263]
of $\rnine$ being greater or less than 0.94. [271]
The ratio of the efficiency measured in data to that measured in MC provides a scale factor which is [290]
applied to the signal MC. Each signal event is reweighted by the product of the scale factors [307]
for each photon in the selected diphoton pair. In addition to these corrections, the value of $\sigma_{E}$ and the photon ID BDT for each photon is [333]
shifted in each signal event to account for imperfections in detector simulations as described in [348]
Section~\ref{sec:diphotonbdt}. [349]
[349]
\subsubsection{Diphoton Level Corrections} [352]
The efficiency to select the correct vertex in the event is measured using $\Zmumu$ events as a [369]
function of the boson $p_{T}$ as described in Section~\ref{sec:vertexselection}. [378]
Signal MC events are categorized by whether or not the [388]
selected vertex is within 10mm of the generated vertex. Each event is then re-weighted by [403]
the ratio of the probability that the event lies in a particular category [416]
as measured in $\Zmumu$ data ($\epsilon_{data}$) to that measured in $\Zmumu$ MC ($\epsilon_{MC}$). Figure~\ref{fig:vtxprobreweight} [430]
shows the weight, $\epsilon_{data}/\epsilon_{MC}$, applied to events in the signal MC in which the correct vertex is selected [448]
as a function of the Higgs boson candidate $\pt$ ($\pth$). Similarly, events in which this is not [465]
the case are reweighted by the ratio  $(1-\epsilon_{data})/(1-\epsilon_{MC})$. [473]
The L1/HLT efficiency is measured in four diphoton categories depending on the maximum [487]
supercluster $\eta$ and minimum $\rnine$ value of the two photons using $\Zee$ data. [500]
As the simulation does not include the trigger, the efficiency is applied [512]
directly as a weight to each MC event. [520]
[520]
\begin{figure} [520]
\includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/generalPlots/vtxReweight.pdf} [520]
\caption{Re-weighting applied to signal MC in which the $z$ position of the selected vertex [534]
is within 10mm of the true vertex as a function of $\pth$. The weights are derived from $\Zmumu$ events [553]
in data and MC.} [557]
\label{fig:vtxprobreweight} [557]
\end{figure} [557]
[557]
\subsubsection{Systematic Uncertainties} [559]
[559]
For each correction applied to the MC, the accuracy to which that correction [572]
is measured provides an estimate of the uncertainty present in the signal model. [585]
In the case of the energy scale measurement, no correction is applied to the MC although the [602]
uncertainty in that measurement is treated as a systematic on the per-photon energy in signal MC events. [619]
The systematic uncertainties that affect the shape of the signal are treated as correlated  [633]
migrations across the BDT output bins. The effect of each systematic in each [646]
bin is derived by shifting the relevant quantity in the signal MC and recalculating the BDT output for each event. [666]
The difference between the signal yield in each bin after applying the shift quantifies the variation due to that uncertainty. [686]
In practise, these quantities are derived by applying shifts to the MC corresponding to $3\sigma$ variations [702]
of each uncertainty and interpolating the difference from the nominal values back to the $1\sigma$ level. [718]
This is done so that the evaluation of the variation in each bin is more robust for systematics which [737]
have a small effect on the BDT output and in signal processes with fewer available MC events. [754]
Figure~\ref{fig:signalmodel_escaleres} shows the effect of the energy scale and resolution uncertainties [765]
on the BDT output of signal from gluon-gluon fusion production. [775]
[775]
\begin{figure} [775]
\begin{center} [775]
 \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/signalModel/systematic_interpolation_test_E_scale.pdf} [775]
  \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/signalModel/systematic_interpolation_test_E_res.pdf} [775]
  \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/signalModel/systematic_interpolation_test_curves_E_scale.pdf} [775]
  \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/signalModel/systematic_interpolation_test_curves_E_res.pdf} [775]
\end{center} [775]
\caption{Top: Energy scale (left) and resolution (right) uncertainties in the $ggH$ signal model. [788]
The effect of $\pm3\sigma$ variations [793]
derived in MC are shown with red dashed lines while the interpolated $\pm3\sigma$ are shown with blue. [810]
Bottom: Variation in bin content at different quantiles (number of standard deviations from the nominal) for the [827]
three highest $S/B$ BDT bins. [832]
The blue and red markers indicate the yields extracted directly from MC while the black line indicates the [850]
quadratic interpolation function used to derive the $\pm1\sigma$ variations for the signal model.} [863]
\label{fig:signalmodel_escaleres} [863]
\end{figure} [863]
[863]
Imperfections in the simulation of the shower shape variables can cause discrepancies in the photon [878]
ID and $\sigma_{E}$ distributions obtained from the respective BDTs between data and MC. To account for this, [895]
systematic uncertainties are included corresponding to shifting or scaling the output of the photon ID BDT [911]
and regression BDT respectively and recalculating the BDT output for each event in signal MC. The size [928]
of the uncertainty is chosen to be that which covers the maximal difference in the ratio of each [946]
distribution for high $\pt$ photons. This is then validated using $\Zee$ events in which the [961]
electrons are reconstructed as photons. [966]
The overall efficiency$\times$acceptance after applying [973]
these scale factors is shown as a function of $\mh$ in Figure~\ref{fig:effacc}. [985]
\begin{figure} [985]
\includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/generalPlots/effAcc_vs_mass.pdf} [985]
\caption{Efficiency$\times$acceptance for a SM Higgs boson as a function of its mass ($\mh$) after [1001]
applying all of the corrections to the MC. The blue bands indicate the error from each source of [1019]
systematic uncertainty on the signal model summed in quadrature.} [1028]
\label{fig:effacc} [1028]
\end{figure} [1028]
Due to the large variations observed when using different underlying event parton showering (UEPS) models [1043]
for the two dominant production processes, systematics of 70\% and 10\% are included as the uncertainty [1059]
in the fraction of gluon-gluon fusion and vector boson fusion events respectively which [1072]
are expected to pass the dijet tag~\citep{HIG-11-033}. [1079]
In addition to the shape systematics, theoretical errors on the SM Higgs boson cross-section are [1094]
included due to uncertainties on the QCD scale and pdf variations of the various [1108]
production modes~\citep{lhcxswg}. A 2.2\% luminosity error is also included as an uncertainty [1120]
on the overall signal yield. [1125]
A complete list of the systematics included in the signal model is given in Table~\ref{tab:sigsystematics}. [1140]
[1140]
