\subsubsection{Interpolation to Intermediate Mass Points} [1178]
[1178]
Signal Monte Carlo is available in $\mh$ steps of 5 GeV in the range of 110 to 150 GeV. [1197]
Due to the excellent resolution in the $\Hgg$ channel, it is necessary to interpolate [1211]
between these generated mass points to construct the signal model at intermediate masses. [1224]
As a result of selecting BDT input variables that are largely independent of the mass, the BDT output distribution in signal [1245]
varies slowly and smoothly with $\mh$. This allows for construction of the BDT output signal distribution at an [1263]
intermediate mass point by performing a bin by bin vertical interpolation between the distributions [1277]
from MC at neighboring mass hypotheses. [1283]
The interpolation is performed separately for each signal production mode. [1293]
The normalization at intermediate points is defined [1300]
as the cross section times branching ratio, which is known for any $\mh$, [1313]
for the intermediate mass multiplied by a linear interpolation of the acceptance times efficiency. [1327]
A closure test on the interpolation procedure [1334]
was performed by comparing the efficiency times acceptance per bin at $\mh=135$ with one derived from [1350]
gluon-gluon fusion MC generated with $\mh=130$ and $\mh=140$ GeV (Figure~\ref{fig:siginterptest}). [1360]
The closure test shows good agreement between the distributions; [1369]
residual differences are negligible compared with the other systematics included in the signal model. [1383]
[1383]
\begin{figure} [1383]
\begin{center} [1383]
 \includegraphics[width=.8\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/signalModel/sigInterpTest135.pdf} [1383]
\end{center} [1383]
  \caption{Closure test for signal interpolation to intermediate mass points. The solid grey histogram [1396]
  is the result of a linear interpolation between the efficiency$\times$acceptance in each bin of the [1413]
  blue ($\mh=130$ GeV) and red ($\mh=140$ GeV) histograms. The efficiency$\times$acceptance from $ggH$ MC [1428]
  generated with mass 135 GeV is shown in black for comparison.} [1439]
 \label{fig:siginterptest} [1439]
\end{figure} [1439]
[1439]
\subsubsection{Validation with $\Zee$ data} [1443]
As with the other MVA discriminators in the $\Hgg$ analysis, the signal model is validated by running the BDT [1462]
on both $\Zee$ MC and data with the electron veto inverted. A comparison of the data and MC is shown in [1483]
Figure~\ref{fig:zeebdtoutput}. [1484]
Although the BDT output shape is not expected to be  [1494]
the same for $\Zee$ events as for $\Hgg$ events, the agreement seen between data and MC for $\Zee$ [1512]
events indicates that the reconstruction and kinematics of a potential signal in data will be well [1528]
modelled in the signal MC. [1533]
[1533]
\begin{figure} [1533]
\begin{center} [1533]
 \includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/zeeValidation/zeebdtoutput.pdf} [1533]
\end{center} [1533]
\caption{BDT output distribution for $\Zee$ events in data and MC (left). [1544]
Data/MC ratio for the BDT output distribution (right). The variation in MC due to [1559]
the largest systematic uncertainties included in the signal model are shown for comparison.} [1572]
\label{fig:zeebdtoutput} [1572]
\end{figure} [1572]
[1572]
\subsection{Likelihood Model for Signal Extraction} [5]
\label{sec:statisticalinterpretations} [5]
[5]
The $\Hgg$ analysis was performed on the full 2011 dataset collected at CMS [18]
corresponding to \clumi of proton-proton collision data at a centre of mass energy of 7 TeV. [33]
Figure~\ref{fig:results7TeV} shows the observed number of events in data in each BDT output bin and from the [50]
dijet tagged events in the $\pm 2\%$ signal region centered on $\mh=$125 GeV. The background model described in [68]
section~\ref{sec:backgroundmodel} is shown in blue with the $\pm1/2\sigma$ uncertainties represented by the coloured bands. [82]
The expected contribution from a SM Higgs boson with a mass of 125 GeV is shown in red. [100]
The full set of distributions for all mass hypotheses tested can be found online~\citep{onlineresults}. [114]
The signal to background ratio increases with higher BDT bin number, as shown in Figure~\ref{fig:results7TeV_soverb}, [129]
making the higher BDT bins more sensitive. [136]
The ratio is highest in the dijet tagged bin due to the additional suppression of the background by requiring two [156]
$qqH$ jets. [158]
[158]
\begin{figure} [158]
\begin{center} [158]
 \includegraphics[width=.8\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/hgg_MassWindow_model_m125.pdf} [158]
  %\includegraphics[width=.48\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/model_m145.pdf} [158]
\end{center} [158]
\caption{Observed number of events in data for each of the seven BDT bins and dijet bin [174]
at $\mh=125$ GeV. The background model is shown in blue along with the maximal $\pm 1/2\sigma$ variations. [190]
The expected contribution from a SM Higgs boson is shown in red~\citep{HIG-12-036}.} [202]
\label{fig:results7TeV} [202]
\end{figure} [202]
\begin{figure} [202]
\begin{center} [202]
 \includegraphics[width=.8\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/soverb_m125.pdf} [202]
  %\includegraphics[width=.48\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/model_m145.pdf} [202]
\end{center} [202]
\caption{Signal to background ratio in each of the seven BDT bins and dijet bin at $\mh=125$ GeV. [219]
The expected background is taken from the data-driven model described in Section~\ref{sec:backgroundmodel}. [231]
The error bars represent the uncertainty in the ratio due to the uncertainties in the background model.} [248]
\label{fig:results7TeV_soverb} [248]
\end{figure} [248]
[248]
For the purposes of signal extraction, the analysis can be expressed in the form of a simple [265]
combination of counting experiments. The [270]
likelihood function (Equation~\ref{eqn:likelihoodhggbdt}) is proportional to a product of Poisson terms [281]
and parameterises the relative compatibility of the data with the signal and background models [295]
as a function of the signal strength $\mu$. [303]
The systematic uncertainties are included via the parameters [311]
${\boldth}=({\boldth}^{s},\boldth^{b})$ (nuisance parameters) and $p$ is a product of unit [321]
width Gaussian distributions centered at $\boldth$. [327]
\begin{equation} [327]
\mathcal{L} ( \mathrm{data} | \mu,\boldth ) = [328]
p(\boldthmeas|{\boldth}) [328]
\cdot \prod_{j=1}^{8} \mathrm{Poisson}\left( d_{j} | \mu \sum_{p}s^{p}_{j}(\boldth) + b_{j}(\boldth) \right ) [328]
\label{eqn:likelihoodhggbdt} [328]
\end{equation} [328]
The observed number of events in each bin, $d_{j}$, [337]
and expected contributions from each signal production process  and [346]
background, $s^{p}_{j}$ ( $p \varepsilon \left\{ ggH,qqH,VH,ttH \right\}$ ) and $b_{j}$, [351]
correspond to one mass hypothesis [356]
although the general form is applicable to all values of $\mh$. [367]
[367]
To avoid cases in which the expectations for the contents of each bin become negative, the effect [384]
of each systematic on the signal or background is modelled using log-normal distributions. [397]
In this analysis, each systematic affects either the signal model or the background model. [411]
The functions $s_{i}({\boldth^{s}})$ and $b_{i}({\boldth^{b}})$ are given by [419]
Equations~\ref{eqn:slh} and~\ref{eqn:blh} respectively where [423]
$ \boldth^{s}$ %= \left( \theta^{k} \right ) $ [424]
represents the nuisance parameters of the signal model and [433]
$\boldth^{b}=\left( \theta_{N},\theta^{b}_{1}\ldots\theta^{b}_{7} \right)$ [434]
represent the eight independent nuisances of the background model. [443]
\begin{equation} [443]
s_{j}({\theta}^{s})  =  s_{j}^{p,mc} \cdot \prod_{k} \left(1+\frac{\displaystyle \sigma^{s,p}_{k} }{\displaystyle s_{j}^{p,mc}}\right)^{\theta^{s}_{k}} [444]
\label{eqn:slh} [444]
\end{equation} [444]
\begin{equation} [444]
b_{j}({\theta^{b}}) = N\left(1+\frac{\displaystyle \sigma_{N}}{\displaystyle N}\right)^{\theta^{b}_{N}} \cdot f_{j} [445]
\prod_{k=1}^{7} \left(1+\frac{\displaystyle \sqrt{\lambda_{k}}V_{kj} }{ \displaystyle f_{j}}\right)^{\theta^{b}_{k}} [445]
\label{eqn:blh} [445]
\end{equation} [445]
The values $s_{j}^{p,MC}$ in Equation~\ref{eqn:slh} are the expected values for the signal from [458]
each of the four Higgs boson production processes ($ggH,qqH,wzH,ttH$) [467]
derived from the signal MC taking all MC to data corrections into account. The values of $\sigma_{k}^{s,p}$ [484]
are the correlated bin uncertainties of the signal model due to each independent source of uncertainty [500]
calculated using the quadratic interpolation described in Section~\ref{sec:signalmodel}. [508]
In practise, $\sigma_{k}^{s,p}$ has two values, one corresponding to positive values of $\theta^{s}_{k}$ [521]
and one for negative values. This is to account for asymmetric variations caused by uncertainties [536]
in the signal model such as that due to the energy scale. [548]
The values $V_{kj}$ and $\lambda_{k}$ in Equation~\ref{eqn:blh} are the eigenvectors [558]
and corresponding eigenvalues of the covariance matrix determined in Section~\ref{sec:backgroundshape}. [568]
Finally, $\sigma_{N}$ is the uncertainty on the background normalisation. [577]
This likelihood can be used as a statistical model of the data for the purpose of hypothesis testing, setting limits and quantifying excesses observed in the data. [604]
[604]
[604]

File: ./statistics/statistics.tex

\chapter{Statistical Interpretations of the Data} [5]
\label{chap:statistics} [5]
[5]
When searching for new physics it is often desirable to do so in the context of [21]
some specific theoretical model or well motivated benchmark scenario. [30]
Where the theory provides well defined predictions, [37]
experimental data can be used to verify or reject the theory [48]
by means of hypothesis testing. This chapter describes the frequentist statistical procedures [60]
employed at CMS to perform these tests and provide quantitative, statistical interpretations  [72]
of the data. In Section~\ref{sec:hypothesistesting}, an overview is given on the procedure by [85]
which $p$-values are calculated to test the compatibility of the data with a given [100]
hypothesis and the $CL_{s}$ technique for setting exclusion limits is introduced. [111]
The results of applying these procedures to the $\Hgg$ analysis described in Chapter~\ref{chap:hgg} [124]
are given in Section~\ref{sec:hggresults2011} including updates for the 8 TeV using data taken [137]
in 2012 up to the ICHEP conference that year. [146]
[146]
[146]
\section{Hypothesis Testing} [2]
\label{sec:hypothesistesting} [2]
[2]
The goal is to use the data [9]
to reject one of two hypotheses, [15]
$H_{0}$ and $H_{1}$, known as the null and alternate hypotheses [25]
respectively. A function is defined, $t(data)$, [31]
which characterises the observed data as a single real value. When rejecting [43]
the hypothesis, $H_{0}$, the critical [48]
region, $w$, is defined as the set of possible values of $t$ [60]
which indicate that $H_{0}$ is not true. The probability then [70]
to observe $t\in w$ when $H_{0}$ is true ($\alpha$), [78]
\begin{equation} [78]
\alpha = P(t\in w|H_{0}) [79]
\end{equation} [79]
is the probability that $H_{0}$ would be rejected even if it was true. [92]
The strength of a test (referred to as its power) is quantified by [105]
the probability, $1-\beta$ that $t \in w$ when $H_{1}$ is true. [114]
\begin{equation} [114]
1-\beta = P(t\in w|H_{1}) [115]
\end{equation} [115]
In the case of the search of the SM Higgs boson, the two hypotheses [129]
can be parameterised in terms of a production cross-section relative [139]
to that predicted by the SM, $\xs$.  [146]
The null hypothesis ($H_{0}$) is then that under which no SM Higgs boson exits, [160]
$\xs=0$, while the alternate ($H_{1}$) is characterized by $\xs=1$. [169]
In this case, $H_{0}$ is referred to as the background-only hypothesis [180]
and $H_{1}$ the signal-plus-background hypothesis. [185]
The possible outcomes of $t$ are assumed to be random with a probability density [199]
function (pdf) $f_{\xs}(t)$. The values of $\alpha$ and $1-\beta$ are the integral of the pdfs [214]
over the critical region; [218]
\begin{eqnarray} [218]
1-\beta =  \int_{w}f_{1}(t)dt\\ [219]
\alpha =  \int_{w}f_{0}(t)dt. [219]
\label{eqn:alpha} [219]
\end{eqnarray} [219]
It can be shown that the choice of $w$ which maximises the power of the test for [236]
a given value of $\alpha$ are the set of points for which, [248]
\begin{equation} [248]
q = \frac {\displaystyle f_{1}(t)}{\displaystyle f_{0}(t)} \ge c_{\alpha}, [249]
\label{eqn:bestw} [249]
\end{equation} [249]
where $c_{\alpha}$ is chosen such that Equation~\ref{eqn:alpha} holds~\citep{statsbook}. [257]
In the search for the SM Higgs boson, the compatibility of the data [270]
with the presence of a Higgs boson is interpreted in terms of the [283]
continuous parameter, $\mu$, which scales the signal strength relative to that expected [295]
from the Standard Model. [299]
Again, the null hypothesis, $H_{0}$, is characterized by setting $\mu=0$ however, [310]
an infinite number of alternate hypotheses exist for any value $\mu \ge 0$. [321]
The likelihood , $\call(t|\mu)$, is defined as a function of $\mu$ for a fixed [334]
realisation of the data and related to each pdf by a constant of proportionality. [348]
The quantity $q$ in Equation~\ref{eqn:bestw}, known as the ``test-statistic'', is then [359]
the ratio of the likelihood at the two values $\mu=1$ and $\mu=0$. [371]
[371]
The test-statistic for a given $\mu$ is defined as the ratio [382]
of likelihoods, $q_{\mu}$, in which the values for the nuisance parameters are taken from fits to the data (profiled), [401]
as given in Equation~\ref{eqn:llr2}. [405]
\begin{equation} [405]
\qmu = [406]
\begin {cases} [406]
-2\ln\frac{\displaystyle \mathcal{L}(\mathrm{data} | \mu,\hat{\boldth}_{\mu})} [406]
{\displaystyle \mathcal{L}(\mathrm{data} | \muhat,\hat{\boldth})} [406]
  &  0 \le \muhat \le \mu \\ [406]
  0  &  \muhat < 0 [406]
\end{cases}. [406]
\label{eqn:llr2} [406]
\end{equation} [406]
The values $\hat{\boldth}_{\mu}$ and $\hat{\boldth}$ are the values of [415]
the nuisance parameters for which the likelihood attains its maximum [425]
given a particular value of $\mu$ and letting $\mu$ to float freely in the [439]
fit ($\mu=\muhat$). [441]
An immediate consequence of this definition is that the value attained [452]
by the test statistic is always positive. Small values of the test [464]
statistic indicate outcomes which are in favour of the signal-plus-background [474]
hypothesis, where large values indicate outcomes which disfavour it. [483]
Due to this, the critical region $w$ can always be defined as the right [497]
hand tail of the normalized distribution of the test-statistic $f(q_{\mu}|\mu)$, [507]
\begin{equation} [507]
w = \left\{ q_{\mu} : q_{mu} \in (c_{\alpha},+\infty) \right\}, [508]
%\label{eqn:llr2} [508]
\end{equation} [508]
Commonly the integral of $f(q_{\mu}|\mu)$ above the observed value of the [519]
test-statistic in data $(q_{\mu}^{obs})$, known as a $p$-value, is calculated [530]
to provide a measure of how much the data disfavour a particular value of $\mu$. [545]
[545]
\subsection{Exclusion Limits} [2]
An upper limit ($\mu_{up}$) can be determined for $\mu$ such that [13]
the hypotheses represented by the set $\left\{ \mu:\mu>\mu_{up} \right\}$ [20]
are nested (contained) within the hypothesis represented by $\xs=\mu=>\mu_{up}$. [29]
For the special case when $\mu_{up}=1$, the presence of a SM Higgs boson is excluded [44]
(at some confidence level $c\in(0,1)$) in favour of the background-only hypothesis. [55]
The constraint of $\muhat \le \mu$ is imposed in the chosen test-statistic, $q_{\mu}$,  [66]
when calculating upper limits which forces the limit on $\mu$ to be one-sided. [79]
At CMS, upper limits are determined using the $CL_{s}$ [88]
which is designed to provide less stringent exclusion limits in analyses [99]
which are less sensitive to signal~\citep{cls}. [105]
This procedure involves computing two $p$-values (tail probabilities) under two hypothesis, $\mu=0$ and $\mu\ne0$ given by, [122]
\begin{equation} [122]
CL_{s+b} = \int_{\qmu^{obs}}^{\infty} f(\qmu | \mu,\boldth=\boldth_{\mu}^{obs}) d\qmu [123]
\label{eqn:clsplusb} [123]
\end{equation} [123]
\begin{equation} [123]
CL_{b} = \int_{\qmu^{obs}}^{\infty} f(\qmu |0,\boldth=\boldth_{0}^{obs}) d\qmu, [124]
\label{eqn:clb} [124]
\end{equation} [124]
where $q_{\mu}^{obs}$ is the value of the test-statistic in data. [134]
The smallest value of $\mu$ for which the ratio $CL_{s}=\frac{\displaystyle CL_{s+b}}{\displaystyle CL_{b}}<\alpha$ is quoted as the upper limit on $\mu$ with confidence level [155]
$1-\alpha$. Typically, for exclusion, $\alpha$ is chosen as 0.05 so that [166]
when the upper limit on $\mu$ is less than one, all hypotheses of $\xs\ge1$ are excluded [182]
at the 95\% confidence level or more. In the search for a SM Higgs boson, this corresponds to excluding [201]
a SM Higgs boson with a particular mass $\mh$ hypothesis under which the likelihood is constructed. [217]
[217]
The distributions of the test-statistic, $\qmu$ under the two hypotheses are generated by [230]
throwing pseudo-experiments using the signal and background models such as those [241]
derived in Section~\ref{sec:signalextraction}. [244]
First, the values of $\boldth^{obs}_{\mu}$ and $\boldth^{obs}_{0}$ are set by fitting the likelihood [257]
to the observed data at a particular value of $\mu$ and for $\mu=0$ respectively. Pseudo-data, $d_{j}$, for each bin [276]
are generated according to a Poisson distribution with expectation value [286]
$\mu s_{j}(\boldth_{\mu}^{obs})+b_{j}(\boldth_{\mu}^{obs})$. Pseudo-measurements for each nuisance parameter, [292]
$\boldthmeas$, are then regenerated before evaluating the [299]
test-statistic $q_{\mu}$ in order to model the effect of systematic uncertainties. [310]
Examples of the normalised distributions of $\qmu$ for $\mu=0.6$ and $\mu=0$ are shown in [324]
Figure~\ref{fig:qmuexample}. [325]
[325]
\begin{figure} [325]
\begin{center} [325]
 \includegraphics[width=.8\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/statsPlots/qmu_example_130.pdf} [325]
\end{center} [325]
\caption{Distributions of the test statistic $\qmu$ under a background-only hypothesis [335]
($\mu=0$) and signal plus background hypothesis ($\mu=0.6$) for a SM Higgs boson of mass 130 GeV. [351]
The distributions are normalised to unit area. The observed value of the test statistic [365]
from data is indicated by the black arrow.} [373]
\label{fig:qmuexample} [373]
\end{figure} [373]
[373]
\subsection{Quantifying Excesses in the Observed Data} [6]
[6]
In the presence of a sizeable excess in data, the background-only hypothesis [18]
can be rejected in favour of an signal-plus-background like one. Specifically, in [30]
the search for the SM Higgs boson, the excess [39]
will be compatible with the presence of a SM Higgs boson up to the rate [54]
at which it is produced. This is due to the inclusion of the signal model [69]
in the definition of the likelihood which typically includes the shape of [81]
the expected signal in some discriminating variable and the relative populations [92]
expected in different channels. [96]
In order to quantify the excess, the test-statistic [104]
is replaced with $q_{0}$ by setting $\mu=0$ in Equation~\ref{eqn:llr2}. [113]
The constraint $\muhat>0$ ensures that only excesses in the data are considered significant. [126]
The background-only hypothesis is rejected in favour of a signal-plus-background one [137]
when the $p$-value $p_{0}$, given in Equation~\ref{eqn:plocal}, [145]
is less than some pre-determined critical level $\alpha$. [153]
\begin{equation} [153]
 p_{0} = \int_{q_{0}^{obs}}^{\infty} f(q_{0} |0,\boldth=\boldth_{0}^{obs}) dq_{0}. [154]
\label{eqn:plocal} [154]
\end{equation} [154]
Since $p_{0}$ is uniformly distributed between 0 and 1 under the hypothesis $\mu=0$, [167]
$p_{0}$ is exactly the probability $\alpha$ of falsely rejecting the background-only hypothesis. [179]
The critical value for $\alpha$ is typically $2.87\times10^{-7}$ (corresponding [188]
to a significance of $5\sigma$) when searching for new physics.  [198]
[198]
In the case of the search for the SM Higgs boson, there is an implicit assumption that [215]
the test statistic is defined for a given value of $\mh$. The test statistic designed this way [232]
means that only excesses which are compatible in shape with that of a Higgs signal at some $\mh$ [250]
are considered significant. The $\Hgg$ signal is a narrow peak in the diphoton invariant mass distribution [266]
meaning only localised excesses in $\mgg$ are considered significant. [275]
The value of $p_{0}$ is therefore interpreted as the probability that the background can [289]
fluctuate to produce a localised excess hence $p_{0}$ is termed the local p-value. [302]
[302]
Analogous to calculating limits, the distribution $f(q_{0} |0,\boldth=\boldth_{0}^{obs})$ can be obtained either [313]
through generating toys or using an analytic form. Figure~\ref{fig:q0dist} shows the normalised distribution [326]
of $q_{0}$ under the background-only hypothesis generated from pseudo-experiments compared with the [338]
analytic form, in this case a $\chi^{2}$ distribution with a single degree of freedom, at $m_{H}=124$ GeV. [355]
[355]
\begin{figure} [355]
\begin{center} [355]
 \includegraphics[width=.8\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/statsPlots/q0_example_125_chi2_sqr.pdf} [355]
\end{center} [355]
\caption{Normalised distribution of $q_{0}$ at $\mh=124$ GeV under the background-only [365]
hypothesis generated  from toys (red histogram) and from the analytic form (green line). [378]
The observed value, $q_{0}^{obs}$, obtained from the data is indicated by the black arrow.} [392]
\label{fig:q0dist} [392]
\end{figure} [392]
[392]
[392]
[392]
\section{$\Hgg$ Statistical Results} [3]
\label{sec:hggresults2011} [3]
[3]
The likelihood in Equation~\ref{eqn:likelihoodhggbdt} was coded using the \texttt{C++} based [13]
statistical package \texttt{RooFit/RooStats} version \texttt{5.3.0}~\citep{roofit}. [19]
A framework for automating the procedure of combining datasets, generating toys [30]
and evaluating likelihoods in the context of the combined search for the SM Higgs boson [45]
was developed within \texttt{CMSSW} [49]
under the package \\ [52]
\texttt{HiggsAnalysis/CombinedLimit}~\citep{combinationstwiki}. [54]
All of the results shown in the following sections were obtained using this package. [68]
[68]
The 95\% confidence upper limits on $\xsbr$ were determined using the full 2011 dataset [82]
for different values of $\mh$ in the range to which the channel $\Hgg$ is most sensitive. [98]
Since the resolution of the signal peak in the $\Hgg$ channel is of the order 1 GeV, the limit is calculated [119]
in 100 MeV steps in the range $110 < \mh < 150$ GeV. Figure~\ref{fig:limits7TeV} shows the expected and observed [134]
upper limit on the ratio $\xsbr$ in that range. Where the observed line falls below the red line [152]
at one, a SM Higgs boson decaying to two photons, with mass $\mh$, is excluded at the 95\% confidence level or more. [174]
The limits were calculated using an asymptotic approximation for the distribution of $q_{\mu}$ thereby [188]
removing the need for generation of pseudo-experiments~\citep{asimov}. The procedure involving the generation of toys [202]
was however conducted for several mass hypotheses and found to agree [213]
with the asymptotic calculation. Table~\ref{tab:compareasvstoys} shows this comparison [221]
for the median expected, 68\% and 95\% quantile ranges at different values of $\mh$. [235]

The local p-value from the data is determined in steps of 100 MeV in the range $100 < \mh < 150 $ GeV [405]
using the analytic expression $p_{0} = \sqrt{q_{0}^{obs}}$ [410]
as shown in Figure~\ref{fig:pvals7TeV}. The expectation in the presence of a SM Higgs boson at each $\mh$ tested [428]
is shown in blue while the expectation from a SM Higgs boson with mass 125 GeV is shown in red. [448]
The largest excess in the range occurs near $\mh=124$ GeV corresponding [459]
to a local significance of $3.4\sigma$. The excess is larger than expected in the presence of a SM [477]
Higgs boson near that mass. This is reflected in Figure~\ref{fig:muhat7TeV} which shows the value of [492]
$\mu$ at which the likelihood attains its maximum, $\muhat$, as a function of $\mh$. [506]
The excess observed at 124 GeV corresponds to $\muhat=1.93^{+0.67}_{-0.60}$, that is nearly twice [519]
the expectation from a SM Higgs boson. [526]
[526]

dashed line. The right hand scale shows the significance in standard deviations at each $\mh$.} [599]

\subsubsection{The Look-Elsewhere Effect} [644]
[644]
As the signal for the decay $\Hgg$ is a narrow mass peak, the probability to observe a local excess [663]
anywhere in the search range is much larger than the probability to find one at any particular $\mh$. [681]
This is an example of the look-elsewhere effect~\citep{leelyon}. [689]
Due to this, the local p-value must be modified so as to [701]
express the probability to find an excess at least as significant as the one seen in data for all values of [722]
$\mh$. This is done by throwing background-only pseudo-experiments [730]
and finding the minimum $p_{0}$ across all values of $\mh$ searched over. The fraction of pseudo-experiments with a minimum [749]
$p_{0}$ less than the one observed in data is then the global p-value. [762]
Figure~\ref{fig:leestudy} shows the relationship between local and global p-values. The red line shows a [776]
fit of the function, [780]
\begin{equation} [780]
p_{global} = p_{local} + Ce^{ \frac { -Z^{2}} {{2} } }, [781]
\label{eqn:lee} [781]
\end{equation} [781]
where $Z$ is the local significance and $C$ is a free parameter~\citep{lee}. This function is then used to [799]
determine the look-elsewhere effect for larger significances. [806]
The excess observed at 124 GeV corresponds to a global significance of $2.4\sigma$. [819]
[819]
\begin{figure} [819]
\begin{center} [819]
 \includegraphics[width=.8\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/statsPlots/lee-extrap.pdf} [819]
\end{center} [819]
\caption{Relationship between local and global p-values to determine the look-elsewhere effect [830]
in the $\Hgg$ search for the range 110 to 150 GeV. [841]
The yellow band indicates the statistical precision of the relationship due to the limited number of toys [858]
produced. The red line indicates a fit of an analytic relation between the two and is used to calculate [877]
the global p-value for larger local significances.} [884]
\label{fig:leestudy} [884]
\end{figure} [884]
[884]
In order to generate suitable background-only toys, pseudo-data are generated in two variables, [897]
$\mgg$ and the diphoton BDT output. The value of $\mgg$ for each event in the pseudo-data [913]
is generated from a sum of two power laws which is [924]
fit to the full $\mgg$ spectrum in data in the range $100 < \mgg < 180$ GeV. The value of the diphoton BDT [943]
is generated by fitting a kernel density estimator to the distribution in data. The value of $\dmom$ is then [962]
calculated for each pseudo-event at every $\mh$ and the pseudo-dataset is analysed using the usual likelihood [978]
of Equation~\ref{eqn:likelihoodhggbdt}. This approach is necessary to maintain [986]
the correlations in the likelihood between neighbouring mass-hypotheses. [994]
[994]
[994]
\subsection{Inclusion of 2012 Data} [4]
\label{sec:8tev} [4]
[4]
The search described in Chapter~\ref{chap:hgg} was repeated on data collected at CMS [16]
during the 2012 proton-proton run of the LHC, up to the time of the ICHEP conference in July 2012,  [35]
at a center-of-mass energy of 8 TeV. The additional [44]
data were combined with the 7 TeV dataset as separate categories. [55]
The following section contains the results from the combined datasets corresponding to a [68]
total integrated luminosity of \clumicomb~\cite{HIG-12-028}. [72]
% May want to expand on stuff here, only specifically on the changes to the analysis [72]
[72]
\subsection{Updates for the 8 TeV Analysis} [6]
\label{sec:updates8TeV} [6]
[6]
The majority of the analysis remains unmodified between the two data taking periods. [19]
Due to increased pileup conditions in the 2012 data, the regression BDTs and vertex BDTs [34]
were re-trained using MC weighted to a higher average number of pileup vertices. [47]
As a result of this, both the diphoton and event categorisation BDTs were re-trained [61]
to incorporate the changes. In addition, the slight variation in kinematics between [73]
centre-of-mass energies of 7 and 8 TeV are accounted for in the retraining. [86]
The isolation input variables to the photon ID BDT were modified, removing the correction [100]
for the average energy density in the event, $\rho$. [109]
Instead $\rho$ was introduced as an additional input [117]
variable so that the correlation between the number of pileup vertices and the isolation [131]
could be taken into account in the BDT training. [140]
[140]
Both the energy scale and resolution were re-measured for the 2012 dataset and the corrections [155]
applied to data and MC as with the 2011 analysis. The invariant mass cut on the dijet system for [174]
the dijet tagged events category was reduced to $250$ GeV, increasing the acceptance of $qqH$ production. [190]
The dijet events were further subdivided by separating events with a large reconstructed dijet mass, [205]
improving the sensitivity of the search. For the analysis described in Section~\ref{sec:signalextraction}, [217]
this results in two dijet bins with one being the tight class, containing dijet events with $m_{jj}>500$ [234]
GeV and the other loose class containing all other dijet events. [245]
Figure~\ref{fig:results8TeV} shows the observed number of events from the 2012 dataset in each [258]
of the BDT output bins and the two dijet categories for $\mh=125$ GeV. The background model is derived [276]
using the procedure described in Section~\ref{sec:backgroundmodel} using the 2012 dataset. [286]
The contribution expected from a SM Higgs boson is shown in red. [298]
[298]
\begin{figure} [298]
\begin{center} [298]
 \includegraphics[width=.8\textwidth]{hgg8TeV/hgg_MassWindow_model_m125_8TeV.pdf} [298]
\end{center} [298]
\caption{Observed number of events in the 2012 dataset for each of the seven BDT bins and tight/loose dijet bins [318]
for $\mh=125$ GeV. The background model is shown in blue along with the maximal $\pm 1/2\sigma$ variations. [334]
The expected contribution from a SM Higgs boson is shown in red~\citep{HIG-12-036}.} [346]
\label{fig:results8TeV} [346]
\end{figure} [346]
[346]
\subsection{Results from the Combined Datasets} [5]
\label{sec:resultscombined} [5]
[5]
The 2011 and 2012 datasets were combined statistically by extending the likelihood in [18]
Equation~\ref{eqn:likelihoodhggbdt} [19]
to include a new set of categories which correspond to the updated analysis for the 2012 dataset. [36]
By including the additional data as separate categories, [44]
exclusion limits and p-values are calculated as described in Section~\ref{sec:statisticalinterpretations}. [54]
Figure~\ref{fig:limits8TeV} (left) shows the expected and observed 95\% upper limits [64]
on $\xsbr$ calculated in half GeV steps in $\mh$ [73]
from the combined datasets. The observed local p-value, $p_{0}$, determined [83]
for the 7 TeV, 8 TeV and combined datasets, as a function of $\mh$ is shown in Figure~\ref{fig:limits8TeV} (right). [102]
The largest excess is observed at $\mh=124$ GeV, corresponding to a local significance of $4.8\sigma$. [117]
This is reduced to a global significance of $3.9\sigma$ when considering the look-elsewhere effect in [132]
the range 110 to 150 GeV. [138]
[138]

  \includegraphics[width=.49\textwidth]{hgg8TeV/hgg_MassWindowPValue.pdf} [138]
\end{center} [138]

(left) and local p-value, $p_{0}$ (right) in the range [160]
$110 < \mh < 150$ GeV from the combined 2011 (7 TeV) and 2012 (8 TeV) datasets. [173]
In the left figure, the black dashed lines indicates [182]
the median expected value for the upper limit on $\mu$ [192]
given the size of the dataset while the green and yellow bands indicate [205]
the 68\% and 95\% quantile ranges respectively. [212]
The black solid line shows the observed upper limit. [221]
In the right figure, the observed $p_{0}$ obtained from the combined [232]
datasets is shown in black while the expected value in the presence of a [246]
SM Higgs boson is given by the black dashed line. The observed $p_{0}$ from the 2011 (7 TeV) [264]
and 2012 (8 TeV) datasets individually are shown by the [274]
blue and red dashed lines respectively. The right hand scale shows the significance in [288]

File: ./combinations/combinations.tex

\chapter{Higgs Combination and Properties} [4]
\label{chap:combinations} [4]
[4]
%Careful not to get phillosphical, this section is about [4]
%combined searches not really about stats. [4]
The sensitivity [6]
of the search for the SM Higgs boson depends not only on the production cross-section and [22]
branching ratio to a particular decay channel, but also on the efficiency [34]
of the selection, the experimental resolution and the relative proportions of [45]
signal to background processes. These quantities typically vary greatly as a function of [58]
$\mh$. By combining results from searches [64]
in many decay channels, over a large range in mass, [74]
the overall sensitivity is greatly improved. [80]
This chapter describes the combined searches for the SM Higgs boson and measurements of its properties. [96]
In Section~\ref{sec:combinationmethodology}, a short review on the techniques used for statistical combination of data from different analyses at CMS is provided and a set of diagnostic [122]
tools developed by the author are discussed. [129]
The results of the search using the ICHEP 2012 dataset, [139]
which led to the announcement of the discovery of a new particle [151]
by ATLAS and CMS in July 2012~\citep{HIG-12-028}, are included. [160]
Section~\ref{sec:properties} deals with early studies of the [167]
properties of the newly discovered particle presented at the Hadron Collider Physics (HCP) [180]
symposium in November 2012. This includes a discussion of [189]
the Feldman-Cousins technique which was implemented and performed [197]
by the author to extract information on the compatibility of the new [209]
state with the SM Higgs boson. [215]
[215]
\section{Combined Higgs Searches} [3]
\label{sec:combinationmethodology} [3]
[3]
In order to combine data from all decay channels relevant in the search for the [18]
SM Higgs boson, the likelihood for a particular outcome of the data given a particular [33]
value of $\mu$ is the product of the individual likelihoods in each channel $i$, [47]
\begin{equation} [47]
\mathcal{L}(\mathrm{data}|\mu,\boldth)= p(\boldthmeas|\boldth)\cdot\prod_{i}\mathcal{L}_{i}(\mathrm{data}_{i}|\mu,\boldth) [48]
= \prod_{i}P(\mathrm{data}|\boldth). [48]
\label{eqn:likelihood} [48]
\end{equation} [48]
The relative signal strength $\mu$ is a single parameter which scales the signal [61]
yield in all sub-channels simultaneously. [66]
Systematic uncertainties in the signal and background models in each channel [77]
are modelled through the nuisance parameters, $\boldth$. Typically these nuisances [87]
will be constrained by some external measurements $\boldthmeas$, such as the energy scale [100]
measured in $\Zee$ events in the two-photon decay channel described in [111]
Section~\ref{sec:superclusterenergyreconstruction}. [112]
The pdf, $p(\boldthmeas|\boldth)$, is a product of the pdfs of each nuisance parameter, [125]
which are usually Gaussian distributions, for each independent source of systematic [136]
uncertainty. [137]
Although each event observed in data is exclusive to a particular channel, [149]
many sources of systematic uncertainty are common to several analyses. For this [161]
reason, some of the nuisance parameters are correlated between sub-channels. [171]
[171]
The likelihood was coded using the \texttt{C++} based statistical package \texttt{RooFit/RooStats} version \texttt{5.3.0}~\citep{roofit}. As with those shown in [190]
Chapter~\ref{chap:statistics}, all of the results in the following sections were [200]
obtained using the \texttt{CMSSW} package\\ [205]
\texttt{HiggsAnalysis/CombinedLimit}~\citep{combinationstwiki}. [207]
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%% [207]
[207]
\subsection{Diagnostics with Toy Datasets} [4]
\label{sec:diagnostics} [4]
Frequentist statistical techniques often involve generating many pseudo-datasets (toys) [13]
to build the distribution of a test-statistic. [20]
These distributions are used to set confidence intervals or determine the significance of [33]
some observed excess in experimental data. The combined Higgs searches at CMS employ the [47]
profiled likelihood test-statistic (Equation~\ref{eqn:llr2}) in which the nuisance parameters, [56]
$\boldth$, are profiled. [59]
For calculating the significance of an excess in data, the distribution [70]
of the test-statistic $q_{0}$ under the background-only hypothesis is required. [80]
The procedure for determining this distribution proceeds as follows; [89]
[89]
\begin{itemize} [89]
\item{Fit the observed data fixing $\mu=0$. The values of the nuisance parameters [101]
at which the likelihood attains its maximum are denoted $\boldth_{obs}$.} [111]
\item{Generate a toy dataset under the background-only hypothesis. For the purposes of [123]
generating data, the nuisance parameters are fixed to $\boldth=\boldth_{obs}$.} [132]
\item{Fit the toy dataset twice, once fixing $\mu=0$, $\call(\mathrm{data}|0,\hat{\boldth}_{0})$ [141]
and once more letting [145]
$\mu$ float freely, $\call(\mathrm{data}|\hat{\mu},\hat{\boldth})$. When [150]
evaluating the likelihood, the values of $\boldthmeas$ are randomly generated from their pdfs [163]
(producing ``pseudo-measurements'') in order to model the systematic uncertainties.} [172]
\end{itemize} [172]
As the values of the nuisances are profiled from the data, it is important to [187]
check for additional correlations between sub-channels which may not have [197]
been properly accounted for when building the background and signal models in [209]
each channel. [211]
[211]
A realistic example of a search for an hypothesised particle, $H$, [222]
decaying to two $\tau$ leptons was produced in the form [232]
of a simple counting experiment. The search is performed as a combination of [245]
three channels arising from the possible subsequent [252]
decays of the two tau-leptons; $\tau_{h}e$, $\tau_{h}\mu$ and $e\mu$, where $\tau_{h}$ [263]
denotes a hadronically decaying tau-lepton. [268]
Events are categorised according to the channel in which they are reconstructed. [280]
In each category, the expected background is estimated [288]
either from simulation or some control region in data. [297]
The data are represented by the number of events observed in each category. [310]
Several sources of systematic uncertainty are included which effect the [320]
expected signal and background in one or more of the channels. [331]
Systematics are incorporated into the likelihood in the form of nuisance [342]
parameters as described previously. The analysis is summarized in [351]
Table~\ref{tab:realanalysis} which details the number of expected events [359]
from each background and signal process in each channel as well as the [372]
observed count in data. [376]
The analysis is available from the \texttt{CMSSW} package \texttt{HiggsAnalysis/CombinedLimit}\\ [386]
under the directory \texttt{data/tutorials/realistic-counting-experiment.txt}~\citep{combinationstwiki}. [392]
[392]
\begin{table} [392]
\centering [392]
\begin{tabular}{|l|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} [392]
\hline [392]
\textbf{channel} & \multicolumn{3}{c|}{$\tau_{h}-e$} & \multicolumn{3}{|c|}{$\tau_{h}-\mu$} [392]
&\multicolumn{3}{c|}{$e-\mu$}    \\ \hline [392]
observed & \multicolumn{3}{c}{517} &\multicolumn{3}{|c|}{540} & \multicolumn{3}{c|}{101} \\ \hline [392]
expected & Sig & $\Ztt$ & QCD & Sig & $\Ztt$ & QCD &Sig & $\Ztt$ & other  \\ \hline [392]
& 0.34 & 190 & 327 &  0.57 & 329 & 259 & 0.15 & 88 & 14  \\ \hline [392]
\hline [392]
\textbf{systematics} & \multicolumn{9}{c|}{} \\ \hline [392]
luminosity  & 11\% & - & - & 11\% & - & - & 11\% & - & 11\%  \\ \hline [392]

\end{tabular} [392]
\caption{A realistic counting experiment across several channels. [399]
The number of observed events and that expected from signal and background [411]
processes are given per channel. Several sources of systematic are included [422]
which effect the expected rate of each signal or background process. [433]
Where a dash is entered, the systematic uncertainty has no effect on that [446]
process or channel.} [449]
\label{tab:realanalysis} [449]
\end{table} [449]
[449]
Around 90,000 toy datasets were generated under the background-only hypothesis as is [462]
appropriate for determining the distribution of $q_{0}$. [469]
Each toy dataset was fit twice, once fixing $\mu$ to zero and a second allowing $\mu$ to float freely. [488]
The results of the fits are used to diagnose the fits and highlight [501]
potentially problematic channels or nuisance parameters. [507]
Figure~\ref{fig:real_lumi_s} shows a summary of the fit results [515]
in the nuisance parameter \texttt{lumi}, [520]
which models the systematic uncertainty associated with the total luminosity measurement. [531]
The upper left panel shows two pull distributions of the values from the fit. The entries are [548]
calculated as the difference between the value of the fitted parameter [559]
and the value from the best fit to data, $\theta_{obs}$, divided by [571]
the $1\sigma$ uncertainty on the parameter before fitting to the data. [582]
The blue histogram includes all toys while the red shows the results [594]
for toys in which the best fit signal strength is positive. Since the test-statistic $q_{0}$ [609]
is designed to report only excesses in the data, [618]
it is important to check that nuisance parameters correlated to the signal [630]
strength are well behaved. [634]
[634]
The pull distributions are fitted with a Gaussian and the width and mean [647]
are reported in the upper right panel. Since the pseudo-measurements [657]
are generated around the best fit to data, the pull distributions [668]
are expected to be centered around 0. In general, nuisance parameters [679]
are constrained from external measurements so it is expected that the [690]
width of the pull distribution is 1. Nuisance parameters which are further [702]
constrained by the observed data will typically have a pull distribution with width less [716]
than unity. The parameter \texttt{lumi} does not show signs of being constrained [728]
by the data. [731]
This is reflected in the lower left panel which shows the correlation between [744]
the nuisance parameter and the value generated for the pseudo-measurement [754]
of this parameter (\texttt{lumi\_In}) in each toy. [762]
This behaviour is expected since this nuisance parameter mostly affects the signal process and [776]
is correlated across all channels so that only the overall [786]
normalization is altered. Since these fits allow $\mu$ to float freely, [797]
any parameter which alters only the overall normalization of the signal should [809]
achieve the value generated for its pseudo-measurement at the maximum of the likelihood. [822]
The lower right panel shows the shape of the negative log-likelihood [833]
as a function of the nuisance parameter ($\theta$), [841]
\begin{equation} [841]
-\log \frac{\displaystyle \mathcal{L}(\mathrm{data}|\mu=\muhat,\theta=\theta_{S+B})} [842]
  {\displaystyle \mathcal{L}(\mathrm{data}|\mu=\muhat,\theta)}, [842]
\end{equation} [842]
near its minimum value ($\theta_{S+B}$). [847]
At each point, all other parameters are fixed [855]
to those of the best fit to the data (in this case, from the fit allowing $\mu$ to float). [874]
The likelihood is expected to be parabolic around its minima with no secondary (local) [888]
minima present. [890]
Degenerate minima, which can cause instabilities in the fitting procedure, will be visible in the [905]
shape of the negative log-likelihood. The diagnostic tools described here were applied [917]
to the ICHEP 2012 combination for $\mh=125$ GeV as documented in a CMS Analysis note by the [934]
author~\citep{AN-12-317}. [935]
The full set of diagnostic summary plots can be found online~\citep{onlinediag}. [946]
\begin{figure} [946]
 \begin{center} [946]
  \includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{combinations/diagnostics/tree_fit_sb_lumi.pdf} [946]
  \end{center} [946]
    \caption{Summary plots for the parameter \texttt{lumi} of the realistic counting experiment. [957]
The entries in the histograms are for fits to toys generated under the background-only [971]
hypothesis letting $\mu$ float freely. The bottom, left panel shows the correlation [983]
between the value generated for the pseudo-measurement of the nuisance [993]
\texttt{lumi\_In} and the fitted value of the parameter. [1002]
The lower right panel shows the shape of the [1011]
negative log-likelihood (NLL) as a function of the nuisance parameter. [1021]
The parameters of the fitted Gaussian for each histogram are given as the [1034]
Mean and Sigma. The value and error of the nuisance parameter are given before fitting [1049]
to the data (Pre-fit), followed by the best fit value of the parameter [1062]
under the background-only and signal-plus-background hypotheses.} [1068]
  \label{fig:real_lumi_s} [1068]
\end{figure} [1068]
[1068]
\subsection{Higgs Search Combination} [3]
\label{combinedsearchresults} [3]
[3]
A search for the SM Higgs boson was performed by combining data recorded at CMS [18]
at a centre of mass energy of 7 and 8 TeV. The search was performed in five [35]
decay modes, $\Hgg$, $\Hzz$, $\Hww$, $\Htt$ and $\Hbb$ with datasets of [46]
integrated luminosities of $4.9-5.1~fb^{-1}$ and $5.1-5.3~fb^{-1}$ [52]
from the 2011 and 2012 data taking periods of the LHC respectively. [64]
The search is performed across a wide range in Higgs boson mass hypothesis ($\mh$) [78]
from 110 to 600 GeV. For $\mh>150$ GeV, the $\Hgg,~\Htt$ and $\Hbb$ decay modes are not used [95]
as they are significantly less sensitive than the $\Hww$ and [105]
$\Hzz$ channels. Figure~\ref{fig:expectedlimits} shows the relative sensitivities of [113]
each decay channel in terms of the expected exclusion limit for the size of the dataset [129]
used. The exclusive final state topologies in each of the five modes used [142]
in the combination, including the size of the dataset used and the mass range to [157]
which they are sensitive, are given in Table~\ref{tab:channelsummary}. [165]
[165]
\begin{figure} [165]
\begin{center} [165]
\includegraphics[width=0.49\textwidth]{combinations/ichep2012/Figure_001-a.pdf} [165]
\includegraphics[width=0.49\textwidth]{combinations/ichep2012/Figure_001-b.pdf} [165]
\end{center} [165]
\caption{Median expected 95\% CL upper limits on $\mu=\xs$ [173]
for the five Higgs boson decay channels and their combination in the absence [186]
of a Higgs boson as a function of $\mh$. The limits are given in the range [202]
110-600 GeV (left) and 110-145 GeV (right). A channel which falls below 1, [215]
indicated by the dashed line, for some range is expected to exclude a Higgs boson [230]
in that range at the 95\% CL or more using this dataset~\citep{HIG-12-020}.} [242]
\label{fig:expectedlimits} [242]
\end{figure} [242]
[242]
\subsubsection{Combined Search Channels} [245]
The $\Hgg$ analysis is one of the most sensitive channels at low $\mh$. The [259]
analysis is that described in Chapter~\ref{chap:hgg} with the exception of [269]
the signal extraction method; Method A is used in the combination. Events are categorized using the diphoton BDT into [288]
four classes chosen so as to optimise the search in terms of the expected limit [303]
at $\mh=125$ GeV. The diphoton invariant mass spectrum in each category is fit [316]
with polynomial functions whose order is determined following a procedure designed [327]
to reduce any potential bias to less than 20\% of the statistical uncertainty on [341]
the background~\citep{HIG-12-015}. The dijet selected events are [348]
categorised separately and treated in the same way as the inclusive events. [360]
[360]
Due to the extremely high cross-section of $b\bar{b}$ production in [370]
p-p collisions, the $\Hbb$ search focuses on Higgs boson production in association [382]
with a $W$ or $Z$ boson, which are identified by the presence of leptons. In the case [399]
of neutrino final states such as $Z\rightarrow \nu\nu$, the missing transverse energy [410]
($\met$) of the event is required to be large indicating momentum propagated out of the detector by the neutrinos~\citep{HIG-12-019}. [429]
This quantity is defined as the magnitude of the negative vector sum over all energy deposits, [445]
$E_{k}$, in the calorimeters projected into the transverse plane [454]
($\hat{\mathbf{i}},\hat{\mathbf{j}}$), [455]
\begin{equation} [455]
\met = |\metvec| =|\sum_{deposits} -\sin\theta_{k}\left(E_{k}\cos(\phi_{k})\hat{\mathbf{i}}+E_{k}\sin(\phi_{k})\hat{\mathbf{j}}\right)| [456]
\end{equation} [456]
The Higgs boson candidate itself is reconstructed by looking for two [467]
$b$-tagged jets indicated by their production at secondary vertices. Events are [479]
categorized into those where the [484]
$W$ or $Z$ boson is recoiling away from the $b\bar{b}$ system with high momentum. [498]
The main backgrounds are from $W/Z$+jets and $t\bar{t}$ as well as from $WZ$ and $ZZ$ [514]
in which the $Z$ decays to a pair of $b$-quarks. The backgrounds are suppressed [529]
by use of a multivariate analysis technique trained on MC simulation. [540]
The search is also performed in events in which the Higgs boson is produced in association [556]
with a pair of top-quarks ($ttH$) categorized into either lepton plus jet or dilepton [570]
final states~\citep{HIG-12-019}. This mode was not included in the 8 TeV dataset [582]
for the ICHEP 2012 combination. [587]
[587]
In the $\Htt$ decay channel, the search is performed using events with leptonic [600]
final states and events in which one of the tau-leptons decays hadronically [612]
($\tau_{h}$)~\citep{HIG-12-018}. [613]
Events are divided into categories based on the number and type of jets in the event [629]
and by the transverse momentum of the visible part of the tau decay. [642]
A signal in this channel will be visible as a broad excess in the invariant mass [658]
of the $\tau\bar{\tau}$ system ($m_{\tau\tau}$). The main backgrounds are from [668]
$Z\rightarrow\tau\tau$ events and $W+$jet production. [674]
Production of $qqH$ is tagged by the association of two jets consistent with [687]
those resulting from vector boson fusion. Finally, the $VH$ modes are [698]
exploited by selecting events which have one or more additional leptons [709]
consistent with a $W$ or $Z$ boson decay. [717]
[717]
The $\Hww$ analysis is one of the most sensitive analyses at CMS for [730]
values of $\mh$ between 150 and 200 GeV~\citep{HIG-12-017}. [738]
The $WW\rightarrow2l2\nu$ sub-channel consists of events with [745]
two oppositely charged leptons, a large $\met$ and up [754]
to two jets (to target $qqH$ production). [761]
The events are further divided into categories in which the two leptons [773]
are of the same or opposite flavour to exploit the different [784]
background contributions from $Z$ decays. For the 7 TeV analysis, [794]
an MVA classifier was trained on signal and background [803]
MC to separate signal from background. The search is conducted by looking [815]
for an excess of events in the output distribution of the MVA. [827]
In the $WW\rightarrow l\nu 2q$ sub-channel, a broad excess is searched [836]
for in the four-body invariant mass spectrum~\citep{HIG-12-021}. [843]
The invariant mass is reconstructed from the lepton four-vector and $\metvec$ [854]
assuming the mass of the $l\nu$ is that of a $W$ boson and [867]
choosing the neutrino's longitudinal component to be that which minimises [877]
the transverse momentum of the $l\nu$ system. [884]
Associated production of the Higgs boson with a $W$ boson is searched for [897]
by looking for an excess of events with three leptons and large [909]
$\met$~\citep{HIG-11-034}. [910]
[910]
The $\Hzz$ analysis focuses on four final state topologies. [919]
The $ZZ\rightarrow 4l$ is a search for a narrow four-lepton invariant mass [930]
peak over a small background~\citep{HIG-12-016}. The kinematics of the $4l$ system are used [943]
to assign a probability that the event is from either a signal or background [957]
process to improve the sensitivity. For the lower mass region ($m_{H}<180$ GeV), [969]
only one of the lepton pairs is required to have a mass consistent with an [984]
on-shell $Z$ boson. [987]
The $4e$, $4\mu$ and $2e2\mu$ sub-channels are categorised separately as the [998]
mass resolutions and the background rates differ between between the three [1009]
final states. In the $ZZ\rightarrow 2l2\tau$ and $ZZ\rightarrow 2l2q$ channels, [1017]
a broader peak is searched for in the dilepton-ditau and dilepton-dijet [1028]
mass spectrum respectively~\citep{HIG-12-016,HIG-11-027}. [1031]
The limited jet energy resolution [1036]
and the effect of the neutrino escaping detection in leptonic tau decays [1048]
degrades the mass resolution in these channels compared to the $4l$ decay. [1060]
The $ZZ\rightarrow 2l2\nu$ search looks for a leptonic $Z$ decay [1069]
and a large $\met$~\citep{HIG-12-023}. [1073]
In this channel, the decay is not fully reconstructible and so a measure of the mass [1089]
is given by the transverse mass, $m_{T}$ defined as, [1098]
\begin{equation} [1098]
m_{T} = \left[2 p_{T}^{Z}\met(1-\cos(\Delta\phi))\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}, [1099]
\end{equation} [1099]
where $p_{T}^{Z}$ is the transverse momentum of the dilepton system and [1110]
$\Delta\phi$ is the angle in the transverse plain between that momentum vector and [1123]
$\metvec$. [1124]
A broad excess of events in the $m_{T}$ distribution is used to signal the presence [1139]
of a SM Higgs boson. [1144]
[1144]
[1144]

\caption{Summary of analyses included in the ICHEP 2012 combination~\citep{HIG-12-020}. [1153]
The column for $H$ prod indicates the production process targeted by the sub-channel. [1166]
A label ``untagged'' indicates that the main contribution is from the $ggH$ production process. [1180]
The final states for each channel are exclusive (no events lie in more than one sub-channel). [1196]
The notations used here are: $jj$ indicating a dijet pair whether from a $W,~Z$ boson decay or [1213]
being consistent the vector-boson fusion process; $j_{b}$ denotes a jet which is [1225]
identified as a $b$-jet; [1230]
$l$ is either a muon ($\mu$) or electron ($e$); OF and SF are dilepton pairs with [1246]
opposite flavour ($e\mu$) and same flavour ($ee$ or $\mu\mu$) respectively.} [1256]
\label{tab:channelsummary} [1256]
\end{sidewaystable} [1256]
[1256]
\subsubsection{Combined Results} [1258]
\label{sec:combinedsearchresults} [1258]
The 95\% upper limits on the signal strength $\mu=\xs$ as a function [1270]
of the hypothesised Higgs boson mass, $\mh$, are shown in [1280]
Figure~\ref{fig:combinedexcl}. The right hand figure is an enlargement of [1289]
the region $110 < \mh < 145$ GeV. The median expected limit in the absence [1300]
of a SM Higgs boson is less than 1 for the range $110< \mh<600$ GeV. [1314]
The observed limits are consistent with statistical fluctuations given the [1324]
size of the dataset in most of the range as indicated by the fact that the [1340]
observed line lies within the 68\% or 95\% quantiles. However an [1351]
excess of events is observed at low mass in the range $122.5  < \mh < 127$ GeV [1364]
so that a SM Higgs boson with a mass in that range cannot be excluded [1379]
at the 95\% confidence level. The significance of the excess is quantified as a function [1394]
of $\mh$ by calculating the local $p$-value, $p_{0}$ as shown in Figure~\ref{fig:combinedpval}. [1407]
For the overall combination, the local $p_{0}$ is around $5.5\times10^{-7}$, [1417]
equivalent to a significance of $4.9\sigma$. The test indicates that the observed excess [1430]
is incompatible with the background-only hypothesis indicating the presence of [1440]
a new state with a mass near 125 GeV. [1449]
The largest contributions to the excess are [1456]
from the $\Hgg$ and $H\rightarrow ZZ\rightarrow4l$ channels, [1462]
both of which have good mass resolutions and hence a good localisation [1474]
of the excess. The combination of the two [1482]
high mass resolution channels results in a local significance of $5.0\sigma$. [1493]
Of the lower resolution channels, only $\Hww$ shows an excess at 125 GeV. The inclusion [1508]
of the $\Hbb$ and $\Htt$ channels reduced the overall significance. [1518]
The overall global $p$-value in the range 115-130 GeV is calculated by [1531]
generating 10,000 pseudo-datasets and fitting for the constant $C$ in [1542]
the relationship to the local $p$-value given in Equation~\ref{eqn:lee} [1552]
(see Figure~\ref{fig:leecombination}). The [1555]
look-elsewhere effect, calculated as the ratio between the local and global $p_{0}$, [1567]
is around 11 such that the global significance of the full combination remains high at $4.4\sigma$. [1583]
[1583]
\begin{figure} [1583]
\begin{center} [1583]
\includegraphics[width=.49\textwidth]{combinations/ichep2012/Figure_004-a.pdf} [1583]
\includegraphics[width=.49\textwidth]{combinations/ichep2012/Figure_004-b.pdf} [1583]
\end{center} [1583]
\caption{Combined 95\% upper limits on the production cross-section of Higgs boson [1594]
production relative to that of the Standard Model in the $\mh$ ranges 110-600 GeV (left) [1609]
and 110-145 GeV (right)~\citep{HIG-12-020}. The median upper limits expected in the absence of a SM Higgs boson  [1626]
are indicated by the dashed black line and the 68\% and 95\% quantiles by the green and yellow [1644]
bands respectively. [1646]
The observed upper limits from the combined ICHEP 2012 dataset is shown by the black solid line. [1663]
Where the observed limit is lower than 1 (red line), a SM Higgs boson with that $\mh$ [1680]
is excluded at the 95\% confidence level.} [1687]
\label{fig:combinedexcl} [1687]
\end{figure} [1687]
[1687]
\begin{figure} [1687]
\begin{center} [1687]
\includegraphics[width=.8\textwidth]{combinations/ichep2012/sqr_pvala_all_byresol.pdf} [1687]
\end{center} [1687]
\caption{The observed local $p$-value, $p_{0}$ for sub-combinations of the low and [1699]
high resolution channels and the overall combination as a function of $\mh$. The dashed [1713]
line shows the expected $p_{0}$ at each $\mh$ should a SM Higgs boson exist with mass $\mh$~\citep{HIG-12-020}.} [1730]
\label{fig:combinedpval} [1730]
\end{figure} [1730]
[1730]
[1730]

\section{Higgs Properties} [2]
\label{sec:properties} [2]
[2]
With the announcement of the discovery of a new state near 125 GeV, attention at ATLAS and CMS [20]
turned to the characterization of the particle through  measurements of its properties. [32]
In particular, emphasis is placed on ascertaining the compatibility [41]
of the new state with the SM Higgs boson. [50]
This section includes discussions of some of the techniques used at CMS to determine the properties [66]
of the newly discovered state and results presented at the HCP symposium in November 2012. [81]
All of the analyses described in Section~\ref{sec:combinedsearchresults}, [88]
with exception of $\Hgg$, were updated to improve their sensitivity [98]
and include the additional data collected at CMS~\citep{HIG-12-045}. The total integrated [109]
luminosity of the 8 TeV data sample used is up to $12.2 fb^{-1}$ depending on the [124]
specific channel. [126]
[126]
\subsection{Extracting Signal Parameters} [3]
[3]
The best fit value for the signal strength is evaluated [13]
by scanning for the value of $\mu$ at which the likelihood (Equation~\ref{eqn:likelihood}) [25]
attains its maximum in data. This can be extended where more than one signal parameter [40]
is of interest by generalising to the profiled likelihood ratio, [50]
\begin{equation} [50]
q_{\boldmu} = [51]
-2\ln\frac{\displaystyle \mathcal{L}(\mathrm{data} | \mu,\hat{\boldth}_{\boldmu})} [51]
{\displaystyle \mathcal{L}(\mathrm{data} | \hat{\boldmu},\hat{\boldth})}, [51]
\label{eqn:llrNd} [51]
\end{equation} [51]
where $\boldmu=x_{1},x_{2},\cdots$$,x_{N}$ represents the $N$ parameters [57]
of interest in the signal model. The values of the nuisance parameters [69]
which maximise the value of the likelihood first [77]
fixing the values of $\mu$ and then letting them float freely are [89]
denoted $\hat{\boldth}_{\boldmu}$ and $\hat{\boldth}$ respectively. [94]
The values for which $q_{\boldmu}=0$ in the observed data are the best fit values. [108]
The contour defined by the set of points for which $C_{N}(q_{\boldmu})=0.68$, [119]
where $C_{N}$ is the cumulative distribution function (cdf) of a chi-squared distribution [131]
with $N$ degrees of freedom, is interpreted [138]
as the 68\% confidence contour. In one dimension, the values at which $q_{\boldmu}=1$ [151]
represent the usual 68\% confidence interval. [157]
This method for extracting confidence intervals is known to fail when the best fit [171]
values lie within or near non-physical regions. [178]
It is necessary therefore to cross-check this method to avoid quoting [189]
non-physical results. This is achieved through the use of the Feldman-Cousins procedure. [201]
[201]
\subsubsection{The Feldman-Cousins Procedure for Evaluating Confidence Intervals} [208]
[208]
For parameters such as the relative production cross-section, $\mu$, negative values [219]
are not considered physical. Constraints on the fit can be imposed to avoid quoting unphysical values. [235]
However, where the best-fit values for the signal model parameters lie outside physically [248]
allowed regions, the relationship between the values of $q_\mu$ and [258]
the 68\% confidence interval no longer holds. [265]
In order to assign the correct confidence intervals, the Feldman-Cousins [275]
procedure is used~\citep{fc}.  [278]
The procedure involves throwing pseudo-datasets and evaluating [285]
a test-statistic to determine the compatibility of the data with each [296]
point in the $N$-dimensional parameter space. [303]
The test-statistic used in the one-dimensional case of the signal strength [314]
is defined using the ratio of profiled likelihoods, $\qmu$ (Equation~\ref{eqn:llr2}). [324]
The physical constraint on the parameter is imposed in this case by [336]
requiring that $\hat{\mu} \ge 0$. [339]
The probability to obtain a value of the test-statistic larger than the one [352]
observed in data ($CL_{s+b}$) is calculated as in Equation~\ref{eqn:clsplusb}, [361]
where the distribution $f(\qmu | \mu,\boldth=\boldth_{\mu}^{obs})$ is [366]
generated from evaluating the test-statistic in pseudo-datasets. [373]
As with calculating upper limits, for generating the pseudo-data, the nuisances ($\boldth$) [385]
are set to the values obtained from a fit to the data. [397]
Figure~\ref{fig:fcegtoys} shows an example of this distribution for two [406]
values of $\mu$ from the (0/1)-jet bin of the $\Htt$ analysis and the values of [423]
$q_\mu^{obs}$ obtained from the observed data. [429]
\begin{figure} [429]
\begin{center} [429]
\includegraphics[width=.49\textwidth]{combinations/fceg_htt_2.pdf} [429]
\includegraphics[width=.49\textwidth]{combinations/fceg_htt_1.pdf} [429]
\end{center} [429]
\caption{Distributions of the test statistic $q_{\mu}$ for the 0/1 jet bin [441]
of the $H\rightarrow \tau\tau$ analysis at the combined best fit mass, $m_{H} = 125.8$ GeV. [453]
The green and yellow filled regions indicate the 68\% and 95\% quantiles of the [467]
distribution respectively. [469]
The left distribution is generated at $\mu=2.28$ [476]
which lies outside of the 68\% confidence interval [484]
while the right distribution is generated at $\mu=1.34$ which lies inside the [496]
68\% confidence interval. The values of the test statistic obtained from the observed data, [510]
$q_{\mu}^{obs}$, are indicated by the solid vertical lines.} [518]
\label{fig:fcegtoys} [518]
\end{figure} [518]
The 68\% confidence interval for $\mu$ is determined as the union of all values of $\mu$ for [535]
which $1-CL_{s+b}<0.68$. [537]
Figure~\ref{fig:confcontour} shows the values of $1-CL_{s+b}$ for different values of [547]
$\mu$ in the 0/1 jet bin of the $\Htt$ analysis. [558]
The vertical red line indicates $CL_{s+b}=0.68$ and the values at which the curve [571]
crosses this line (indicated by the horizontal red lines) form the 68\% confidence [584]
interval for $\mu$. [587]
\begin{figure} [587]
\begin{center} [587]
\includegraphics[width=.7\textwidth]{combinations/confcurve_htt.pdf} [587]
\end{center} [587]
\caption{Confidence level evaluation curve for the $\Htt$ analysis in the (0/1) jet bin. [601]
At each point, pseudo-data are generated with signal injected at the given value of $\mu$ [616]
and its confidence level (CL) calculated. [622]
Linear interpolation between the generated points is used to determine the 68\% confidence [635]
interval; the two values of $\mu$ (horizontal lines) which cross the curve at $1-CL_{s+b}=0.68$ [649]
(vertical red line).} [652]
\label{fig:confcontour} [652]
\end{figure} [652]
The procedure is easily extended to a higher number of dimensions [663]
by exchanging the test-statistic for $q_{\boldmu}$, given in Equation~\ref{eqn:llrNd}. [672]
Pseudo-datasets are generated and fit as before and the union of points for which [686]
$1-CL_{s+b}<0.68$ defines a confidence-contour in an $n$-dimensional parameter space. [696]
[696]
[696]
\subsection{Combined Mass Measurement} [3]
The mass of the Higgs boson is a free parameter in the context of the [18]
Standard Model. The high resolution channels, [24]
$\Hgg$ and $\Hzz \rightarrow 4l$, [27]
provide the strongest constraint on the mass of the new particle as the signal [41]
is visible as a narrow peak in the invariant mass of its decay products. [55]
To measure the mass, $m_{X}$, of the particle in a model-independent way, [67]
the signal strengths for the $gg\rightarrow \Hgg$, $qq\rightarrow \Hgg$ [74]
and $\Hzz\rightarrow 4l$ processes are assumed to be independent and thus are treated as [87]
nuisance parameters in the likelihood. Each of the signals in these channels [99]
are assumed to be due to the presence of a single state with mass $m_{X}$. [114]
Figure~\ref{fig:mass} (left) shows the value of the test-statistic [122]
$q_{m_{X}}$ for the $\Hgg$, $\Hzz$ channels and their combination near the [133]
best fit points. From the combination, the mass is determined to be $m_{X}=125.8 \pm 0.5$ GeV. [147]
The 68\% confidence interval is determined [153]
from the values of $m_{X}$ at which the curve crosses the horizontal red line at 1. [169]
Large background fluctuations in the $\Hgg$ channel can result in [179]
large variations of the measured mass when the signal is small.  [190]
Conversely, the kinematic constraints on the $4l$ system cause a large variation in [203]
the branching ratio of $\Hzz \rightarrow 4l$, and hence the expected signal yield, [214]
as a function of $\mh$. [219]
Figure~\ref{fig:mass} (right) shows the two-dimensional 68\% confidence intervals [227]
in $m_{X}$ and $\xs$ for the $\Hzz\rightarrow 4l$, $\Hgg$ and their combination. [238]
For this combination, the ratio signal strengths between the two channels is [250]
kept fixed to the SM expectation; only the overall signal strength is left as a [265]
free parameter.  The best fit value of $m_{X}$ is consistent with the [277]
value determined in the one-dimensional case. [283]
The best fit value for the combined signal strength relative to the [295]
Standard Model is $0.88\pm0.21$ for a mass of 125.8 GeV. [305]
[305]
\begin{figure} [305]
\includegraphics[width=0.49\textwidth]{combinations/Figure_007-b.pdf} [305]
\includegraphics[width=0.49\textwidth]{combinations/Figure_007-a.pdf} [305]
\caption{ Left: One-dimensional scan of $q_{m_{x}}$ for the $\Hgg$, [313]
$\Hzz$ channels and their combination. For the combination, the relative [323]
signal strengths between the channels are allowed to float. The 68\% [334]
and 95\% confidence intervals for $m_{X}$ are determined as the values at [346]
which the curves cross the horizontal red lines. Right: 68\% confidence [357]
contours in $m_{X}$ and $\xs$ for the $\Hgg$ and $\Hzz$ channels and their [370]
combination. For this combination, the relative signal strengths of the [380]
channels are kept fixed to the SM expectation~\citep{HIG-12-045}.} [388]
\label{fig:mass} [388]
\end{figure} [388]
\subsection{Compatibility with the Standard Model} [5]
The Standard Model makes very precise predictions for the coupling of the Higgs [18]
boson to all of the known fundamental particles. These couplings directly influence [30]
the various rates of production and decay of the Higgs boson. [41]
Precise measurements of these rates [46]
in the combined search channels provide information on the couplings. [56]
Significant deviations from the values predicted by the SM [65]
would indicate the presence of new physics. [72]
[72]
\subsubsection{Channel Compatibility} [74]
When determining the preferred value of $\mu$ in the combined data, [85]
the ratios of decay rates to each contributing channel relative [95]
to that predicted by the SM are kept constant. [104]
By relaxing this constraint, the compatibility of the new state [114]
with the SM Higgs boson can be studied on a per-decay/per-production level. [127]
Due to the limited amount of data collected at CMS, [137]
some of the channels and sub-channels entering the combination [146]
have a negative value for the best fit signal strength ($\mu=\xs$). [157]
In order to avoid quoting unphysical values in each channel, the Feldman-Cousins [169]
procedure is used to determine 68\% confidence intervals for $\xs$ separately in the different [183]
channels/sub-channels entering the combination. [188]
Figure~\ref{fig:fc1d} (left) shows the 68\% confidence intervals on $\xs$ for the sub-channels [200]
included in the combination obtained from the HCP dataset. The results are compared with the intervals determined [217]
directly from a scan of $\qmu$, as shown in the same figure (right). The two methods are found [235]
to be in good agreement. The intervals are extracted for a Higgs boson [248]
mass $m_{H}=125.8$ GeV (the overall best fit mass of the new state obtained from the [263]
same dataset). The 68\% confidence interval on $\xs$ for the full combination is indicated [277]
by the green band. With the exception of the dijet (VBF) tagged channel in the [292]
$\Hgg$ analysis, all of the intervals contain the value $\mu=1$ which is the expected value for [308]
a SM Higgs boson. [312]
\begin{figure} [312]
\begin{center} [312]
\includegraphics[width=.49\textwidth]{combinations/sqr_fc_ccc.pdf} [312]
\includegraphics[width=.49\textwidth]{combinations/sqr_mlz_ccc_mH125.pdf} [312]
\end{center} [312]
\caption{68\% confidence intervals for $\mu=\xs$ for individual [319]
channels or combination of sub-channels determined using the Feldman-Cousins procedure (left) [330]
and by scanning the likelihood (right). The value of $\xs$ denotes [341]
the production cross-section times the relevant branching fraction for a given [352]
channel, relative to the SM. The green band indicates the 68\% confidence interval [365]
on $\xs$ for all channels combined. The intervals are determined at the best fit [379]
mass, $m_{H}=125.8$ GeV~\citep{HIG-12-045}.} [382]
\label{fig:fc1d} [382]
\end{figure} [382]
[382]
Several of the analyses which are combined in the search for the Higgs boson use  [397]
selections (tags) which are specifically designed [403]
to enhance the sensitivity to particular Higgs boson [411]
production topologies. The $\Hww$, $\Htt$ and $\Hgg$ analyses all include [421]
dijet (or VBF tagged) categories which are designed predominantly to select events [433]
produced via vector-boson fusion ($qqH$). [438]
Additional sensitivity is gained in the $\Hww$, $\Htt$ and $\Hbb$ channels by [450]
looking for additional leptons or $E_{T}$ in association with production of [461]
a vector boson ($VH$). The production rates associated [469]
to couplings with top-quarks ($ggH$ and $ttH$) and vector bosons ($qqH$ and $VH$) [482]
are determined by removing the requirement that the relative production [492]
cross-sections $\muggh$ and $\muqqh$ are equal. [498]
The compatibility of the rates observed in data with respect to those [510]
predicted by the Standard Model can be tested using the Feldman-Cousins [521]
procedure or scanning the test-statistic $q_{\boldmu}$. The relative branching ratios to each of the five observable final states [539]
are left unconstrained. [542]
Figure~\ref{fig:fc2d} shows the 68\% confidence contours for each [550]
of the five decay processes using the two methods. Good agreement is found when comparing the two methods. [568]
With the exception of the $\Hzz$ analysis, the [576]
explicit exploitation of the different production modes leads to [585]
elliptical contours. The SM point $(1,1)$, indicated by the yellow diamond, [596]
is contained within the 68\% confidence contours from each decay channel with the [609]
exception of $\Hgg$.  [612]
[612]
\begin{figure} [612]
\begin{center} [612]
\includegraphics[width=.49\textwidth]{combinations/sqr_rvrf_fc_2d.pdf} [612]
\includegraphics[width=.49\textwidth]{combinations/sqr_rvrf_scan_2d_all_68.pdf} [612]
\end{center} [612]
\caption{68\% confidence contours for the production cross-section in [620]
$ggH$ and $ttH$ modes ($\muggh$), and $VH$ and $qqH$ modes ($\muqqh$), [631]
relative to the SM determined using the Feldman-Cousins procedure (left) and [642]
by scanning the likelihood (right). [647]
Each colour indicates the result by combining all sub-channels in a particular [659]
decay mode. The crosses indicate the best fit values of the two parameters. [672]
The yellow diamond at $(1,1)$ indicates the SM values. [681]
The contours are determined at the best fit mass, $m_{H}=125.8$ GeV~\citep{HIG-12-045}.} [692]
\label{fig:fc2d} [692]
\end{figure} [692]
[692]
[692]
% This section might not make it into the final draft, bit too out there? [692]
\subsubsection{Coupling Measurements} [694]
\label{sec:coupling} [694]
[694]
The compatibility of the couplings of the new particle with the SM cannot be directly ascertained [710]
in the experimental data. In order to extract the relevant information, the rates of production and decay in the various [730]
channels must be interpreted in terms of the underlying couplings to the SM particles. [744]
For the purposes of evaluating the compatibility in the couplings, the following simplifications [757]
are made: [759]
\begin{itemize} [759]
\item Signals observed in each of the different search channels originate from a single [772]
resonance near 125 GeV. [776]
\item The natural width of the resonance is small enough to be neglected such that the [791]
cross-section of the signal in each channel can be expressed as [802]
\begin{equation} [802]
(\sigma \cdot BR)(ii\rightarrow H\rightarrow ff) [803]
= \frac{\displaystyle \sigma_{ii}\Gamma_{ff}}{\displaystyle \Gamma}, [803]
\end{equation} [803]
where $\sigma_{ii}$ is the production cross-section through the initial state $ii$, [814]
$\Gamma_{ff}$ is the partial decay width to the final state $ff$ and $\Gamma$ is the [829]
total width. [831]
\item Only modifications of the absolute values of the coupling strengths are allowed. [843]
The structure of the couplings is fixed to the SM, in particular this means the [858]
new state is assumed to be a CP-even scalar. [867]
\end{itemize} [867]
In general, no specific assumptions are made on any additional states of new physics [881]
which could influence the phenomenology of the 125 GeV state. [891]
A number of frameworks to investigate the coupling structure of the new particle [904]
are used at CMS~\citep{couplingsint}. The simplest of these is an unfolding of the production cross-section [919]
modifiers $\mu_{ttH+ggH},~\mu_{VH+qqH}$ by expressing them as functions of the couplings [929]
to fermions $\kf$ and vector bosons $\kv$ and is described here as an example. [943]
The decay rates to each channel are also expressed as functions of these parameters such that the overall [961]
yield in each channel relative to the SM expectation is parameterized. [972]
The ratio of the total width to that predicted by the SM is denoted $\kappa_{H} =\Gamma/\Gamma_{SM}$. [987]
Table~\ref{tab:kvkf} shows the parameterization of $(\sigma \cdot BR)(ii\rightarrow H\rightarrow ff)$ [993]
for each production/decay  included in the combination. The parameters $\kf$ and $\kv$ [1006]
are the couplings relative to the SM predictions for the Higgs boson such that the SM is recovered setting [1025]
$\kv=\kf=1$. The only non-trivial scaling is from the $\Hgg$ vertex (indicated by $\kappa_\gamma$) [1038]
which is needed to account for the contribution from the $WW$ and $\ttbar$ loops. [1052]
No invisible final states are assumed so that the total width, [1063]
$\Gamma$, is a function of $\kv$ and $\kf$. [1071]
[1071]
\begin{table} [1071]
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|} [1071]
\hline [1071]
& $\Hgg$ & $\Hzz / \Hww$ & $\Hbb / \Htt$ \\ [1071]
\hline [1071]
$ggH/ttH$ & $\frac{\kf^{2}\kappa_{\gamma}^{2}(\kf,\kv)}{\khf^{2}}$ & [1071]
    $\frac{\kf^{2}\kv^{2}}{\khf^{2}}$ & $\frac{\kf^{2}\kf^{2}}{\khf^{2}}$ \\ [1071]
\hline [1071]
$qqH/VH$ &  $\frac{\kv^{2}\kappa_{\gamma}^{2}(\kf,\kv)}{\khf^{2}}$ & [1071]
    $\frac{\kv^{2}\kv^{2}}{\khf^{2}}$ & $\frac{\kv^{2}\kf^{2}}{\khf^{2}}$ \\ [1071]
\hline [1071]
\end{tabular} [1071]
\caption{Boson and fermion vertex scaling as a function of $\kv$ and $\kf$ [1083]
for each production/decay included in the combination. Each cell represents the scaling [1096]
factor applied to the production (row) decay (column) combination.} [1105]
\label{tab:kvkf} [1105]
\end{table} [1105]
[1105]
Figure~\ref{fig:kvkf} shows the best fit values in the observed data [1115]
for $\kv$ and $\kf$ and the 68\% confidence contours determined from a scan of $q_\boldmu$. [1130]
The values are extracted independently in each decay channel and from the [1142]
full combination. In addition to the SM point, the fermiophobic Higgs scenario, [1154]
in which the Higgs boson does not couple to fermions, is indicated. [1166]
The data are compatible with the expectation of a SM Higgs boson; the SM [1180]
point ($\kv=\kf=1$) lies within the 95\% confidence contour defined by the data. [1192]
[1192]
\begin{figure} [1192]
\includegraphics[width=.8\textwidth]{combinations/Figure_014-b.pdf} [1192]
\caption{The 68\% confidence contours extracted from data in the [1201]
individual decay channels (coloured regions) and the full [1209]
combination (solid line). The yellow square shows the SM value, while [1220]
the fermiophobic and background-only scenarios are indicated [1227]
by the pink dot and red diamond respectively~\citep{HIG-12-045}.} [1235]
\label{fig:kvkf} [1235]
\end{figure} [1235]
