\chapter{Conclusions and Outlook} [3]
\label{chap:conclusions} [3]
[3]
The Standard Model of particle physics provides the most precise description of [15]
fundamental physics and remains  the most experimentally verified [23]
model available. The mechanism by which electroweak symmetry breaking occurs [33]
in the Standard Model, giving rise to the masses of the fundamental fermions and [47]
bosons, predicts the existence of a new massive scalar boson, the Higgs boson. [60]
Such a particle should be experimentally observable, although prior to the LHC being [73]
turned on, no such particle had been discovered. [81]
[81]
In this thesis, a search for this particle, through its decay to two photons, [95]
in proton-proton collisions recorded with the CMS detector, during 2011 at a centre of mass $\sqrt{s}=7$ TeV [112]
has been described. [115]
The decay channel, despite having a [121]
relatively low branching ratio, is one of the most sensitive at CMS [133]
due to the high resolution [138]
of the electromagnetic calorimeter and the narrow invariant mass peak it provides. [150]
The analysis detailed employed the use of several multivariate analysis techniques [161]
in order to provide the greatest sensitivity to a potential signal. [172]
As the signal yield in the two photon decay channel is small, [184]
the search for $\Hgg$ is highly sensitive to the background modelling. [195]
The signal extraction technique described in this thesis was one which was [207]
developed by the author and served as a cross-check of the published result from the 2011 dataset. [224]
This allowed for additional scrutiny on the background modelling [233]
to which the search in this decay channel is so sensitive. When combined with additional [248]
data from 2012 at a centre of mass energy $\sqrt{s}=8$ TeV, an excess near 125 GeV [264]
was observed with a significance of around $4\sigma$. [272]
[272]
In order to maximise the sensitivity of the search for the Standard Model Higgs boson, [287]
data from several decay channels are combined at CMS using the methods described in this thesis. [303]
An excess compatible with a Standard Model Higgs boson with a mass around 126 GeV was observed [320]
in the combined 2011 and 2012 datasets. The excess was [330]
significant enough so as to claim discovery at the $5\sigma$ level. The excess is driven [345]
by the $\Hgg$ and  $\Hzzl$ channels, although additional evidence is found in the $\Hww$ channels. [360]
With the data available by the Hadron Collider Physics symposium of November 2012, [373]
study of its couplings to Standard Model particles indicates that the new particle is [387]
consistent with the Standard Model Higgs boson, though additional data are required to [400]
make a definitive statement. [404]
[404]
The discovery of the new particle is one of great significance to particle physics. [418]
Should the particle turn out to conform to the predictions of the Standard Model, [432]
its discovery will have provided a great step towards understanding the nature of [445]
electroweak symmetry breaking. However, if this turns out not to be the case, [458]
deviations from the predictions will indicate hints of potential new physics [469]
and serve as guidance in the search for physics beyond the Standard Model . [482]
Additional data will be taken once the LHC resumes [491]
collisions in 2015 with an increased centre-of-mass energy of $\sqrt{s}=14$ TeV. [502]
With the additional data, stronger statements can be made as to [513]
the exact nature of the new particle and its interactions with Standard Model particles or potential other new particles. [532]
With this discovery in hand and the search potentially at an end, [544]
it is clear that a new window into fundamental physics has been opened, and the intriguing [560]
studies into what that physics is has now begun. [569]
[569]
[569]
[569]
[569]

\section{L1 Jet Energy Correction Fits} [5]
\label{app:jecfits} [5]
The energy corrections applied online at L1 to jets are derived in 11 $|\eta|$ bins [20]
corresponding to the 11 regions of the GCT. The values of the fitted parameters [34]
in each bin for the parameterisation in Equation~\ref{eqn:jecfit} are [43]
given in Table~\ref{tab:calibrationcoeffs}. These parameter values are extracted from [52]
fitting the L1 response as a function of $\Lonept$ as described in [64]
Section~\ref{sec:jetenergyresponse}. Figures~\ref{fig:allcorrfuncsp1} [66]
and~\ref{fig:allcorrfuncsp2} show the results of those fits in each $|\eta|$ bin. [77]
[77]

\section{L1 Jet Resolution} [3]
\label{app:closurefits} [3]
[3]
The L1 jet resolution measured in MC was shown as a function of $\Lonept$ before and after applying [21]
the derived jet energy calibrations in Figure~\ref{fig:mcresolutionl1}. The value of the response in at [35]
each point is taken from a Gaussian fit to the distribution of $\Lonept/\Genpt$ in bins of $\Lonept$. [52]
Figures~\ref{fig:mcresfits_u_p1} and~\ref{fig:mcresfits_u_p2} show the fits before applying the corrections while [62]
Figures~\ref{fig:mcresfits_pf_p1} and~\ref{fig:mcresfits_pf_p2} show the fits after. [68]
The central value for the points in Figure~\ref{fig:mcresolutionl1} are taken from the width ($\sigma$) of the fitted Gaussian [86]
distributions. The error bars on this plot are taken from the error on the fitted value of $\sigma$ which is too small to be visible. [111]
The improvement in resolution after applying the corrections is clearly visible. [122]

\section{Energy Scale and Resolution Measurements} [5]
\label{app:escaleandresolutiontabs} [5]
[5]
The energy scale and resolution is measured in the 2011 dataset using $\Zee$ events as [20]
described in Section~\ref{sec:superclusterenergyreconstruction}. [23]
The additional resolution required to match the [30]
$\Zee$ peak in MC to that of the data (Table~\ref{tab:eres2011}) is used to correct the [45]
Higgs MC for modelling the signal in the $\Hgg$ analysis. [55]
The scale measurements (Tables~\ref{tab:escale2011eb} and~\ref{tab:escale2011ee} ) are used to correct the energy of the [68]
photons in data. [71]

\section{Binning Algorithm Optimisation} [3]
\label{app:binningalgooptimisation} [3]
[3]
The optimisation procedure used to select the bin boundaries of the $\Hgg$ categorisation BDT [17]
involves a full scan over all combinations of bin boundaries. As this scan can be [32]
very slow, the procedure is separated into two parts, first a broad scan in large steps [48]
to find the region containing the optimum point then using small steps to refine the scan. [64]
The first step in the binning procedure is designed to ensure that at least 20 background [80]
events are expected in every bin. This gives a total of $B$ bins at a given luminosity. [97]
To maintain this feature, only boundaries which match any of the $B-1$ bin edges (remembering [112]
-1 and 1 are fixed boundaries) are scanned. The step size of the scan is therefore expressed [129]
as a step in number of bins so that for a given BDT output range, $(b_{i},b_{j})$ includes [146]
an integer number of the $B$ bins. The fine scan is defined to have a step size of 1, [165]
being the minimum step size defined this way. The step size for the broad scan, $P$, [181]
can be chosen to reduce the total time taken for the scan. [193]
For $N$ BDT boundaries, the scan is $N$-dimensional and the total number of points to scan [210]
(combinations of bin boundary values) assuming the two step procedure is given by, [223]
\begin{equation} [223]
\frac{\displaystyle 1}{\displaystyle 2^{N-1}} \left[ \left(\frac{\displaystyle B}{\displaystyle P}\right)^{N} [224]
+ (2P)^{N}\right] [224]
\end{equation} [224]
imposing the condition $b_{1}<b_{2}<\cdots<b_{N}$. [228]
Figure~\ref{fig:pmin} shows the total number of iterations required to perform [238]
the full scan for different numbers of boundaries as a function of the broad step size [254]
$P$. The value, $P_{min}$, which minimises the total number of iterations [265]
is the same for any value of $N$ and is given by, [277]
\begin{equation} [277]
P_{min} = e^{\frac{1}{2}\ln(B/2)} [278]
\end{equation} [278]
\begin{figure} [278]
\begin{center} [278]
 \includegraphics[width=.8\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/appendix/minimumtime.pdf} [278]
\end{center} [278]
\caption{Total number of iterations in the binning optimization scan as a function of the broad step size $P$. [296]
The curve is shown for different numbers of final BDT boundaries. The minimum always occurs at the same [314]
value of $P$ as indicated by the green vertical line.} [324]
\label{fig:pmin} [324]
\end{figure} [324]
The scan is repeated, increasing the number of boundaries until the improvement in terms of the [340]
maximum expected significance in the presence of a SM Higgs boson is less than 0.1\%. [355]
Figure~\ref{fig:binningopt} shows the additional sensitivity gained as the number of final BDT output bins [369]
is increased for different starting values of $B$. The red curve is representative of the actual scan performed [387]
for the 2011 analysis. [391]
[391]
\begin{figure} [391]
\begin{center} [391]
 \includegraphics[width=.8\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/appendix/newbinAlgo.pdf} [391]
\end{center} [391]
\caption{Increase in expected significance in the presence of a SM Higgs boson as the number of final BDT output bins [411]
is increased. The three curves show the improvement for different numbers of initial bins, $B$. [426]
The red curve is representative of the result obtained from performing the optimization procedure in [441]
the 2011 analysis.} [444]
\label{fig:binningopt} [444]
\end{figure} [444]
[444]
\section{Signal Systematics} [2]
\label{app:sigsys} [2]
[2]
The treatment of systematic variations in the signal modelling for the $\Hgg$ analysis described in [17]
Chapter~\ref{chap:hgg} is the same for all uncertainties except those due to the [29]
theoretical uncertainty on the Higgs boson production cross-sections and the integrated luminosity measurement. [42]
For each uncertainty, the relevant quantity in the MC is varied by 3$\sigma$ and the [58]
resulting BDT distributions are compared to the nominal one. The three ``templates'' (corresponding to [72]
nominal and $\pm3\sigma$ variations) are used to determine the $1\sigma$ variations of the $j$-th BDT bin [89]
of the signal model due to the $k$-th signal systematic ($\sigma_{k}^{s,p}$ used in Equation~\ref{eqn:slh}). [104]
The procedure is performed for each signal process, $p$, separately. [114]
The value for the $1\sigma$ variation in each bin is given by, [126]
\begin{equation} [126]
 \sigma^{\pm} = a \pm b + c, [127]
\end{equation} [127]
where $\sigma^{+}$ is the value of $\sigma_{k}^{s,p}$ used for positive values of the [140]
associated nuisance parameter and $\sigma^{-}$ is for negative values. [149]
The parameters $a$ and $b$ are determined for a particular bin by solving the set of simultaneous equations; [167]
\begin{equation} [167]
\everymath{\displaystyle}\begin{pmatrix} [168]
s^{-3\sigma} \\ s^{mc}  \\ s^{3\sigma} [168]
\end{pmatrix} [168]
= [168]
\begin{bmatrix} [168]
9 & -3 & 1 \\ [168]
0 & 0  & 1 \\ [168]
9 & 3  & 1 [168]
\end{bmatrix} [168]
\begin{pmatrix}a \\ b \\ c [168]
\end{pmatrix}, [168]
\end{equation} [168]
where $s^{mc}$ is the nominal value for the signal in that bin and $s^{\pm 3\sigma}$ are the values [185]
determined from the  $\pm 3\sigma$ templates. [190]
[190]
Figure~\ref{fig:additionalsignalsys} shows the $\pm3\sigma$ and $1\sigma$ variations [197]
of the BDT distribution expected from the $ggH$ production process calculated from [209]
MC and using the interpolation procedure respectively. The distributions are normalised to the expectation [223]
in \clumi. The energy scale and resolution uncertainties can be found in Section~\ref{sec:signalmodel} [235]
(Figure~\ref{fig:signalmodel_escaleres}). [236]
[236]
\begin{figure} [236]
\begin{center} [236]
 \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/signalModel/systematic_interpolation_test_idEff.pdf} [236]
  \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/signalModel/systematic_interpolation_test_kFactor}\\ [236]
 \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/signalModel/systematic_interpolation_test_phoIdMva} [236]
  \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/signalModel/systematic_interpolation_test_regSig}\\ [236]
 \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/signalModel/systematic_interpolation_test_triggerEff} [236]
  \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{hgg7TeV/sidebandMvaPlots/signalModel/systematic_interpolation_test_vtxEff} [236]
\end{center} [236]
\caption{Systematic uncertainties on the $ggH$ signal model. [243]
The effects of $\pm3\sigma$ variations [248]
derived in MC is shown with red dashed lines while the interpolated $\pm3\sigma$ are shown with blue.} [265]
\label{fig:additionalsignalsys} [265]
\end{figure} [265]
[265]

\section{Per-event Log-likelihood Ratio} [3]
\label{app:pereventllr} [3]
The combined observed significance from the ICHEP 2012 dataset, corresponding to $4.9\sigma$, [15]
is driven largely by the two high resolution channels $\Hgg$ and $\Hzzl$. Those two channels [30]
alone combine provide a significance of $5.0\sigma$ at $\mh=125$ GeV. [40]
Before entering the likelihood of Equation~\ref{eqn:likelihood}, the contribution from the [50]
events in each channel are first combined. For each channel, the sum over events $i$, [65]
\begin{equation} [65]
\log \call_{\mathrm{channel}}(\mathrm{data}|\mu) = \sum_{i}\log\call(i|\mu), [66]
\end{equation} [66]
represents summing the per-event log-likelihood at a given value of $\mu$. As usual, the [80]
value of $\mh$ is implicitly assumed in the definition of the likelihood, $\call$. [93]
Here the nuisance parameters are not explicitly indicated, although they are profiled in the usual way at a given value of $\mu$. [115]
The test-statistic appropriate for [119]
determining significances, $q_{0}$, can be expressed as the difference in the negative [131]
log-likelihoods ($\Delta(nll)$) for $\mu=0$ and $\mu=\hat{\mu}$ (the best fit signal strength), [142]
\begin{equation} [142]
q_{0} = -2\left[\log\call(i|\mu=\muhat) - \log\call(i|\mu=0) \right]= 2\Delta(nll). [143]
\end{equation} [143]
[143]
The individual contribution from each event in data in each channel can therefore be determined [158]
by considering the per-event delta log-likelihood. Figure~\ref{fig:perevllr} shows the distribution [168]
of the per-event log-likelihood in data for the $\Hgg$ and $\Hzz$ channels. [180]
The distributions expected under the background-only and signal-plus-background hypotheses, where [190]
$\mu$ is set to the best fit value, are also shown. [201]
In these two channels, there is an additional term in the likelihood which [214]
represents the normalization of the signal plus background model as the likelihood [226]
in these cases is unbinned. It should be noted that the [237]
best fit value for $\mu$ is evaluated from the combined data in the $\Hgg$ and $\Hzz$ [253]
channels so that the individual contributions from each datum can be positive or negative. [267]
[267]
[267]
\begin{figure} [267]
\includegraphics[width=0.49\textwidth]{combinations/perEvLLR_hgg8TeV.pdf} [267]
\includegraphics[width=0.49\textwidth]{combinations/perEvLLR_hZZ4l.pdf} [267]
\caption{Per-event delta negative log-likelihood ($\Delta nll$) distributions for the [275]
background-only and signal-plus-background hypotheses in the ICHEP 2012 $\Hgg$ (left) and $\Hzzl$ (right) [288]
analyses. The distributions for the observed events from each channel are indicated by the black points. [304]
The likelihoods are evaluated for $\mh=125$ GeV at the best fit values of $\mu$ from the combination [321]
of these two channels only.} [326]
\label{fig:perevllr} [326]
\end{figure} [326]
[326]
[326]

\section{Feldman-Cousins Boundary Effects} [3]
\label{app:fcboundaryeffects} [3]
The Feldman-Cousins procedure used to check the compatibility of the new observed [15]
particle with the Standard Model Higgs boson typically produces the same 68\% confidence [28]
contours as obtained from scanning $q_\boldmu$. [34]
Disagreement between the two methods is usually observed where the best fit value [47]
is outside the physically allowed region. However, for contours which are close to the [61]
boundaries of the physical region, the two methods will yield different results even [74]
if the best fit point is inside the allowed region. [84]
A simple demonstration of this effect can be seen in Figure~\ref{fig:comparefclh} [95]
which shows two contours in the $\muqqh,~\muggh$ plane obtained from data [106]
in the $\Hgg$  analysis on the ICHEP dataset. The signal extraction technique [118]
used here is the binned technique described in Section~\ref{sec:signalextraction}. [127]
The two contours shown are those at the 50\% and 75\% confidence levels from each [142]
method. These contours are chosen specifically in this case to demonstrate the effect [155]
of the boundaries at $\muqqh=0$ and $\muggh=0$. Although the 50\% contours [166]
agree well between the two methods, disagreement can be seen between the 75\% contours [180]
where the contour is close to one of the boundaries. [190]
[190]
\begin{figure} [190]
\begin{center} [190]
\includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{combinations/compare-fc-lh.pdf} [190]
\end{center} [190]
\caption{Comparison between 50\% (inner) and 75\% (outer) contours in data from the $\Hgg$ [203]
channel as determined using the Feldman-Cousins and a scan of $q_{\boldmu}$ (labelled ``Likelihood Scan''). [217]
In the Feldman-Cousins technique, the constraints, $\muggh \ge 0$ and $\muqqh \ge 0$ are [227]
imposed. } [228]
\label{fig:comparefclh} [228]
\end{figure} [228]
